reviewText:
Elite: Dangerous, I find it most likely that this installment of the Elite series coined the name after what its target audience becomes after being forced to watch a glorified loading screen of `Hyperspace`.

The learning curve was steep, the combat engaging and boy is it pretty.

This specific genre seems to throw several points in its favor; the graphics are very much a strong point as both the ships themselves and the landscape are in detail and quite charming.

You can choose your exact play-style, some of these I find to have their flaws made pretty obvious, your career paths are essentially split into violent and non-violent.

The violent style are done very well in my opinion as the combat is fun even if it is a little on the easy side, you could be the crime fighting bounty hunter; chasing down any and all with a high enough price on their head, if that's not your style, you could be the elusive pirate; pulling freighters from hyperspace to unleash a plethora of weapons and tools to force their hand in yielding their cargo.

The non-violent career paths i'm sure do satiate the fan-boys of the genres thirst for building up your own space empire from scratch, but quite frankly this doesn't happen and other games and franchises do it much more justice (looking at you X), that being said you do have the choice to play as the entrepreneur, you can make money by looking at the prices of goods in one sector and comparing them with the prices of another, basic old fashioned trader play-style, this to me took the point out of a game given the title `Dangerous` as the only immediate danger was the looming inevitability of pirates, which once reaching a high enough speed simply cannot keep up with you and give up the chase. although yes i'd be willing to bet that it is the most effective way to make your pockets heavier. Unfortunately the over excessive use of hyperspace makes it feel boring as most of your time is spent in hyperspace looking at said glorified loading screen for hours on end.

After finding the station you want to get to is several light-years away and that full speed ahead will still take you over half an hour staring at the glorified loading screen for the sweet spot in which the auto pilot tells you to slam down on the breaks in an effort to prevent you from impacting with said station at however many times the speed of light.
I don't mind this aspect, that is if the prompt would pop at the correct time, this simply doesn't happen and you will inevitably end up significantly off-course from your objective, god forbid you run out of fuel in doing so, as you have no option other than to twiddle your thumbs in a tin can floating in the vast emptiness of space with a limited oxygen supply.

Of course you could try and chase your fortune in becoming a miner, which isn't worth the thought as it just didn't pay in my experience, you sacrifice a weapon on your ship to give it the 'mining laser' which can cut through some of the most expensive and most durable minerals and metals in space, yet it won't scratch someone else's ship. if you get caught by pirates you're gonna have a bad day as you are now essentially unarmed with a full cargo of rare dirt. you'll either die or give up the rare dirt and have a slightly lower chance of dying.

So I've covered how to make money, now what to do with it?

You can upgrade your ship or buy new ships, you can't buy stations or any static property, hence `building up your space empire doesn't happen` oh and there is no point in buying more than one ship as you can't control them and have to keep them locked up in a hanger of your choosing.

Although I have said mostly negative points they are all negative points which could be improved upon or even fixed entirely, for instance adding an AI to player owned ships so you can command them to carry out the dreaded glorified loading screen jobs, as the galaxy they have made is a strong point I don't see why they couldn't add some player owned stations such as guild halls as it would offer a completely new front to the PVP field.

As for my recommendation, I wouldn't recommend this in its current state, especially not for full AAA price, I would however be willing to change my mind if the dev team concentrated on updating the balancing of the play-styles and sorting out the grinding aspects. It just needs a little dusting up.

Edit:This review is now outdated and several major flaws that I ridiculed have now been resolved, please don't base a purchasing decision on this review.

reviewText:
UPDATE: I recently was given the chance to try the horizons expansion, which I did. I spent a decent 8-12 hours in the game exploring, fighting, trading. I will say that it was quite enjoyable until I realized that the core game has not been improved in any way since the power play expansion. The game also suffers from some ridiculous frame drops ( I run 2x980's), so very poorly optimized and It has been two months since this expansion was released. The statistics of players that support and play the game has also been steadily dropping, likely due to the obvious money grab that this expansion has shown itself to be. It seems they forgot their initial goal of providing a solid PC space game and are now more worried about profits and maximizing their player base by porting to consoles.

Please, do research before you purchase this game. At one point I would have urged you to purchase this game without a second thought. Since the beta this game has progressively disappointed, mostly due to negligent development. (likely publishers pushing profit based logic).

Lots of potential in this game, utterly ruined. The game will likely die after this expansion, I will be surprised if another comes out. However, if that is the case and the game succeeds I will be waiting until all expansions are out, then purchase the most recent one and get ALL the content from the previous ones.

So let this one go for now. Maybe in a few years it will be complete.

reviewText:
I went whole hog for this, I invested in a HOTAS flight stick and prepped to really go at this, even after a short while's play I am left wanting in fundamental ways that I can't see a solution to.
Another reviewer put it better than me. Elite: Dangerous is an awesome game trapped inside a good game. Don't get me wrong, it is absolutely oozing with potential. Most of my criticisms ape the problems other people had with the game the whole notion of A Mile Wide and an Inch Deep is no exageration here. The framework is there. It is played out on a lovingly crafted engine that creates beauty procedurally and lets you fly through it in a well programmed control system. This game has so much polish you can see your face in it. You can was the glee drain from your face as you realise that once you've run back and forth with a few missions, pirouetted in a bunch of dogfights and landed your ship a handful of times. You've burned through all the gasp wow" moments the game had to offer.

Everything else is just growth by increments. Fly back and forth between stations until you get a bigger ship that can fly more between stations. The missions are procedureally generated and fall into 4 broad categories "Take this mcguffin to this place"
date: "Go out and obtain the following mcguffins then come back"
recommended: "Go kill these people and possibly take their mcguffins". Oh and "Donate money to this station because reasons"\n\nThe dogfighting is tight and action packed but feels very lonely and inconsequential. It wouldn't feel entirely alien to have the fights played out in timed rounds like counterstrike or something similar where everything resets at the end of the fight and you roll out to fight again. The limited variety of weapons in the game leave the meta stuck at the ground floor again
hoursPlayed: similar to roundbased twitch games.\n\nAt the moment if I want to dogfight
voteText: there are better games for that
helpfulPercent:
and if I want to haul cargo there are better games for that. There are games that offer more meta and certainly more human interaction.

This is less a "Don't buy this game" and more of a "don't buy it yet" wait for Frontier Software to fire out some more of the (very) promising additional content they are singing about. My flightstick now sits on the top of my wardrobe waiting for the day when I will look at what Frontier have added to Elite Dangerous and go "Daaaaaaamn I gotta play me some o that".

But that's not now. Or the near future."

reviewText:
Team play is over complicated, unexplained, and almost impossible to co-ordinate. Only bounties are really shared and there are no team missions. There are few to no objective markers and very little is co-ordinated.

All of the stations are the same and against the promise of scope there is in fact only a few types of planets and stars mixed endlessly to create the false image of a grand game.

While the game certainly has promise there is no way to play with friends nor co-ordniate in such a way that would make it meaningful. Even worse, there is no real purpose to solo play and no way to generate money effectively short of trading, which very quickly becomes a torturous grind.

I tried for over 40 hours to like this game. I wanted it to be good so badly. The co-operation, objectives and progression is so ♥♥♥♥ed up you will suffer playing this game. After you get the Type 6 freighter the price of ships raises exponentially, and profits do not. reviewText:
If you play elitie dangerous expecting it to have a predetermined story, guidelines to follow, or tutorials that hold your hand at all, then this game isn't for you.

However, if you're looking for a game that gives you the chance to pilot your personal starship across the galaxy, pirate, trade, bounty hunt, and mine asteroids at will, then this game might actuall suit you. Also, don't mistake my saying that this game has no predetermined story as meaning that it has no story.

In fact, it has thousands of stories progressing in real time. You find yourself mining in peace only to hear a news broadcast about a slave revolt in a nearby star cluster. If they succeed, the star system's economy would tank and the ore you're mining would become worthless, you think to yourself. Armed with motive, you swap out your mining laser for a multi-cannon at the nearest orbital station and head to the conflict zone, helping to quiet the revolt.

This game is a sandbox. The story, constantly changing and told through pieces of information you gather from every station across the galaxy, can be molded into whatever shape suits your needs and desires at the time. Like to RP? This game is your best friend. IN SPACE.

That's all for now.
See you in the stars, my fellow Commanders.
CMDR AZZARANDA, out.

reviewText:
Initial impressions: Elite Dangerous has amazing graphics, sound, and controls for a space dogfighting game. It lacks direction for the player and is a complete sandbox that will probably keep many casual gamers away, but this is a great game if you are willing to put in some time to get started and figure it out.

The graphics and sound still blow me away.


Update: After 20 hours of gameplay I can start seeing the bigger picture. I've also shown this game to a few friends and we now have a group of seven people for our private group (you play on a private server with people in your group).

Exploration is very time consuming, but a lot a of fun. Its mostly predicting where planets/solar systems will be in a specific system and trying to find them with scanners. We're currently trying to find unexplored systems with good spots to bounty hunt/buy ships/trade.

Combat is what keeps me the playing the game for many hours at a time. Dog fighting is very satisfying and everything about it just feels right. Controlling the multiple systems while in a fast paced battle results in vastly different skill levels amongst different players. This doesn't mean you need skill to do combat. You simply adapt your skill to a style. The best players can play in fast ships with close range weapons while others can back you up with missles, take shields off with lasers, or even snipe with railguns.

None of us have engaged in trading as of yet. Likely to try it out once we can afford some nice trading ships. We do know that exploration ties heavily into trading. Finding two systems that have differing functions close to eachother results in easy money from trading as they will buy the other systems goods.

Knowledge is a great source of power and wealth in Elite Dangerous.

Our group started with goals. The first being to find a system to call home and work around. Followed by finding shipyards and stations with good ships and outfitting services which we are still working on.

Later goals are likely to be extensive exploration / checking out faction wars / picking minor factions to support in our turf. Haven't decided if we want to play in the open world format. We are actually just looking to get our private group big enough to enjoy all aspects of the game as this game is a ton of fun with friends.

Game has been a load of fun for us. If you like space simulation games you'll enjoy Elite Dangerous. Might want to wait for the price to drop if you are unsure, but I think many players will enjoy the game as long as they know what they are getting into.

There is no main story. There is no real direction of you need to go here and do this. You start in a station and can do whatever you want which many people will take hours just figuring out what that even means. If you create that direction for yourself this just might be the space sim you always wanted. If not you will likely quit from boredom within a couple days.

Explore, Trade, and Fight. in 400,000,000,000 systems that are all massive in scale themselves.

reviewText:
I may be exaggerating, but the only thought that comes to my mind about E:D right now, is that this is the kind of game I wanted EVE Online to be when I gave it a try, back in 2004.

Do I recommend it? If you want a space sim with virtually no bounds, where you start as a nobody, to carve out your own path, this IS your game. The 400 billion stars of our very own Milky Way, will become your playground.

Old timers, who've seen much steeper learning curves than this, won't have much trouble. New guys however, will need patience and the foreknowledge that in this game, there's no such thing as instant gratification. It's called Elite for a reason.

reviewText:
Great combat, extremely polished ui. Complete lack of content makes the game extremely boring.

Can not give my seal of approval  unit they make the game worth playing. There is literally nothing to do but grind missions or trading. There is nothing that rewards the player and there is no multi-player interaction. No guilds, no player driven economy, no crafting, no group oriented content. It's just empty.

The base game ie... the flight, the combat, the ui... they are all fantastic and the game has tons of potential but it has ZERO content.

Add some stuff for people to do and I will most certainly come back and change my review, feel like I paid for a game and got a foundation of a game instead.

reviewText:
Played almost a hundred hours in a week, so i'd say it's ok ;)

Seriously though, i wasn't sure this game would draw me, as i was looking to pass the time till star citizen and no man's sky, but boy did this one hook me. Yes it is repetitive, yes you can't land on planets, yes there is no offline mode, but overshadowing all these is the sense that this game is actually alive and real. You are a nobody in the whole wide universe, but work with the community and you can change it little by little: Help terraform a planet and expand civilization by transporting the necessary materials - side with the rebels in a star system to overthrow the existing goverment (or the opposite, crush the resistance!) by taking part in the war - and who knows what the devs will come up with next..

Best part for me though is you can play vastly different roles, that actually matter (even if only a tiny bit) within the universe - and you can do this playing solo (no griefers and still all the community fun).

- Exploration: 400 billion stars to explore! The fun is in finding desirable rare things such as earthlike planets and black holes, then selling the cartographic data for profit and also putting your name on a planet as the first to discover it. Will you play it safe making short trips near on the edges of civilization ? Or will you go an a month-long journey to explore the edges of the galaxy ? What if you carry data worth millions and happen upon a skilled pirate ?

- Pirating: It's not always as simple as blowing up other players. Many pirates will let you go for a price. But pirates beware, for as soon as you commit any crime inside civilized star systems you should be very afraid when another ship beginns to scan" you. You'll be hunted down if you happen upon a security ship or even worse...:

- Bounty hunters: You'll be having fun hunting pirates
date: taking part in small- or large scale wars. Or why not team up ("wings") with a trader and see hiim safely through anarchy space ...for a price ?\n\n- Traders: If you fancy yourself as a trader
recommended: prepare to be noting down prices alot (or use online crowdsourcing tools)
hoursPlayed: searching the map for industrial and high-tech places or agricultural and terraforing places etc to trade between. Or maybe you'll make your mark as a trader of rare goods
voteText: which become more profitable the farther away you sell them.\n\n- Miners: Tired of blowing up ships? Then blow up some rocks! You'll be searching for pristine metallic reserves in asteroid belts and rings
helpfulPercent: hunting down the pieces you laser off said asteroids and racing to a place in need of your metals and minerals. Beware though
votesHelpful: pirates are aware of your favorite places.\n\nAll in all
votesTotal: if you're looking for an immersive experience look no further. Just be patient in the beginning while learning the controls and understanding how the universe and your ship's parts work. It is well worth it - and this coming from a player who really seldomly plays the same game more than a couple hours."

reviewText:
Elite: Space Trucker.  I say this as a compliment, this game is unique as it's one of the few games to truly embrace what is required for a game to have serious longevity, massive amounts of boredom seperated by instances of knee jerkery.

What I just said probably won't interest most players though and that's the real shame here since this is an incredibly well done experience.  The level of immersion in this game is borderline annoying but somehow that just makes everything better.

In this quasi mmo experience you are not a unique and special snowflake like in every other mmo experience, you aren't here to save the world, you are not the prophecy fufilled and no one cares about what you do.  Just attempt to learn how to pilot your ship, try to make money and generally just get by...and that's pretty much everything you need to know about this game.

I recommend everyone buy this game not because I know every one of you will like it, I want you to buy it to give more money to the developers so they can continue expanding this amazing game, but if you don't like it and you feel you wasted your money then you should come back here and say This review was helpful" because clearly I warned you.

Seriously

reviewText:
Rewriting my original review since 1.3 came out and changed the game in many ways for the better!

Also note that while I don't have that many hours clocked in at the time of writing, I played the game months before the developers gave pre-Steam purchasers Steam keys. I would estimate I have played 200 hours, 220 total if you include the 20 hours I've already clocked on Steam

Elite: Dangerous is a fantastic game. It's certainly not for everyone, but I don't see how anyone could deny that what it does right, it REALLY does right.

Elite: Dangerous is a space simulator game set in a recreation of our Milky Way, with 400 billion stars to explore. It uses procedural generation to keep that insane number up and it's gigabyte total down.

But only a couple hundred systems are actually inhabited, and if you don't plan on being an explorer, this is where all of the action will happen.

There's many different careers you can choose from. The most profitable and infamous one is trading. It's undeniably profitable, but also boring to many. This used to be the only way of making money quick, but post-release updates have made other careers viable as well.

Bounty hunting can be a good and fun way of making money, but you're gonna need a decently kitted out ship before you go down that path. You can also mine asteroids for metals and minerals. Mining was greatly buffed in the 1.3 update with the inclusion of collector drones, automated drones that collect cargo and bits of asteroid so that you don't have to pick it up manually.

Smuggling is like trading except with illegal goods. You can smuggle drugs, slaves, or regular commodities that you got from an illegal source. Smuggling is slightly more profitable but also risky, because if you get caught while hauling a big load of drugs, you'll have quite the fine to pay off.

Then there's exploration, which utilizes the 400 billion stars. Once you get a few hundred light years out, you'll start finding systems that *literally* no other player has been to before. When you eventually come back to civilization with your exploration data to sell, systems that you were the first to discover will be marked with your name on the map of that system.

Once feel like you've made enough money with any of those career options, you can dive into Powerplay. Powerplay was introduced into 1.3 and adds much needed end game content.

Powerplay is a galactic conquest. You can pledge allegiance to a Power which will give you special benefits and rewards, and you'll then be able to help your Power out in a number of ways. These differ depending on what kind of Power you pledged to. Some are focused on combat, like the pirate Archon Delaine, and some are focused on diplomacy and finance, like Felicia Winters of the Federation.

When you join a Power, you are subject to attacks from members of opposing Powers, which can be both NPCs and other players (you'll only see other players if you choose to play in Open mode).

You are also free to attack members of opposing powers without penalty from your own Power.

The whole point of Powerplay is to maintain the systems your Power owns while at the same time expanding into new ones. Both steps are crucial, as players of opposing Powers can attempt to undermine your control and expansion attempts, meaning you need to coordinate and group up with fellow Power players to get work done.

There's a lot more to Powerplay but this is a review of the entire game, so I should move on.

Elite: Dangerous is divided into 3 modes of play.

Open play will match you other Open players whenever possible.

Private group is where you can easily set up a private game with up to 31 friends, where you all will be guaranteed to get in the same instance together, without interruption from unwanted players.

In Solo you are the only player.

All of these modes affect the universe in the exact same way. Solo players can affect Powerplay in the same universe as Open players, it's all interconnected. Some see this is a good thing, and some see it as a bad thing.

Many Open players believe that Open should have some extra reward, since you are taking extra risk by playing in Open. Solo/group players say that would be unfair to them who chose to play the game the way they want.

Personally, I think it's a genius system, but not one without flaws. Open players do have a point. Solo play has a lot less risk for the same reward.

But at the same time, E:D is not supposed to be a game about huge player combat. Sure, there are PvP encounters in Open, but the game isn't about that, and the fact that the game is instanced means that it would never be able to support Eve-like encounters anyways.

But in the end, it's great that players have the choice to play how they want, whenever they want. I am exclusively an Open player but I see why people would like the calmness of Solo.

Let's talk about the cosmetics. The graphics and audio of this game are fantastic. The audio has to be heard with headphones, everything is just so detailed and you really feel like you're in a spaceship.

Same with the graphics. Space is beautiful, and the game's amazing lighting amplifies that even more, and it still runs great on almost any rig.

Elite: Dangerous is hands down the best VR game yet. I've had the chance to try it in an Oculus Rift DK2 with a full joystick and throttle setup, and it's breathtaking. It works so well because of the nature of the game. In real life you're sitting in a chair with a stick and throttle, and in the game you're sitting in a chair with a stick and throttle. It translates perfectly.

Your inputs actually translate into the game, you can look down and see your character moving the controls the same way you are, which is obviously amazing in VR.

Speaking of controls, there's lots of options and they are all great. In VR you basically have to use a joystick and throttle for maximum immersion, but on a monitor there's tons of great options. Keyboard and mouse works perfectly, gamepads work great, you can even use a single joystick without a throttle if you have one lying around.

There's currently 22 ships in the game. The goal is to eventually have 30 ships, but what's there is already very diverse, and there's plenty of ships for each price range.

The game has a very ambitious future. What's planned for paid expansions is the ability to get out of your seat and walk around your ship, or even get out of your ship to walk around space stations or board other ships. They are also planning seamless planetary landings. We haven't seen any of this in action yet so don't buy it because of what the game might be, but it's still good to be informed on what they're planning.


Let's end it with some pros and cons.

Pros:

* Amazing graphics and audio

* Decent variety in career paths to keep it from being too boring

* Best VR game to date

* Great ship variety

* Seamless mode transitions and easy-to-set-up private friend groups

* Good co-op functionality with the Wings feature

* Great range of options for controls that all work great

* Implements real life astronomy. If you love astronomy in real life, there's tons here to keep you interested in it's scientific side.

* Fun mission system

Cons:

* Easy to get burned out when going for the high tier multi-million ships

* Peer to peer architecture causes some connection issues and also makes it relatively easy to exploit the game (the devs are thankfully cracking down on this and have banning lots of people recently)

* Some minor bugs

This isn't the game for everyone. It isn't non-stop combat and thrills. But the uncertain nature of the game makes those encounters all the more exciting when they do eventually happen.

Do some research, watch some videos, and decide for yourself. This game is perfect for me and what I like, but if you are looking for an arena-combat type of game, this isn't it.

Thanks!

reviewText:
This game is beautiful. It's flashy. Entertaining at first.

But then you come to know the grind. A boring grind, at that.

I'm going to give you the basic ideas of this game and not get into the small details, such as ship hardware/weapons.

This is a game where you can do missions, trade, mine, explore and bounty hunt. Out of these options, only two, arguably three are worth your time.

The missions are all stale and repetitive as hell, and don't provide much reward for your time unless you're in the early game.

Trade is basically just taking your time to figure out a good route, and going from point A to B and back again selling things. That's about it. Sometimes you'll get attacked by an NPC, but mostly you can just run away unscathed. Possibly the most boring and time consuming part of this game.

Mining is pretty RNG heavy and not very profitable.

Exploring consists of going very very far away from civilization and looking at planets and stars, scanning them, and then returning home. Eventually you'll find what spherical objects are more worth looking for and it will quickly turn into a stale grind.

And finally, bounty hunting. Bounty hunting in this game is the number one reason I've played it as long as I have. The best way to get money, in my opinion. You go to a resource extraction site (mining area) and pick off NPC pirates that spawn and try to kill the NPC mining ships fruitlessly. The ship combat is fun to a point, but as with everything else in this game, turns into a stale grind.

The point of making all of this money?
Buy a better ship. Buy better weapons and parts.
And when the price gaps between ships go to extreme amounts after the early game, that's when you maybe begin to realize: Oh. This game is a grind and there's not enough to do to keep me interested."
And you stop playing.

If I only had to pay $25

reviewText:
안녕하세요 (hello in Korean)  So you want to know how Elite Dangerous is? At first i was like yay let's play this awesome space game. This game is so boring that even writing this review is boring.

Game constantly rips your soul and hopes with every patch.
Before community goals we had community that searched for ways to give you ways to make you rich. Like smuggling seeking luxuries. It got nerfed and deleted.
With power play there came high risk slave trade smuggling which made quite a buck, but fun is forbidden in this game, only Korean MMO grind is allowed here! So it gets nerfed 3x so it's actually less profitable than legal trade but with thrills and chills from possibly getting astronomical fine!

What you can do in this game? Is it Eurotruck in space? Not even close, in ETS2 you have stunning scenery. Here you have red ball and black background with dots, more dots more dots. You trade from A->B you worry about pirates? Go to single player and middle finger those mmo players that try to bring something thrilling to the game.

Exploration? Be the first guy who gets shot by another guy in center of galaxy because lot of people try to visit this scenery, so once again you'll probably go into solo because your exploration ship is no match for full combat armed conda parked in the center of galaxy just to shoot you down. Exploration boils down to, red ball, hit scanner, yellow ball hit scanner, white ball, hit scanner, something ball hit scanner.

Smuggling? Same as trading but without the profit and with risk of police scanning you and giving you big fat fine.

Bounty hunting? Why you even try? Bounty hunting in big ship will barely make enough credits to repair your ship integrity repairs.

Mining? Underpaid spacerock blasting and sending drones to pickup floating rocks, no skill required, no profit gained.

Glorified grinding game where you have no sand in your sandbox. This game does not simulate anything. Trading same route for 4 months with no change to supply or demand. Solo/Open play does not matter same boring stuff.

Sound effects are epic in this game and that's about it.

SUMMARY:
To do other things than ultra boring grindfest trading, you have to do trading to fund your other desires. If you die in ship that cost quite a lot, expect hours of trading to pay back insurance costs. If you die you lose hours of tedious boring grinding trading.

reviewText:
My angry review of this great, yet somehow awful game:

Let me start this review off by stating that I am a pretty picky gamer, and I tend to arrive at the conclusion that a game is flawed more often than concluding a game is good, and much less often, great. If that is a comment on the state of the gaming industry (AAA and unfortunately, now indie) or my general cynical bullsh*t is a question for another day.

Like so many other titles I've played recently I was floored by the initial impression I got from Elite: Dangerous. The graphics are beautiful on my freshly built, glowy gaming pc, the flight mechanics are out of this world (enough to buy the game for if that's your modus operondi) and tooling around with a joystick is incomparable, and the scale and beauty of the universe (1:1 scale of the Milky Way I've read) is breathtaking. That being said, it feels kind of like... an arcade game? I don't know something crucial is really missing here. There are obvious culprits, the missions are lackluster, even when compared to the considrably dreary missions of EVE Online, the carebear professions are horrifically one note and not satisfying, and there is just a wall of boredom and shallow gameplay you will run up against that is utterly game breaking for me.

I played my first week as a mission runner and then a bounty hunter when that got tiresome. At first bounty hunting, with my real life friend who also purchased the game, was a blast. We flew into nav points, resource extraction sites, and even interdicted a few wanted criminals and blasted our way to a small fortune. The fights are sometimes interesting, but 9 out of 10 times you will be assisted by security forces or other credit hungry players and the fight will be one sided, and like everything else about this game, decidedly one note and flat. I honestly can't bring myself to log on and its got me even thinking nostalgically about EVE, which is not healthy. I might keep playing every once in a while with my friend, because like i said I am a cynical a**hat and he thinks this game is great. I always feel like the odd man out when reading raving comments on so many games that just feel sh*tty or unfinished, like people are dancing around the problems to get what enjoyment they can out of a game until the community collectively decides it sucks. Elite: Dangerous feels like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ waltz around a gaping black hole in that regard, and a lot of waltzers will get aggressive and throw sh*t at you if you point out that black hole, but I think that sentiment might stem from a desire to see this game succeed because of the awesome flight mechanics and the scale of the universe. I get that, everytime I get into flying I want so badly for this game to be better, but it just plain isn't.

The developers have promised a heap of features, walking on planets, entering cities, more social and building aspects, but I don't buy anything devs sell in that vain without proof anymore because I've been burned and (/equip Tin Foil Hat) keeping customers playing with false or unrealistic content promises is a good model for making a quick buck by keeping a solid enough playerbase to attract more suckers - I mean customers. I could only honestly reccomend this game to space flight buffs and Oculus users curious to try something other than walking down a creepy hallway or looking around a classroom filled with dolphins, and only at a reduced price, in its current  state. Personally I'm going to hold out hope that Star Citizen lives up to the hype, try to stay away from EVE until then, and kick myself repeatedly when this title goes on sale for half price before likely going belly up when the Devs can't deliver the moon, or at least the ability to land on one.

3/10

reviewText:
First off, awesome game if you like awesome, I do recommend it.

- Use a Joystick
- Go through the training
- Watch the youtube tutorials

^^^^ If you don't do the last two first, you will be doing it later.  Though the game is not SUPER complex, without knowing a few of the basics you will get lost, and traveling at ludicrous speed and trying to figure out how you get out of supercruise is not a fun chore.

The game really shines everywhere in my opinion, it is beyond measure in size, it is BEAUTIFUL even on an Nvidia 660TI, the combat is fun, but what I love most...

The immersion.

How do they do it you ask?  There is nothing you can't do from your cockpit, in fact, everything is done in the cockpit, as though you were sitting in the seat of your own spacecraft.  Need to check what sun that is you are flying dang near into?  Turn your head to the left.  Need to get into your ships sub-systems and turn on some external lights so you can see the wreckage you found exploring?   Turn your head right.  The way the menus are done just floors me, I feel like I am really there.

Story time!

So, today, about 7 hours into my actual game play, I ended up getting a little to close to a sun.  Got warm, ok not just warm, like hot and it started to fry my systems.  I lost lifesupport, shield recharger and my FTL, crud, going to run out of oxygen in 4:30...how do I get to a station for repairs in 4 minutes without my FTL?  Well...lets see what sort of systems we have in this thing...holy smokes a reboot and repair option under my sub-systems, lets give it a shot.  *ship goes dark, sun is bright, ship systems rebooting*, whoa, what the heck.  FTL has been repaired to 10%, I can divert all shield power and scanners to my FTL to get it to spool up and wammo!  On our way to repair city!

^^^ That right there was probably the best experiance I have had in a game since Master Chief met the Flood for the first time.  I can't wait to see what tomorrow brings, I am headed out to a system a bit farther from the start, do some exploring, come back and sell my data, I think it will be a good day.

For those that stuck with it and maybe enjoyed what I wrote I hope it helps.

reviewText:
I'll use the game's own ranks (from the CQC arena mode - which I find to be the most fitting). More general thoughts below.
The rank order is as follows: helpless, mostly helpless, amateur, semi professional, professional, champion, hero, legend, elite.

Potential: Elite
World size: Elite
Sound: Legend
Graphics: Hero
Flying: Professional
Ship Variety: Professional

Location Variety: Amateur
Equipment Variety: Amateur
Bounty Hunting: Amateur
Multiplayer: Amateur
Mining: Amateur
Longevity: Amateur
Mission variety: Amateur

Economy: Helpless
Trading: Helpless
Smuggling: Helpless
Exploration: Helpless
Player/NPC interactions: Helpless
Mission narrative: Helpless

Pricing model: Helpless
Outlook: Mostly Helpless

General thoughts:

- It's not feature complete and it's not content complete.
All existing features are bare bones, never or barely touched again after original release.
For all intents and purposes, one year from release and now with a paid expansion in tow, this is still an Early Access title.

Prime example - bounty hunting is just sitting in a certain location waiting for a wanted ship to appear, killing it in about 30 seconds and waiting for the next one to appear a minute later, repeat ad infinitum - sadly this is the general level of fidelity to expect.

Two main types of activities - combat (random encounters/fish in a barrel scenarios) and fetching (A->B trading/smuggling/mining). There's also exploration, but that is just flying from system to system and pressing a button.

- Paid expansions only come bundled with the base game, so you'd have to pay for the base game every time (DOUBLE DIPPING WARNING) - you can play in the same universe without them though. First paid expansion is as bare bones feature-wise as the base game.

- Great setting with beatiful sound and visuals and enormous, yet unfulfilled potential.

- Roughly 40 hours of enjoyment to be had in the honeymoon phase, mostly due to the above.

- Contrary to the game description, it's not an MMO and never will be. Instancing could be compared to lobby multiplayer, where you will have a lot of trouble getting into the same lobby with your friend(s). Generally in Open Play there's a handful of places where you can meet players and 95% of the time you won't see a soul.

- Shrinking active player base - outside of sale/update spikes it's falling steadily. Now that there is a paid expansion with (some) planet landing, the number of players you might encounter in space will be further affected by the number sitting on planet surfaces, if they're not already in Solo Mode that is (always online single player universe). Out of the estimated ~600k owners on steam less than 1% plays the game regularly.

- The game is not very difficult or complex (it's not a simulator in the proper sense of the word and that's perfectly understandable), flying/shooting is pretty arcade, instead the perceived complexity stems from lack of in game information that you need to find elsewhere (no in game help tooltips/popups for entry level players). It's not hard, it's just very unintuitive.
Trial and error should suffice though, you should be up and running in an hour or so, few hours is enough to breeze through all mission types the game has to offer (some missions are so unintuitive that you might need to read wikis/forums beforehand though).

- Overall, it's a game of great unfulfilled potential, marred by a disastrous pricing model and the lack of proper feature iteration. In short, it's a 1984 game design with 2015 graphics/sound.

Recommendation:

ON SALE ONLY
(around 2017 or 2018)

reviewText:
I've been a fan of the genre since I was a child - Freelancer, Elite, Pardus, the X3 series, MOO3. Elite Dangerous could have been the game I've been looking for ever since the original Elite. It's got an amazing engine for generating the world around you procedurally and I'm sure it's a technical marvel in that sense.

However, and this is a big however, the game is almost absolutely empty. Every system is so similar to the last system. There is barely a difference between the major factions, beyond a few ships they give you. It's so frustrating to be presented with a universe that looks so gorgeous and you want to find your way in and then find that the universe is so shallow and that you're limited to a few roles that are super repetitive. The universe is beautiful, but quite dead.

The economy is almost completely static. Missions are limited to basically a handful of types. Once you've seen the few types of starbases, you've seen them all - they're literally the same in all the factions. There isn't even a difference in style between factions, let alone base types.

The more I play this game the more frustrated I get with how sterile it is.

Don't get me wrong, there is an amazing engine running under all of this. But the devs need to add more and varied content to the base game to justify the (quite heavy) price they've charged, before they start focusing on paid expansions.

reviewText:
As it stands right now, Elite: Dangerous, compared to other space sims, is lacking depth and content. Yes the graphics are beautiful and it's a huge universe but it's also generic and repetitive and has pretty much been done before just on a smaller scale. Don't get me wrong, I'll come back to it every now and then as I enjoy the combat but thats where it ends for me fpr the following reasons:

1. Smuggling is 2 dimentional, you just line up with the mailbox at 7.5k out, ask permission to dock, fly at full boost speed untill your in the docking bay so you don't get scanned by authorities, it's easy, and boring. Trading is the same except your not doing anything illegal.

2. Ship customization is minimal and linear.

3. Exploration is repetitive and boring, go to system, hold down button to scan, congrats your capable of holding a button, here have data you can sell for a minimal amount of credits, repeat.

4. Military career consists of joining a conflict zone, popping a load of ships for an hour, going to a station to hand in combat bonds, realise you could have made more in 20 mins by being a bounty hunter.

5. Pirating is just as boring, you can't even interact with NPCs to order them to drop cargo or surrender, it's just the same process of scan for cargo, oh look they have goods, target cargo bay doors, shoot some cargo loose, blow up ship, pick up cargo, repeat.

6.I never once thought that even the most densely poplated systems where teeming with life, which is a problem given the theme.

Elite: Dangerous feels like it's got potential and it's certainly aethetically pleasing but the content just isn't there yet, it's like what COD is to ARMA in some ways. I'll make amendments to this review as time goes by and updates are released, as I hope the devs take advantage of this games potential, I really do.

reviewText:
I bought the game for $60 as it looked really cool and fun to play. Sadly it wasn't, even if I tried really hard to discover something which was. I feel Team Braben has created a good looking game but have no clue at all what's making a game fun to play. Here are my comments of current state of game. It has more or less been the same recent half year. Nothing has really changed for the better about my negatives...

- Trade system:  If I take a risk to carry very expensive cargo I expect to earn more than when I carry cargo cheap as waste for example. That's not the case at all in this game. Several monthes ago you could find really lucrative trade routes where you felt you could earn credits for a new ship. But it's completely gone. When I play a game like this I expect at least from time to time find a golden route, but that's not the case at all any more. All price difference is more or less the same. It doesn't matter if you buy very expensive cargo or cheap like waste. You will earn equal much. Several times I have been suprised about the prices. At one time I bought very expensive cargo and just got 23 credit in profit for each ton even if I expected the station needs those cargo like industry needs metals and agriculture needs crop machines. The galactic average price doesn't work at all as those planets which you expect to have need of food or minerals or whatever buy it below average price more or less even if the planet is on a different system. The trade system is crap. They have completely ruined the trade system.

- Mission: This has also become much worse than before. Before you could earn credits by taking from time to time lucrative missions (it's like finding a treasure), but no, no. Not anymore. You need to do lots of missions to gain faction 24h a day so you after lots of time invested in just that sun system can take mission which gives you little more money. They have completely destroy the mission system. Not fun at all. It doesn't feel like a game anymore, more like a boring work. You will not find any golden missions here either.

- Combat is bland. Not so fun to deal with as I hoped. It cost a fortune if you loose your ship as money is hard to come by.

- Mining feels like a work, even if the mechanism is fun, as you earn very little from it.

- No story exist. Not even conflicts between worlds or alien invasions which draws you into the game.

However the graphic and sound is really good. Sadly the rest really destroys the fun. I will change my review if I see the game change for the better (see my critics above). I will try the game maybe once each other monthes.

reviewText:
Update Nov 15: I am updating my review based on recent developments with the release of an expansion that costs $60. Per my original review the game lacked a lot of features and was quite boring after the intiial learning curve. The expectation was that the base game would be developed further.

Now it seems the strategy of the developers is to keep releasing $60 expansions for features that should be added free to the base game. This is a real kick in the face for supporters that bought the original game knowing it was bare bones and trusting the developers to flesh it out.

Star Citizen releases in 2016, I would wait for that rather than give these guys another $60.

Original Review

I could have gone both ways with my recommendation but 1 thing is sure, ignore those people writing a review after 20 hours or less of gameplay as they have no idea what they are talking about. The game is in honey moon phase for those people where you are still learning to fly, learning the various careers (exploring, mining, trading, bounty hunter) and you don't mind grinding a little to get the next ship because the grind is a few hours, the game is fun.

As the game progresses trading becomes more and more powerful until nothing else compares from a credit earning point of view and at that stage all you are doing is flying between 2 stations buying and selling commodities in order to buy your next ship which costs a lot of money. My next upgrade requires 22 hours of this back and forth trade grinding.

I think the game has a lot of potential however at $60 and considering current content I cannot recommend this game. It should have been released for far less with paid DLC later on. It really needs a lot more meat on it at that price.

reviewText:
I backed this on Kickstarter. I don't really regret it, as the procedurally generated universe here is truly stunning -- you can effectively visit every star in our galaxy. That said, there is only one boring activity to do at 99.999% of them, and what there is to do at the rest is either boring, grindy, or both. The combat is the only fun part, and that pales in comparison to Star Citizen's Arena Commander. The game is extremely wide, but has all the depth of a kiddie pool.

The real reason I can't recommend this game is because of the newly announced Horizons expansion pack. It is going to cost the same as Elite: Dangerous, and include the entire game. This is awesome for new players -- you can get the whole game + the expansion for the same price as I paid for the base game. For me and anyone who's already purchased, though, it's a gigantic slap in the face: they're only offering us a 25% discount, effectively charging us nearly double for the same content. This is on top of a game that still feels very unfinished and has almost no interesting content past the first few hours except for PvP, which again, is done better in other games.

Don't support these greedy devs. Check it out in a year or two, maybe it will be worth the reduced price then. For now I'd recommend checking out Star Citizen, or a classic like Freelancer.

note: my time played is significantly higher, did most of my playing before the Steam release.

This just doesn't have that depth and variety that it could and the open play is almost completely devoid of other players. reviewText:
This game has so much potential. If you're expecting a big epic space adventure, you may or may not get it, depending on what your definition of epic is.

I find expecting it to be sorta a, space truck simulator, keeps my hopes undashed. It's fun to wing up with friends. Problem is you never really encounter as many people as you see in the trailers. They're few and far between.

How big this galaxy is, is really a blessing and curse. It's impressive but not always fun.

There's really not much to the Horizons expansion. You can land on planets! --But only planets that are entirely rock. There's a lot to be desired with the planetary exploration. As of now, it's just big rocks of different colors, sometimes with a dock or two, occupying a speck of an otherwise bleak and empty world. Apparently there's more to come later this year though.

IDK. I still enjoy the game. It's a major grind fest though. What action you find will almost always just be against NPCs. There's lots of time spent just kinda, driving. It's fun, impressive, big. but certainly has it's drawbacks.

reviewText:
Don't buy this game. Your first 50 hours will be glorious but after that you realize there's nothing left. All it becomes is, grind for money (credits), buy new ship. Grind for money, buy next ship. Once you have the ship you want, guess what there is to do: more repetitive missions that are not really dynamic other than NPC names.


If you really want to buy it, wait for the new expansion because if you buy this you'll get screwed over when you want more content than just a grind. The new expansion doesn't sound all that great anyway because it's just adding the ability to land on planets and use a glorified RC car. They have seemingly ignored everyone's pleas to walk around in your ship or even step off your ship in first person.

I don't know, I just feel let down. I'm definitely going to be watching Star Citizen and No Man's Sky. Both of those show more promise and hopefully the devs don't charge you $40+ to buy an expansion that only lets you land on a few planets and drive a stupid RC car.

-probrably better if you have a joystick or something like that(keyboard and mice is fine though just preferance)
-you have to do things yourself without much help(I do not mind since I like to do my own thing)

Final Verdict: I personally thing this game is very fun and also challenging. If you like to do your own thing and like space sims, this is for you! I plan on putting many more hours on this game right after this review is posted.

Edit: Powerplay info added.

Do not let the play time fool you. I have over a thousand hours in this game. Frontier unlocked Steam keys to Beta backers, and now I get to write a review about this game.

reviewText: I want to love this game, but so far it has been such a hollow experience. There is little wonder in exploration and attempting to get started on most of the content feels tedious. And even in open play the universe feels incredibly lifeless. Maybe this will change in future expansions, but at its core it feels like there is a fundamental lack of purpose in the game. I will likely keep playing it in the hopes of discovering something... SOMETHING in it, and there are small moments of brilliance (sound design, the first time you emerge from a jump in front of a star), but as it is, I cannot recommend this title.\n\nEditing to add some thoughts: You will notice that my playtime in this game is still going up, despite my review here. I am certainly finding things to enjoy about this game -- most notably now that I've started to just Captain Kirk my way across the stars into empty space. But I stand by my comment that much of the experience is hollow. The lifelessness has little to do with the emptiness of the universe, but more to do with the interactions as you have them. The only interaction you get seems to come from bulletin boards and news feeds. You never see anybody's face or have their voice spouting faction propaganda at you. Basically, your CMDR is extremely isolated from anything that might be going on in the game. There is no soul to the interactions that you can have. I think the idea is for players to experience an emergent story, but it's hard to get drawn in when your experience is kept at a sterile distance. So I've decided to just forget about the community part of the game and embrace lonely exploration. Because the game seems to do a simulation of that very well. It is a beautifully constructed simulation, and I don't mean to detract from that in what I am saying. I just can't really recommend it to others. Read some of the replies that others have given to me, though, and decide for yourself.

reviewText:
When I first bought this game, I paid a sale price and fell in love with it.  It felt like space.  I could haul, I could kill, I could explore, I could trade, I could take shady jobs or I could be a community pillar.  I could sway politics here and there.  I could screw up a system by blowing up a dignitary.  I could find my own damn star, and I did.

And then three weeks later, an expansion was announced.  Horizons.  For $60 more I could get content that wasn't included in the game, and two more full-price expansions were on their way afterward.  $210 to get the entire Elite experience, or pay for the season pass...  $40.  No.  I did not buy a product that I would need to keep buying over and over when it was clear that the new content was just unreleased content.

Sorry, Frontier.  You should have finished the game before asking a full-game price.

reviewText:
I like it for all the reasons that others say they don't in the negative reviews, in fact I bought it based on those reviews.

I like that you are not forced to take on some fictional persona, who turns out to be an orphan of an ex rebel military hero who, as becomes clear later, is befriended by the villain in the early throws of the game.

I like that it actually takes time to travel anywhere and there is no quick magic jump to somewhere just because I've been there before.

I like it that there is a vast expanse of space to explore and that there are parts which are sparse and isolated.

I like that if you forget to refuel and trek off into the outback of the galaxy, you probably will run out of fuel and have to, knowing the consequences, activate the self destruct sequence.

These game play ( negative ) positives are then cemented for me by the best straight to play x52 pro joystick integration I've encountered so far, along with well implimented support for trackIR and an easy to use UI.

I usually wait for the sales to buy most of my games, but being a big space trading, pirating, exploring game fan ( Privateer the Darkening, X series, Battlecruiser 300 ad, Frontier Elite, Dark Star One etc... ) and seeing that the only thing most players complained about were the things I liked, I took a risk paid the full price, and I am glad I bought it to play now.

reviewText:
I bought this after the Horizons pricing controversy, so I don't care about any of that. I was hesitant to buy this game initially, after reading about how grindy it is, from all the reviews here, but when the Vive came out, I needed a good VR game to play. And despite the grind, I loved it for a bit. When I got too burned out on one thing, I'd take on a different role (ex, trader, explorer, miner, smuggler, bounty hunter). But with the latest 2.1 release, that's no longer possible. The NPCs will blow you out of the sky, within seconds, unless you have max out your ship for combat, making it useless for any of the other roles.

Pros:

* Huge, mostly unexplored universe.
* Great sense of immersion in VR.
* Nice graphics and ambiance.
* You have a lot of control over your ship.

Cons:

* Way too grindy. And as of 2.1, you can barely earn enough to cover your insurance costs.
* NPCs are overpowered and cheat.
* Not enough variety to ship types and modules.
* Most missions are pointless. Repetitive, not too fun and not enough reward.
* Takes way too long to rank up. Most people do it through mission exploits, but many of those have been removed.
* Very high learning curve, those first couple of days.
* No way of building your own base/station, means there's little to work towards.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this game to anyone right now. I'd wait for those other space sims to come out first. I figured this would hold me over until those come out, but it's become unplayable since the last update. Even without the AI changes, they've removed the most fun smuggling missions from the game, while simultaneously making other means of earning income much harder. It's grindy and shallow and all of the casual elements have been removed. It might be worth a look, if you're unemployed, but the devs seem to be moving further in the wrong direction, rather than address the avalanche of criticisms of this game.

reviewText:
I am no veteran in the Elite series, neither am I an expert at simulators or survivor games (bar Stranded Deep) so my review is honest.

It is very in depth and well thought out. You can trade, become a pirate or a bounty hunter, choice is yours, and you can switch between the paths quite easily. You build rep with factions with the list of factions being endless.

The world they have created is huge, I mean HUGE! My advice: I highly recommend this game, get straight into it but I must warn you that it doesn't offer much of a tutorial, its just you, your ship and endless, vast nothingness that is space and whatever it may contain.

All in all, if you're looking for an easy, enjoyable, worth-your-money space sim, look no further!

reviewText:
The overwhelming positive reviews of this game and the idea of a huge scifi sandbox convinced me to fork over the $59 price of this game and I regret the decision.

There is a very loyal/vocal fan base to this game but they seem to be more in love with what the game is sold as than what it really is.

The combat feels like a reworked WWII flight simulator and even has machine guns complete with downward arcing bullets... so what is pulling them down? I guess some sort of cosmic gravity.

Even though you are flying near huge" space stations and gas giants nothing feels epic. The scale is all wrong. Planets are these little balls that hardly dwarf your ship
date: asteroid belts are tightly packed chunks that are more like an arcade game version of asteroids than the gut churning
recommended:
roller coaster in the Star Wars franchise or even SWTOR... while you are on rails the effect is still cool.

The "giant" space station's scale is wrong. If you got out of your ship (as they promise is up coming) then you would tower above the buildings that surround the landing pad. I guess you are a space giant...  Maybe it is your mass that pulls the bullets you shoot downwards.

The game feels as incomplete as it actually is. There is little need for social interaction and even less a point in it. You can go solo and earn tons of money until you can afford an uber fighter and then go kill noobies in Open Play. If you are a noobie then there is no benefit to Open Play other than you can experience bankruptcy if you get griefed a couple times.

The story is not creative or original. If the game was incomplete but there was a cool premise then I might be more forgiving. Basically you have a federation
hoursPlayed: an empire and an alliance. (How many times has this been done?) There are a multitude of smaller factions spread out through the systems but they are aligned with one of the three and have some basic stories that go along with each but it all feels like it makes no difference.\n\nFederation advancement for me stalled out with an invitation to SOL
voteText: but it mattered little since I had basically paid for the rank with some "donations" and seemed to get no benefit by being a "Federation Officer"
helpfulPercent:
not even help when under fire near a Federation ship...

Despite the weak story and stale game play I kept playing in hope that somehow it would connect and I would feel engaged but it never happened. Even as I upgraded ship after ship I could not help but feel let down as each felt and operated not much differently from the intro level ships.

A space game should feel epic. The large celestial bodies should dwarf you

reviewText:
2-5-16 Update: They just censored tons of negative reviews for Horizon's by removing it as a separate game and switching it to a season pass for the base game.  I'm fine with the switch as it now shows the 'expansion' for what it really is; I'm not fine with the censoring of all those reviews.

They also lowered the price (by $7) and removed the base game from it. Now you have to buy both if you're a new player (for a higher price). This makes Horizon's an easier swallow for existing buyers, but they're still charging us for content to an extremely bare base game.

No other company I know has a business model like this.  It's awful.

---
There's only 3 things to do in this game.

1) Fly around transporting text from identical hangar to identical hangar for minimal text profit.
2) Fly around trying to find pirates and destroy them for a text reward (or kill innocents yourself to become a pirate.. which just means people get text for destroying you; die and everything is forgiven).
3) Fly around and go AFK for hours while you try to leave the map and explore systems that somehow haven't been explored yet, for a text reward.

There's some slight variations on that, but it's basically all the same.  Mining is the only different one, but it's so barebones that it's not even worth mentioning (shoot at rock, get text, sell text).

I got a week worth of playtime, and I had to push myself to do that.  Bought an x52 to do it with too.

It is fun (and very immersive) at the start, but once you see the game for what it is, there's nothing to do but grind and grind and grind for text (credits) or text (reputation).

What's worse than having next to no content?  They're charging the full retail price for an update, a 'season of expansions' they're calling it, for a feature they promised to be in the game in their Kickstarter. Edit: Which is nothing more than the Mass Effect 1 planet rover. Actual planet life, and walking on it, dubbed Atmospheric Landing" will "hopefully" be in the next paid "season of expansions" in 2017.

What's worse than that?  They plan to have multiple paid updates.

And even worse?  The season pass for those updates is $200. Edit: And was $50 in beta before most people knew about the game. Edit2: And now you can't buy it anymore.

Frontier have rapidly become scumbags
date: like Bandai Namco charging for Dark Souls 2's DX11 update.  Hell
recommended: now that I think about it
hoursPlayed:
I'm surprised they didn't charge for the Powerplay update. Edit: Apparently the ability to form a party was considered expansion content too.


Avoid Elite: Dangerous

reviewText:
I concur with most of the other negative reviews so will not repeat what's already been said.

Great fun to begin with and the combat system is pretty cool, but ED quickly becomes repetitive.

There are two key issues from my point of view:

1) This game lacks any sense of purpose. I’m used to games where you grind for money such as EVE online, however, with EVE online you have a multitude of ways to invest your hard earnt money such as building player owned space stations or assisting in developing your corporation/alliance. With Elite Dangerous, the only thing you need money for is to buy a bigger ship or a better upgrade.

2) Although this game is labelled as an MMO, player to player interaction is extremely rare at best and never encouraged. In my 140 hours of play, I came across 2 other players that said 'hi' and then went about their business. Not sure if the developers intend to improve this but DO NOT buy this game on the proviso that it is an MMO. Honestly... it feels like a single player game. Even a galaxy wide chat channel would assist this greatly as this would give ED a sense of community.

I got to 140 hours of play and finally realised... WHY AM I DOING THIS???? I thought to myself…. after grinding for what would likely be 100’s of hours to get the best ship, what would I do next?

I really wanted to love this game and it has A LOT of potential, however, it just doesn’t deliver in its current state. I will continue to keep an eye on this game in the hope it will become something greater, but for now….I’m done!

Some of the funniest moments i have ever had in a game are here.

I couldn't recommend this game enough, though with saying that.... Only buy it if you are keen on mastering a steep learning curve.

This game wont hold your hand for you when you load in ( I spent a few good hours working out wtf i was actually doing) You are literally carving your own RP experience here, down to Bounty hunting, Trading across the galaxy, Pirating, Scavenging, Mining, Hired merc and the list goes on.
http://elite-dangerous.wikia.com/wiki/Elite:_Dangerous_FAQ

The best thing though is that you are not limited on what you do, the possiblities are pretty nuts so far and they are only getting better.

Meeting up with friends has never been easier in a game and i think they have nailed it pretty well here.
From adding a friend and inviting him as a Wingman You are able to lock onto their targets, follow their jump paths, help them when they are interdicted by another player, and much more.

I think one of the best selling points for this game so far would be the fact that it not only supports Open (Online) but also supports Private mode (Friends) and a Solo mode (AI) And everything you gain will still roll over into the other game modes.

With all said and done you have to remember that It is a sim at its core and everything else is a bonus. Expect a steep learning curve and be prepared to bang your head against ur desk or what have you every now and then.

I recommend watching a few vids or tune in on a few streams before you buy and definately check out their road map :)

reviewText:
(Steam playtime is not indicative of actual playtime, have logged well over 500 hours thus far, done all that there is to do.)
Don't buy if you intend to play the game for any longer then a few hours a week.

Progression is stunted, player impact on the world limited. Content post mid game is a grindfest that makes most Korean MMOs blush.

Early game will last you around 20 hours, after that you hit the wall and start discovering the limitations of the design at every corner. Where mechanics are supposed to be complex and have depth, you discover that it is only a illusion.You end up with a very bitter taste in the mouth with the realization of just how great this game could be, but is held back.

Visit 4chins Video Game General on Elite, ask there about the game instead of the official forums. You will get more realistic responses that are actually grounded in reality.

Finally, I would say check back in a year, but of late Frontier has gone from one asinine design choice to the next, while apparently attempting to slash and burn as many markets as possible to push sales. Its not looking good overall.

reviewText:
My experience thus far.

The beginning of this game i got pretty lucky. I ended up in a big battle against a single ship, it was maybe 6 vs 1. In the end after a few died we won and i gained 50,000 credits, i was hardly even 30 minutes in the game. I went to buy a new ship because i thought i could make a lot of money trading. I was dead wrong... trading is not as profitable as i hoped or i'm just the worst trader in all of elite.

Later on i lost my ship to a really stupid reason. I was on my way to a destination carrying expensive minerals. Out of warp I'm flying directly into a white dwarf. I veer off but the heat is real intense. Thinking I'm safe from this little monster, i try continuing to my destination. After i enter warp my heat climbs up to 330%... What? I'm not even close to the sun and I'm taking intense heat damage. The damage was so severe more than half my ship was disabled. I start shutting off modules and redirecting power to my last thrusters, i was so glad my power distributor and power plant was still functioning. Sadly though, my life support was down, i only had 5 minutes to get to my destination. After an intense battle with MY OWN ship, I made it! But didn't have enough time to dock... I died just outside the docking station in front of like 5 people. Completely humiliated, I'd still definitely choose to die again, the feeling of being on the edge of death in deep space is too entertaining. But this isn't the reason i permanently lost my ship, it's what lead up to it.

After you die in game you are have the option of re-spawning your ship under the condition of a loan, which they take 10% of all profits till that percentage pays it off. I foolishly thought i could choose which ship i could spawn with and still keep my hauler which i spent 48,000 on. Lost my ship... for good. After enough scavenging with my sidewinder, i finally get enough money to buy another ship, I bought my first Eagle. before buying my Eagle i said F*** it

reviewText:
Hadn't given much thought, bought the game. Oh Lord.

Those moments where you're in a vicious dog fight, you've gone all-in with your power fully routed to your weapons...

...you realise the lunatic is flying straight at you, your ♥♥♥ puckering instinctively as you exchange withering salvos...

...you swing low at the last moment, thrusters maxxed and shields crying for mercy like an ignored child as you follow the eerie, looming mass of illuminated, torn metal up, up, up in a deadly ballet...

...the delicious, throaty crackle of his engines spews thunder into your ears but he's too late; your weapons are lined up squarely with the back of his ship and his hull is at 8%.

You fire.


You sit back, soaked in the glory of Elite when you look down at your pants... that's not sweat. You're covered in your own ejaculate from the waist down.

Br@zzers / 10, better than porn

reviewText: Elite: Dangerous it is one of those titles that make you want to travel to the ends of the universe just to see if there is something to discover. One of those games that not everyone wants to deal with but for this become even more special. Elite: Dangerous it is a game for ten and a game seven, packaged into a single experience that is still incomplete, but full of possibilities. We make the average between the two souls of the title knowing that the judgment could grow with the materialization of the potential of the game and the update promised by developers. Gaps, however, do not diminish the experience currently available is of the highest level of trade, smuggling, this dynamic, mysteries, flight mechanics and intriguing 400 billion systems to explore. The limits are a brake support multiplayer experience, this is undeniable, but Elite is all in flux.

reviewText:
Avoid like the plague.
Game devs keep making idiotic or self serving choices and listening to fanboys and sycophants instead of reasonable beta testers and content idea providers.
Power Play was almost a complete failure to provide meaningful content and the game is full of menial tasks (like log on every 30 minutes to get forts instead of being an automated process).
But at least the Power Play weapons were balacned. Some strong, some weak, tweaks made, more needed. And they were available to all players.

Now though they went full Pay-to-Win mode with the expansion, giving absurdly overpowered weapons and modules and stuff. Basically the DEVs are forcing people to buy the expansion at gunpoint. A great pay-horizon has been put in place of any competitiveness left in this shallow game.
Some GUI changes were good and others were bad, leave it alone please"-bad. Missions content and rewards balance is better but gui is worse

reviewText:
I'll be evaluating from a players perspective the information they have posted on the Steam store page, ie what perspective buyers are meant to read before buying the game.

About this game
Elite: Dangerous is the definitive massively multiplayer space epic, bringing gaming’s original open world adventure to the modern generation with a connected galaxy, evolving narrative and the entirety of the Milky Way re-created at its full galactic proportions.
Massively multiplayer, if your definition of massive is 32 players per instance. That's right, you can only ever play with 32 other humans in the same instance, and everything in this game is instanced.
An evolving narrative... that the developers control the creation of, pacing of, and ending of. You're just an observer.
Yes, the galaxy is very large.

Starting with only a small starship and a few credits, players do whatever it takes to earn the skill, knowledge, wealth and power to survive in a futuristic cutthroat galaxy and to stand among the ranks of the iconic Elite. In an age of galactic superpowers and interstellar war, every player’s story influences the unique connected gaming experience and handcrafted evolving narrative. Governments fall, battles are lost and won, and humanity’s frontier is reshaped, all by players’ actions.
Doing whatever it takes
date: = grinding in Resource Extraction sites, or grinding trade routes, or if you're incredibly masochistic grinding exploration (more on that later).\n\nEvery player's story influences the unique connected gaming experience and handcrafted evolving narrative." = I guess if you grind enough you can make a name or number change on a station or system. Literally nothing else happens. Stations all look the same
recommended:
and never change regardless of what happens. You can't build stations. You can't make stations appear. All that is chosen by the developer.

400 Billion Star Systems. Infinite Freedom. Blaze Your Own Trail.
Infinite freedom... to do what? There's very little interactivity in this game
hoursPlayed: almost non-existent.\nYou can really only shoot things to interact. And don't even get me started on exploring
voteText: hint: you basically watch loading screens 90% of the time... I wish I was joking. Fanboys literally say that watching a loading screen is a major part of the gameplay. I seriously wish I was joking here.\n"Blaze your own trail
helpfulPercent:
I like this saying. Totally meaningless. There's only one way to get ships, grinding credits, and boy oh boy is it a grind. This is a worse grind than vanilla WoW back in the day. This is great if you want to fall asleep staring at your screen. Expect to hold down your fire button (bounty hunting), or fly back and forth repeatedly until your eyes bleed (trading in a nutshell). Exploration consists of watching loading screens and is awful at making credits. This is my biggest letdown. Exploring is so awful, downright offensive really. It's the height of non-interactive gameplay. You literally point your ship in a direction, and then watch a loading screen. If you want to scan an astronomical body you point your ship in its general direction and if you're close enough (which to get close you basically watch an ETA timer count down) you start scanning. God is it ever mind numbing. And 99% of everything looks exactly the same, so don't bother getting close enough to make anything bigger than a handful of pixels.

A Galaxy Of Wonders
The 400 billion star systems of the Milky Way are the stage for Elite: Dangerous' open-ended gameplay. The real stars, planets, moons, asteroid fields and black holes of our own galaxy are built to their true epic proportions in the largest designed playspace in videogame history.
The largest designed playspace in videogame history."
And the only way to interact with the environment? Well... there is none.
I guess you can shoot an asteroid

reviewText: First off let me say I never write ranting reviews. Seriously this game got me so excited and I loved it...for a while. Then I realized it was the most shallow experience they could have cobbled together and any semblence of realism you feel that gets you excited you realize is heaped on bs physics and terribly simple AI patterns with painfully little to do that was fun or interesting. The most fun I had was wiping out the chumps with bounties that love asteroid mines for some reason.\n\nThen the new season" comes out and I think ok cool I can't wait to see what they added to make this a game. You have to buy it! Are you ♥♥♥♥ing serious!? I don't care how many jackasses say they warned you on their kickstarter that this was their pricing model. The fact is the steam page is built to mislead you into thinking the game will be a living world updated by developers who give a ♥♥♥♥ about your experience. I can't stand to read one more review justifying their "plan" for this game because their plan is to pull the wool firmly over your eyes and then under deliver and over charge. I cannot wait for No Mans Sky because it has to be better than this admittedly lovely looking attempt. End of rant."
