reviewText:
So I waited and waited and waited.... but finally bit the bullet about a month ago and purchased ELITE Dangerous.

Was highly sceptical - I've played many a space game over the years, never been fond of Kickstarter campaigns and remakes of old games, very old, very popular games?  Nah, was never going to work.

Well I couldn't have been more wrong.  After a month or so down the line I have dedicated over 300 hours to this game so far and not touched another game since.  Simply very impressed.

Currently I play in Solo mode (PvE mode), though you can play in PvP (player v player v AI) - though I am happy with Solo for now.  The tutorial is worth checking out for this will give you a chance to get used to some of the controls, I also found it useful to priint out the keyboard layout, though this was only needed for the first 24 hours or so.

First time I played I had little to no idea what I was doing, there is no hand holding in this game and it is very much down to you to find your way" in it. Though you will want to try a little of everything

Now they are releasing a DLC for full price called ED: Horizons, which restricts everyone from being able to use the new content added that allows people to land on planets unless you pay the same price the game is now AGAIN for it. These guys made an awesome game, but they are going down the same money-hungry trail that Evolve and COD went. The implementation is just boring and repetitive, travelling through space with cargo or grinding at a resource site for bounties. That is the only way you can make money, the missions are trash and are either scooping up cargo in space or transporting cargo or killing someone. That's it. However the game is beautiful, it has great potential, but it's sad how they've ruined it.

No Man's Sky or Star Citizen, this is trash.

reviewText:
So what kind of game is Elite Dangerous you wonder? In a word, contradictory.

In a few more words: impressive, dull, beautiful, hollow, detailed and repetitive.

The galaxy is immense in size and scope with millions (billions?) of different stars and planets to explore but travelling across it often takes a very long time and once you've seen a few stars and planets they all more or less look the same.

There is a lot of missions you can sign up for but they are just the same few basic job types (deliver cargo here, kill this person, mine some ore, etc) which don't offer you much engagement or sense of purpose/investment and they pay pathetically little compared to the time invested and the amount of credits you'll need to buy the higher level ships. Worse, they often involve travelling somewhere and hanging around for a contact to show up (well the contact might show up anyway).

Combat can be fun, it certainly looks and sounds fantastic, but has very little variation as there is only a handful of weapons/combat upgrades to equip on your ship. Even the different ship classes (in similar price brackets) don't vary much as they've been 'balanced' against each other for PvP.

Overall, there is a lot of attention to detail through the game (each ship has a unique engine sound, beam lasers leave glowing score across your targets hull, etc) and that will keep any space sim fan entertained for a short while but eventually you realise that you are just grinding and don't have any sense of purpose or goal outside of buying another ship.

So is it worth playing? Absolutely. The first couple of hours in game had incredible atmosphere with the huge attention to detail that has been given to the travel/fuel system, the ships cockpits and sounds/visuals. After that though it becomes a tad tedious and time consuming in a bad way (jumping into a system, flying to a station and docking can take 10+ minutes even if you're only doing it to spend 5 seconds to click the refuel option).

If you can pick this up during a good sale, then you'll probably get your money's worth but I can't recommend it for full price, not when you could pick up the X3 Albion Prelude pack for a lot less, and though not as pretty it is a solid game with a lot more variety and content.

And if the wall of text above looks too daunting or simply too boring to read, here's the translation...

Pros:
- Incredibly beautiful graphics
- Amazing sounds
- Attention to small details often overlooked in other games
- Ship insurance (pay a fraction of the total cost to get your ship back if destroyed)
- Realism (atmosphere when travelling around is well created....)

Neutral
- An immense galaxy to explore (albeit pretty repetitive and shallow)
- Customisation (can be fun but very limited options and not always clear exactly what benefit an improved part will give your ship)
- Has an array of tutorials for some basic skills to play the game but not totally inclusive of everything you need (after doing all of them I still had to go searching for some controls for the cockpit like changing tabs in the console screens)

Cons:
- Realism (….but damn, does it take a very long tedious time to travel around)
- Lack of purpose/investment
- Quickly becomes a grindfest
- No depth. The great visual feast disguises a pretty hollow and basic space trader/shooter

reviewText: The game was Released as a complete game but the available content makes it play and feel more like an Alpha.Not an alpha in the sense that it is buggy, the bugs have been worked out and what is there is good quality and playable just lacking in content.  You can choose several ways to grind out your fortune. You can be a bounty hunter, an explorer or a trader. All are grindy which is an aspect to all games but you grind to get a bigger ship then grind more to get an even bigger ship. What can you do with the biggest and best ship out there once you get it? You can grind to put the best parts and outfit your ship. There is no endgame, nothing to do once you get the better ships but more grinding. There is no ultimate goal to achieve or epic battle to be fought. Zero endgame unless you count getting a title next to your name of Elite as a worthwhile endgame achievement worth all that grinding. The game just feels like it is missing a reason to play.\nThe best part is instead of game updates to get the game where it needs to be the developer is releasing expansions" PAID expansions so you get to pay extra to get the game from it's current Alpha state to a good playable version.  This might be ok if the initial purchase price of the game wasn't in line with AAA game title prices. The price for the expansions are also $60 which in line with a AAA game initial purchase price per expansion.  To top it all off if you buy it now you get to buy it again when the "expansion" is released as the expansion will cost $60 and include the core game. If you buy the core game you still get to pay $45 for the expansion so you get to pay twice.\nThis game has great potential and I think it will be a great game in the future
date: maybe after 6 more $60 paid expansions it will realize it's potential and be a great game to play. If that sounds good to you then order now if not there are plenty of other space sims out there that currently offer more bang for your buck.\n\nI know I am showing a lot of hours played and some of it is the case but keep in mind if you just close the game window and leave the background screen up Steam continues to count that as "in game time" in addition the hours and hours I have spent in game have consisted of 99% of going to one space station and buying goods to sell at another space station that looks exactly like the first rinse and repeat. I have done some battles as a bounty hunter and fought in conflict zones but both pay very little in credits (the in game currency) and the battles arent very exciting either. Shoot for a while
hoursPlayed:
shoot some more the enemy is dead rinse and repeat until you run out of shield booster then return to the space station to get more shield cells and return to battle.

There is no MMO aspect to the game. Players all (as in everyone) play on solo mode and the maximum number of players in an instance is 32 anyways so it will never have the MMO player interaction or social aspect to it. The number of players you can see or interact with will always be limited because Frontier chose the cheap way out and all player interaction is via a peer to peer internet connection.
I play with friends and there is very very little we can do together due to the way the game mechanics don't allow you to share profits or credit for actions. My friend can escort my cargo ship and he can get 5% of my trade profit.  I can't opt to give him more or less it is always a straight 5%. Not even enough to make it worthwhile to be an escort. Players can team up and bounty hunt together and share profits and that is about it. (Just make sure you are bounty hunting NPC's see below comments for the explaination on that)
There is very little reason to group up or to do anything other than solo with the current gameplay model. To be more specific there is no in game content that is very challenging when playing solo so there is no reason or benefit to teaming up and therefore few people do it. There are no guilds

reviewText:
Intense, that is the word I would use to describe this game. For those of you that remember Earth and Beyond this is a much more in-depth version of that game. It is a simulater first and foremost so keep that in mind, but it is not overbearing like current flight simulaters.

What I like most about this game is that you have complete free will on what kind of star commander you want to be. You can join a federations military and patrol starports and nav points, you can be the space explorer and search unmapped space, be the trader/smuggler between star systems. Pirates are very real and yes you can join them as well or become the bounty hunter and hunt the pirates. A full on PVP enviornment makes the game intense as soon as you see another player performing a scan on your ship, you immediately begin to wonder what, where, and why!!

I also highly recommend a Joystick for this game, it really adds to the immersion of flying your own spacecraft! And please do not skip the tutorials! the Flight School is needed because you will be expected to land and dock into spaceports on your own! Learning curve is about 30mins, but well worth it.

reviewText:
I have heard a lot of complaints about steep learning curve and difficult controls.

Admittedly I was using a 360 controller, but basically I have only done 1 combat tutorial and 1 docking tutorial before diving straight into the game where I have only had a few minor issues (see below). I thought controls were easy and straight forward to learn. I am however old enough to have played the original and so the mechanics of the game were somwhat familiar.

I've also heard people saying it takes ages to get anywhere (distance wise)  but to me (compared to the original) it seems about right. Judicious use of the frameshift drive eats up distances in no time at all. If there is an issue there at all dropping out of frameshift is a little clunky, it's very easy to overshoot, but I'm sure that will come with practice.

The only other issue I've had is sometimes finding your designated landing pad can be frustrating, and it sometimes takes an age before it realises you have landed. May be something I'm missing as I've skipped so much of the tutorials.

I've barely scratched the surface of the game, but the game itself is shaping up to be the amazing sequel we all know is possible. Yes it probably is a game that plays best with a controller, but on what I have seen so far can only recommend it, especially if you were a fan of the original.

reviewText:
Don't be fooled. Elite: Dangerous is a single player space exploration simulator dressed up to look like an open world MMO.

You can do three things.

Trade: spend countless hours jumping from station to station, maybe slightly harassed by easily avoided NPCS, farm cash so you can buy the biggest baddest ship and then continue trading because there's noone worth PVPing with.

Explore: After farming enough cash to outfit a ship for exploration you can venture out into the void and spend your days scanning(way more boring than you think) and scooping fuel from stars(tedious and you might blow up thus negating all of your efforts), if you find some undiscovered worlds you get your name on them as the first discoverer(whoopy). Eventually you return to civilized space to sell all of your exploration data, buy the biggest baddest ship, and PVP with noone.

Combat: The least lucrative way to farm cash is to hunt NPCs, for bounties or as part of a simulated and meaningless war, you can also steal their cargo by blowing them up but it's far from worth the hassel. Eventually you can buy the biggest baddest ship and continue fighting NPCs because anyone worth PVPing with is playing in SOLO.

That's it, I've literally described everything you can do in this game. This is not EVE, you cannot go around pirating people or even taking over their solar systems. Everyone worth pirating simply plays SOLO.

SOLO is the game mode where you are in the exact same universe and your actions still affect other players, you can do all of your exploring and trading free of hassel from otherwise fun seeking fellow players. You can literally farm in SOLO until you have the best ship, then switch to the Open World" and PVP with noone. Also players who wish to infleuce the universe can sit in SOLO and undo anything that any organized group willing to play in OPEN has done.

If you do manage to find a few people to PVP with you will be treated to instancing issues. Coordinating with a large group of other players to attempt an assault? Just warped into the system where the bad guys are? Great! You got dropped into the instance with 10 enemies
date: all of your friends got dropped into a different instance and while you are getting blown to bits
recommended:
they are flying aimlessly in circles unable to help because of instancing limitations.

Oh and don't forget they already ported it to console so don't expect the PC version to get any love.

tl;dr this game is for single player space explorers who don't want any threats that could pose a challenge.

Should you buy it? No

reviewText:
Frame Shift Drive Charging…
The explosions of exiting a wormhole in a system that you have never laid eyes on in our own galaxy hundreds of light years away from our home, Sol, is one of the pinnacles of the breadth of escapism you can experience in Elite Dangerous.  With over 400 billion potential experiences like this with the game’s model of our own Milky Way Galaxy, you are sure to have more than one experience like this.  But this may be a bit too much or lacking for others who choose to join the ranks of the Elite.

Elite Dangerous sticks you right in the pilot seat with nearly full control over ever aspect of the craft you will be using to navigate and traverse our galaxy to make your name and stake your claim in the galaxy.  There is training available in the way of mainly combat, however most of the other activities in the game that can be used to make money for new ships and upgrades, as well as upkeep are left out.

There is very little hand holding in Elite Dangerous, for some people that can be a great thing, however for those who need a little direction, you may be a little overwhelmed.  Nearly any façade of generating a credit flow with a space craft are feasible to you as a pilot in Elite Dangerous.

Exploring:  If traveling on the edge of the known galaxy is your thing, equipped with a fuel scoop you use to gather fuel for your exploration vessel and a few scanners to identify systems and the surface of space bound objects, exploration is by far and nearly an endless venue for you.  With your ability to collect and gather data as an explorer you are able to make your credits by going where no man has gone before.  Selling the information for varying prices based on its value, is how you will be making most of your money as an explorer.

Combat:  If strapping as much firepower to your fighter and doing various missions for the highest bidder as a soldier of fortune is your thing, a combat focused profession holds a lot of potential.  With bounty hunting, pirating and various missions for the multitude of factions that exist within the game you are sure to always have something new to test your metal in the heat of battle.  Commanders have the ability to interdict, check bounties, and pirate their way to the top with different outfitting options for any ship in the game.

Mining:  Staking a claim in a system’s resource extraction point, gathering minerals and refining them into money producing items is the miners claim to fame.  It isn’t easy and it takes a special type of person to achieve this livelihood.  But with the right ship and the right tools and even allies this can be a good way to make large sums of money without having to travel too far.


Trading:  If finding product in high supply being sold at a lower than galactic average price and selling it to another system that has a high demand is your thing; trading is one of the best ways to make large sums of credits quickly.  This profession isn’t for everyone but with various ways to accomplish roughly the same goal like smuggling, pirating, stealing, scavenging, and even running rare goods long distances, it feels as though Frontier spent a lot of time making sure the games economy was fleshed out.  Stolen goods?  No problem, sell them on the black market.  Don’t let the feds scan you or you will be space dust.

Overall graphics and sound in the game is done very well.  With the ability to use your HOTAS, pedals, gamepad, keyboard and mouse and even products such as the Oculus Rift you are sure to get exactly what you want out of your desired level of immersion into this galaxy.  Keeping the lights dim and minimizing distractions can suck you right in and before you know it hours could have gone by.  Gameplay is great if you are one of those who love’s the sandbox feel.   Being put in the middle of the galaxy with nothing but a few credits and the ship you own, it is up to you to go where you want and do it how you want.

The conrol you have over your craft is not limited in any way.  You can cycle through systems and toggle them on or off, making contact with stations to allow yourself permission to dock, deploying cargo scoops, full 3d movement, its all there.  The game is a bit simmy" in that sense
date: however with a bit of time and practice as well as patience you will be piloting your craft like a well trained Commander.  With the ability to switch flight assist on or off you can pull stunts like those seen in Galactica or fly your craft more like those seen in Starwars with flight assist on.  Control is not lacking in any sense of the word.  Shutting all your systems down to minimize your heat signature and floating through space to scoop up cargo right under the fed's nose?  Check!\n\nFrontier has promised many expansions for the game

A pirate basically humiliated me on the mining trip, not only i were barely able to get away, he also used few cargo stealing limpet drones to basically grab most of my resources.

Best game, 10/10.

reviewText:
Sandbox.... what does this mean?
For me it means that im able too affect the world, conquer sectors, build something, destroy something, i want to leave a mark / footprint.
The only footprint that you can leave in Elite Dangerous is limited to be the first discoverer of a system / planet. All big events should be triggered by the players (station building, economic development of new worlds etc...), but they are just
scattered or nonexistent.
All current elements of the game: NPC-Trade, bounty hunting, exploration, mining or PVE are just incomplete.
Anyone who is committed to a particular sector will usually lose the desire after a few hours and get pulled in an almost endless grind.
In short: They should improve the core game but all what they do is to care about their Horizon" expansion.

greetings: Beta backer Lucian Mordren

reviewText:
i recommend this game for hard core space sim fanatics and new players as well.  let me tell you why.  at the time of this writing there is (still) no story mode (like squadron 42).  for those who like pvp there is open play (as of CQC module there is dedicated PVP play which does not impact open/solo insurance).  for those who like co-op there is private game mode.  for those who want to play against ai w/o bothering (with) other players there is solo play.  AND these modes use the SAME save file.  for those who despair of getting out of the starter system w/ ship intact ( a valid concern on some servers) this means that learning to play alone and/or w/ friends does not mean having to start anew when entering open play.  this aleviates _some_ of the game's harsh learning curve.

as to the learning curve i recommend completing _all_ the tutorials before entering play in any mode.  this will put a player above the skill of the default ai and above most players.  it will not help a player who is hopelessly outnumbered and unwilling to disengage for refit/repair.  note that it is a good idea to pay fines as early as possible unless going the outlaw path (fines must now expire).

which leads me to my next point.  it is the player's responsibility to make their own story as they go.  this may seem a daunting task so i will suggest only a few.  trading - find profitable trade routes and maximize local economies.  though this has a low impact on the game galaxy, a good trade route can return enough cash to upgrade ships and internals and allow for more ships on hand for time of need.  scouting - even w/ a starter ship (sidewinder) one can equip a scanner and a fuel scoop to enable unlimited flight.  bulletin boarding - this one is a bit tricky in that it will involve factions.  taking jobs for one or allied factions will boost reputation w/ said faction(s).  taking jobs for opposing factions will, at best, cancel out reputation gain.  this is most notable in the trans-sytem factions of Alliance, Federation and The Empire.  taking missions for these last 3 will eventually unlock rank missions.  rank unlocks certain ships and grants passage to sequestered systems.  outlaw - do what you like, when you like, where you like.  i recommend any independent system w/ good facilities for a base of operations.  these are only a few of the meta games i can think up off hand.  make your own and play your own game.

survival skills:
1. know when to bug out.  if your cargo is worth more than your insurance claim for a new ship or your _entire_ balance is invested in your current ship and its current cargo you would do better to submit to an interdict and fly away from attacker(s) until your FSD comes back online then escape to supercruise.

2. dont shoot the cops.  when doing business in a system it is unwise to encur the wrath of the local constabulary.  this is unavoidable in certain jobs board missions but those are special cases.  if you are patrolling a resource extraction site or bounty gathering at a nav point be aware of the ships near your target.  also mind your turrets are not engaged when selecting targets which might not be wanted or could be system security.  shooting a cop or a ship w/ no bounty will give _you_ a bounty which in turn makes you fair game for anyone w/ a gun.  should this happen i recommend you disengage and fly to nearest platform (not station mind you) and clear your fine (patched - fines must now expire before being paid.  the term of validation is based on the severity of the infraction).

3. anarchy means anarchy.  in an anarchy system even non bounty ships might attack you.  this is key when plotting a trade route.  just be aware of all ships around you in anarchy systems.

4. power management.  big guns need big power.  when outfitting your ship be sure to make note of the total power draw from ship's systems.  nothing worse than bringing up hardpoints and causing a power loss.  thats right, your a sitting duck until you pwer down enough systems to get total @/below 100%.  to enable bigger guns and higher shield regen and turbo regen i recommend the highest power distributor you can afford.  the need for a higher power plant becomes evident in outfitting.  the need for higher FSD depends on desired jump range.

5. dont run out of gas.  be mindful of nearby systems you can use for refuelling.  a fuel sccop can lessen this need but be aware that some stars it is very dangerous to gather fuel from (and yes im looking at you t-tauri stars).  you can very nearly fly and supercruise forever in any given system but you will need sufficient fuel to reach a scoopable star or a system with accessible ports (note ship size vs landing pad size).

with the powerplay update you can ally yourself w/ any of a number of galactic powers to further their goals and by extension your own.  i do not play this aspect but i recognize that it bears a passing resemblance to a story mode so there is that.

TL/DR Summary:
recommended for hard core space sim and new to advanced pvp, co-op play w/ friends highly recommended.  warning - this game is a time sink.  have audiobooks and music playlist ready and waiting.  (note - acquired steam key for game through frontier store's account manager.  actual game time is not reflected by steam.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xY6J5kCK0J8

*added note about fines must expire
*added CQC PVP and some spelling

reviewText:
I don't have that many hours clocked in my profile, but here's my little review

Elite Dangerous
Preview
Elite: Dangerous is a space simulation game where you take a ship and credits to make money legally or illegally.
trade, bounty-hunt, pirate, assassinate your way across the galaxy.

First Contract
+ You'll initially find yourself strapped into the cockpit of your starting Sidewinder, a small ship of limited means.


Positive
+ Ship cockpits are immaculately designed and filled with details both functional and cosmetic.
+ Ships have an ideal maneuverability speed where the rotational speed is best, which is represented on the HUD as a blue bar next to the throttle indicator.
+ FTL Travel : In normal space, you use your thrusters to maneuver, dogfight, and dock with stations, but to move faster within a star system, you use your frame shift drive to accelerate to FTL supercruise speeds, so you can travel in minutes rather than weeks.
+ Exploration is another avenue of gameplay that you can pursue, but it's also one of the weakest. The game has billions of star systems, and at the current rate, it will take centuries before players find them all.

Negative
- Combat is exciting, but you'll spend a lot of your time hauling freight. Ohh ♥♥♥♥...

reviewText:
The BEST space game of our lifetime.

+Stupidly huge galaxy which you get rewarded for exploring.

+Controls feel natural, extremely intuitive on all device types.

+Gorgeous visuals.

+Music is very atmospheric (which is kind of ironic)

+In-game voice is awesome, extremely immersive experience.

+Plenty of ships that all fill their roles very well.

+Trading, Smuggling, Mining are all viable professions to pursue.

+Combat is wild, tense, and a little scary.

+Devs are quite open about their goals, tend to be pretty on the ball.

+My Anaconda don't.

-I can't play all day every day.

-Wings are a max of 4 people, making larger fleets troublesome to coordinate.

Seriously, I used to play EVE, I dropped it for this game. Elite is the game I dreamed of. I wish I had bought it sooner, even with the hefty price, this game has been well worth it.

reviewText: Backed this game at planet naming level (£750), as well as sunk another £200+ into it since then on merchandise, skins, and so on. I named my planet & space station after my late Dad. I was heavily involved in the Design Discussion Forum (DDF) all the way through. Needless to say, I wanted this game to be good. Pay no attention to the hours played on Steam - I have been playing since Alpha 1.0.\n\nUnfortunately, once the initial wow" factor of the huge galaxy wears off
date: you discover there's very little actual game there - and
hoursPlayed: even less opportunity for you to create your *own* game. The systems are very similar
voteText: the stations are even more similar
helpfulPercent: the NPCs serve no purpose whatsoever
votesHelpful: and the ill-advised & badly implemented "multiplayer" doesn't make up for the overriding feeling that the game is largely devoid of purpose. Everything feels "fake".\n\nIt looks pretty in my Oculus Rift (bought for the game during alpha). It's a useful tech demo in that respect. The menu systems are terrible. Having to take your eyes off the action to fiddle with menu options to do some basic task is stupid. I'm not surprised that they're releasing a console version
votesTotal: as the "game that is designed for the PC from the ground up" (as promised during the Kickstarter) clearly wasn't.\n\nThere is no pause button. Even if you only play solo (as I usually did) if you accept a (boring
votesFunny: fetch and carry) mission

you better finish it in that play session because the timers will count down on it even if you're not playing. Then you will lose rep. It would make sense if there was an actual effect on the system / faction if they didn't receive their 6t of Tea in time... but there isn't.

It's incredibly grindy. There's nothing to do except grind for more cash to... buy a bigger ship... just so you can grind faster to... what? That doesn't count as "progression".

The overriding feeling I have is one of profound disappointment & regret. I wish I hadn't spent so much money on it. I wish I hadn't named a space station as a memorial to my Dad as the game will now only exist for as long as Frontier continue to pay for the servers

reviewText:
I was extremely disappointed to learn that the development for the base game left so much undone. When I paid $60 for a game like this I expected a lot more than to fly around a randomly created galaxy performing randomly generated missions. Every aspect of the game has the same feel of unused potential.

To begin with, I enjoyed the simple act of piloting my spaceship in and out of spaceports because it seemed so realistic, and I was excited to see what the game added. Unfortunately, the answer was not much."

I soon learned that the developer's goal was to milk as much money out of its players as possible. I thought that charging additional real-life money to customize your paint job was an ominous sign. I wish I had listened to my gut. Now to add essential gameplay elements to the game
date: you will be required to pay for expansions that cost as much as the base game. The developers even dared to offer a lifetime pass for expansions that they charge over $100 for.\n\nThe game did seem too good to be true. I won't likely be returning to the game now that I know how much of a dead end or cash sink it is. If I do
recommended: I will definitely wait until all of the expansions are out and on sale for 75% off."

reviewText:
Abysmal. Devoid of any meaningful content, goals, or challenge. Not an MMO as described. Online and offline modes share the same character. Grind the best gear in solo and then switch to online to smash noobs. When you yourself face danger, log out to avoid death and loss, like everyone does. Pvp does not exist because yay just log to avoid death. No challenge in the AI ships either. A potatoe can defeat the deadliest of AI in this game. The greatest challange is to find a reason to play.

On the not so bright side. It's kinda cool to explore the galaxy for the first day... Until you see the scenery repeat itself to nausium. Every faction shares the same few space station designs (but sometimes the lights are different colors!). There is no variation in behavior among the factions. I suppose it would be easier to notice if they ever spoke. Missions are uninspired, terribly boring and repetative. If you played Freelancer in 2003, it had a better mission system than this much newer game.


Aside from pretty sounds and graphics, this game dropped the ball, on its balls.

tl;dr: Empty shell/framework of a game, mmo claims essentially lies/false advertising, 12 year old Freelancer is better.

reviewText: Elite Dangerous is a space/flight simulator, with an emphasis on trade, as well as elements of action and mining. It is also an MMO".\n\nIn Elite: Dangerous you start out in a basic ship in the same general starting area as everyone else. From here on
date: you're free to go about and make something of yourself in the universe. At first

column33: completely removing them from the instance. This means all the effort you spent trying to kill them has gone to waste.\n\nFinally
column34: exploration is another option. Elite: Dangerous has around 400 billion procedurally systems. When you eventually get the money

column37: scanning stars

With horizons coming i think that things could get better but at the same time they really need to implement a few more random events that are truly random yet great on the ambience, think flying around then ship systems crash and you spin while having to figure out what went wrong and rebooting your ship to then have a couple of ships appear and realise you fell into a trap OR for traders, a criminal hid in your cargo on the last station and you get interdicted by police, you receive a message from the criminal offering you a deal if you help him out and you have to choose between the cops or the criminal with two different risk/rewards that could make more happen down the line.

reviewText:
Big, but empty.

Nothing to do, but fly around and do boring missions, that have no impact. It's wide and big, but shallow.

I've been an X (from Beyond the Frontier to Albion Prelude) player for a long time and I've never been this bored in that series, even though it's learning curve is much harder. At least there were stories there and you could actually have impact on the universe around you (universe that actually felt ALIVE, unlike in Elite) - for example, a friend of mine genocided every other race in the game and took over the universe.

Elite on the other hand is just grind, grind, grind - the point of the game is grind. There are expansion packs coming, but each will be the price of a whole, brand new game!

There is no single-player. There is no offline mode. For single player you need to be connected to the internet and their servers.

Reminds me of Diablo III and that whole disaster, but at least there's no fear people will crash ED server, because it's far from over-loaded.

People compare it to Euro Truck SImulator 2, but at least in it's MP mod you are constantly around other players and can interact, for good or bad. And ETS2 at least isn't frustrating, unless there's a troll it's actually quite a calming-down experience, serene. They also like to compare it to EVE online, but where are then the player-owned stations? Where are the corporations? Where is the player interaction?

Then there is the launcher.

First off, I should not need to create a new account with a 3rd party other than steam to play a game I bought on Steam and then have to go through a bit too long process to even launch the game. That's a peeve.

Why not expand on the demo included (but is it a demo when you get it only after you've bought the game?), give it a set universe and make it an open game and let it be played as offline singleplayer? Apparently not good enough for Braben, but I'm sure  a LOT of people would be happy with that. And I DO mean OFFLINE play.

Yes, the game looks amazing, even on my system, and the trailers on steam make it look mind-blowing to play.

On that topic, the trailers and teasers themselves are misleading. Station space is no-fire zone, so there won't be any skimming-the-station-surface-while-evading-fire moments. The ships in the game are actually not that maneuverable. And you'll never actually see the outside of your ships (unless you enter the screenshot mode in which you have no control over your ship, but are vulnerable and can be killed) because you fly from the cockpit.

And even that has unpredicted problems. If, like me, you use headtracking (TrackIR or Freetrack) you will see a second copy of the HUD flicker on the screen.

The developers seem satisfied with the end product (even though it's far from finished in players' opinions), so unlikely to fix the biggest problems, especially ones that would need a change in philosophy.

In the months that I've owned this game there have been 2 patches. None of them has added anything new to the game, they were only fixes of bugs producers acknowledge as such.

Bottom line, I don't recommend this game.

.

What I would instead suggest is to rather buy a game of the X-series. My favorite is the X-3 line, particularly Terran Conflict and Albion Prelude. They are not perfect, but in my opinion much better than ED is at the moment.

If you want excellent space combat that can involved hundreds of ships at the same time, X3 are the games for you.

If you want space economy that actually has meaning and on which you can have impact then X3 are games for you Example: factories only produce goods - that are needed by other factories for their production, only if they are supplied and in many cases you can be the only supplier, so you have direct impact on what gets produced - for example, your Argnu beef factory is in the first chain of production for anti-capital-ship cannons - if there is no beef supply, you won't be able to buy those cannons and equip your M2 battleship. With mods you can set up system and universe traders that earn you money without your constant babying them.

If you want a space sim with story, then X3 is for you. ED has none, while in X3 every race has a story that you can be part of and that takes a different approach. Some may want only your combat skills, while others will need you to become a successful industrialist. Rewards vary from better ships, unique equipment to goods or money (credits).

X3 has one of the most epic soundtracks out there - excellent example being compositions in systems like  Kingdom End and Getsu Fune.

If you want your grind to actually have effect, then X3 is for you. You start out with a very basic fighter, but can end up having FLEETS of BATTLESHIPS and CARRIERS, that each can carry up to 60 fighters and are protected by corvettes and cruisers and light and heavy fighter wings, EACH of these ships being playable. Mods (of which there are hundreds) give you even better control of them.

If you want multiplayer where you will feel lonely and won't see another player for days then Elite Dangerous is the game for you. In this respect it's no more multiplayer than X3 and for X3 you DON'T need to be connected to the internet and some servers to play.

If you don't want to have any impact whatsover on the universe around you then ED is for you.

If after a few days of playing you want to be bored, then get ED.

In the end it's your decision and if you buy it and are happy even after weeks of playing, then I'm happy for you. But if you end up bored soon, then don't say I didn't warn ya. ;-)

reviewText:
Disclaimer

The recommendation comes with a heavy grain of salt.

I have played this game for 425 hours on steam and around 300 before it was on steam, and I think I have done enough of every aspect of the game to give a fair review of the game.

The Beginning
I am sorry to say that I can no longer testify to the opening hours of the game as accurately as I would like because I first played it around 1.5 years ago and many things have changed since then, but some things I believe to be the same are immense, but IMO rewarding learning curve, adjustment to the vastness of the galaxy, and beginning to make money effectively.  The amount of learning will depend on your mileage with space/flight sims.  The galaxy is breathtaking, but the novelty wore off for me around 50 hours in (which is still longer than some games offer).  The money is a whole other issue which takes me to the mid game (Yes I consider the beginning to be the first 50 hours, even after that I still learned new things that I didn't know).

The Middle
The main part of the mid game is doing various types of careers or missions to earn money.  The game is a grind, a huge grind at that.  I can hardly think of more than 20 of my 725 hours that I spent playing the game in which I was not grinding.  This is where the grain of salt comes in.  I spent around 600 hours in the mid game in which I went from the cobra (small versatile classic ship) to the Federal Corvette (huge war machine with massive guns but turns like a truck).  I went through many ships and every profession (minus exploration, I'm waiting on VR for that one) and grinding my way to riches, and federal rank (in game faction).  The reason I liked this game so much is for 2 main reasons

1.) I love space and the idea of a game like this keeps on fascinating me

2.) I, for some reason liked the grind. I hated it and stop playing for a while at about the 200 hour mark, but then I came back and loved it.  I have no clue why, maybe it was something like stockholm syndrome but I was pulled in and I loved just going on endless 'farming' sessions for 8 hours just blowing up pirates and never got bored.

My final notes on the mid game are the following.  I am sorry, but I don't think a review can tell you whether you will enjoy this game or not, even if you hate grinding like I did this game can change your mind.  You have to try it, and you also IMO have to love space and be able to set a goal for yourself (Corvette for me) otherwise I don't think there will be enough motivation because that is the kicker with this game, everything is self motivation.  The game doesn't give you an end goal and a lot of people don't like that because there is not a ton of gameplay and there is not much sense of progress besides a number on the screen, and if you don't like that, which most people probably don't, then don't get the game it will just frustrate you.

Elite leaves a lot of blank spaces for the player to fill in and does not give them a lot to fill it in with which leads to an understandable outcome of a lot of people not liking the game.  However, I liked it for some reason and I just think this game is too different from most other games to quantify it as good or bad.  Its weird and different and grindy and has cool space stuff.  If you don't have a strong interest in games like that don't get it.  If you aren't sure, give it a try.  At the very least it will intise you for maybe 20 hours and give you an interesting space experience.

The End
While I liked the mid game, lots of people don't for understandable reasons.  The weird thing about Elite is that there is no true end game, but I would say a lot of players find a point where they don't feel the need to have monetary progression anymore, which by my video game logic I guess would mean you are at the end game.  I had this when I got my nice big ship and went out blowing up pirates for hours on end, but this is where my only gripe with the game comes in.  It was the same as before, now I just had nothing to work towards, so I got bored after another 75 hours of doing various things with my new ship and stopped playing.  I was left kind of unsatisfied, but I thought to myself, I got 400 hours of really fun time from this game and while the first 200 hours and the last 75 hours were kind of rough, I got a lot of enjoyment out of this game and thought the $60 was well worth it.

tl;dr

Elite is a weird game with tons of grinding and waiting and space stuff (lazors and ships).  I liked the grind so I liked the game, but ultimately it depends on whether you have to motivation (or desire to waste time as some may call it) to spend tons of hours working towards an arbitrary goal you set for yourself and then feeling happiness from seeing all your progress.  Or maybe you just like flying through space forever on your computer, whatever floats your boat.

Side Note

I have not been able to try with VR yet but I heard it is quite amazing and could bring new life into the game for me and many other people.  I also recommend a second monitor / phone / tablet so you can watch some videos or movies while playing to ease parts of the grind.

reviewText:
Now, I hear a lot of arguments over this and Star Citizen.
So let me make this clear.
Elite is good RIGHT NOW. They're using their time well and the development is going great.
Star Citizen is NOT good right now, but it WILL be.
If they finish it. Which I doubt. They're taking way too long despite their absurd amounts of money.
If you want something that won't cost you an arm or a leg to play right now, get Elite. Planetary landings and more are on the way soon, and although that's an expansion, it's not DLC. It's a proper expansion. I haven't seen one of those in years.

So if you wanna fork out like, idk, 60 quid (?) total for Elite and the Horizons expansion right now? Do it. PLUS IT'S ON SALE CURRENTLY SO THAT'S LIKE 67% OFF WOAH

If you wanna spend like several hundred pounds right now to get into Star Citizen and get a ship or two? You can do that too, but you'll have to hear the sound of your wallet crying as your PC struggles to handle the graphics and explodes.

Both are good.
One's just better now.
Save your life and your wallet, get this game.

reviewText:
It's been twenty years or there abouts since I played Elite First Encounters, first picking up after friends raved about how great Elite 2: Frontier was. For those that remember, First Encounters was bug ridden at launch and I suspect derailed the development of the Elite francise til now. I will make most comparrisions between Dangerious and First Encounters or egosofts X reunion/rebirth game as this is the most recent and perhaps most familiar space sim (not counting Eve Online)

First of all to anyone familiar with the old Elite games, Elite Dangerous will instantly feel like an nice fitting old glove you have not put on in a long time and it'll appear so comfortable wearing it again. The radar and weapon systems are just like I remember it from First Encounters twenty years ago, but with up to day graphics. Grapically it looks amazing for a space sim, reminds me a lot of the X series of games when I first played those. An easy way to summaries this is X series (egosoft) graphics with Elite game mechanics. Music is very nice from what I heard. Space combat is just like I remember it from the old games. In fact much of the game mechanics, and galaxy map/system is pretty much the same as the old elite games but better looking. Only one major change is docking is manually done, it's not autopiloted as found in First Encounters

For those who never played any of the Elite series before, you are loaned a starter ship from the begining and given a handful of credits to start your adventure. There is no real definite goal in this game other than what you set yourself. YOu can become a trader, explorer, pirate, bounty hunter, mercenary or a plain old space taxi driver. There are three main activities in the game in which you are ranked, combat, exploration and trading. You can eventually achieve elite ranking in each and every one of these three but it's not something that is going to be done overnight. Much of the game you will spend either in the space station working out the best trades to make or how to avoid loses and traveling in space. The game is based within our own milky way galaxy as a reference and it is massive in terms of scale. Significantly bigger than the universe in egosoft's own series

The game has a number of ships many of which will be familiar to fans of the Elite series and all are costumisable in their loadouts to suit your needs.

There are major gripes I have with what I have seen thus far.

1. The tutorials are horrible and poor, they virtually DO NOT explain any thing clearly and literally require a bit of inititive on your part to find out what does what and a fair bit of time staring at the keymap settings. I gone through three of the tutorials and it feels like being asked to take a driving test blind folded! Here you're probably better off looking for a youtube video by someone to explain how things work! Instead go to their website and watch their tutorials on their website, link here..
http://www.elitedangerous.com/guide/training

2. The game doesn't seem to be desinged with a mouse user in mind, mouse sensitivity is very high, in default you can easily spin into a loop if you just nudge your mouse left or right, you'll often have to change the settings or switch to a joystick or controller. The controls are highly costumisable so its not that huge an issue as much as it is an irritation.

3. The game can not be played in an Offline mode, this is part due to the economy being influenced by what other players of the game do. The economiy and price of goods is impacted by other players, if everyone trades far too much in one type of good it will change the trade conditions in that area. As such trading in Dangerious is a much harder and complicated affair than what it was found in First Encounters. All in all that is not really a problem when you consider the reason.. What may become an issue is that the servers the game use, you may have some problems connecting to them. Not sure of the cause of this

4. Docking, what's seemingly not mentioned anywhere is that you need to be facing a particular direction when you dock else you won't be able to dock. I lost count of the number of times i had my ship backwards and failing to dock, leaving me wondering for a few seconds what was wrong as I got everything else right

Based on first impressions, and of what I know of the old Elite games...

Highly recommended if you are any of the following
1. A fan of the old Elite games, Frontier, First encounter etc.
2. Like the combat and trade element of Egosoft's X series, but not keen on empire building in terms of owning space stations
3. Someone who loves open world games where you set your own goals... The game galaxy is absoluely massive!

I do not recommend the game to the following ..
1. Instant gradification players, the game is slow to get into in that much of the game will revolve around very long term goals.
2. Players who like zero inertia space sim games, there is no instant turning on a dime in this game, you will easily travel a few AUs or Light seconds before you make a turn if your speed is very high.
3. Anyone expecting to have the empire buidling element of the egosoft X series like owning stations and a whole host of fleet owned ships.

reviewText:
**This review was written by my friend, DeeJay http://steamcommunity.com/id/xDeeJayGamer - This review also applies to my current experience with the game as well.**

Anytime before 06/05/15, I would've recommended this game. It had promise and I found it quite enjoyable... until powerplay. Powerplay ruined Elite: Dangerous and plagued it with bugs galore, even after fixing most of the bugs it felt stale with a cliché government system now added. As of 05/08/15 all my hope for this game has offically ran out, creating an expansion with a £39.99[www.frontierstore.net] ($85.77AUD) paywall, I bought for the game for $60AUD and I'm not paying another $85AUD to unlock features that were promised to be in this game.

I give this game 3/10 for the direction that its going in.

Don't buy this game, you're better of waiting for Elite: Dangerous Horizons if you don't want to waste your money.

reviewText:
This is a first-impressions review so I will try to update as I get further in the game.

First off- wow. The scale and depth of the game continues to blow my mind. I had to reread the description to make sure. The interface is beautiful and will integrate seamlessly into any VR technology. The graphics are fine, basically what I would expect out of a 2015 release. The sounds lend the the immersion of the game and the music is atmospheric as well.

Combat in the game takes the form of outerspace dog-fights a la Battlefront 2, but again contemporary features from the past decade add finesse and flexibility to the system. You can be a pirate or a bounty hunter and I assume (though I have yet to participate in) there is some faction related content as you progress. You take the money that you earn to upgrade your ship or trade for more profit.

For me, all of this really takes a back-seat to the exploration element of the game. It's the entirety of the milky-way. You get rewarded for exploring as you can sell data that you've accumulated to space stations in order to fund your adventures. Like startrek for profit. It's probably not the most efficient way to make money in the game but it's super fun.

I don't know if they have plans to expand an avatar system. AFAIK the most personal you get with your pilot is seeing their hands as they do their piloting. Customization there would be cool. It would also be pretty neet to land on and explore the planets you discover, but I guess that would present a new set of challenges.

Still as it sits, Elite: Dangerous is both polished and fun. If you're going to spend $60 on a game this month, it's definitely worth your consideration.

Back when I was  a kid in the 80's, I played Elite on the Commodore 64. I played for hours upon hours, it was a fun game that captured my scifi loving youth.
When I saw that we were getting a modern version I was ecstatic. I waited a few months after release and bought it a week ago. After leaving town on a family emergency, I came home and fired up the game. I have to say it looks fantastic, plays properly, everything works. However It's overly complicated, and playing this game can be a BORE. There is just nothing going on to keep me playing. I had very high hopes, and from what i can tell it's mostly faithfull to the original I loved so much as a child. Either my tastes have changed or it's just plain boring. voteText: 27 of 41 people (66%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Let me make something clear:It was inevitable that some people would hate this game. It's an intellectual, immersive space game. The story evolves slowly and it's a game filled with thought. People are so used to games with constant non-stop action and senseless violence these days, a game like this is bound to have it's haters. That said, the combat is still brilliant.

The fact is the technology alone is incredible. They have a real-scale replica of the ENTIRE Milky Way Galaxy, all 400 BILLION star systems. I can't even begin to imagine how their systems are capable of simulating that real time, procedurally or otherwise.
They are also hosting a full-scale MMO without charging a monthly subscription. NICE.

Because of the plethora of negative reviews I very nearly didn't buy this game. Since I did, I showed my parents and they got so excited they went out and bought flightsticks and extra copies just so we could all play together. My Dad ended up buying a Saitek X52, a seperate-throttle super high-quality flight controller that was actually modelled into the game's cockpits. That's right, it's the exact same one as what's in the game.

We've bought numerous copies to send to friends so we can all play together, and many of my friends went out to buy their own flightsticks as well.
If you're bored of hauling cargo, get a gun and go shoot someone.
The consequences of this are, you get chased by cops, and you get to shoot them too!
If you like combat, the game has combat.
If you like exploration, it has that too.
If you like ongoing development on an MMO style game but without a monthly subscription IT ABSOLUTELY HAS THAT.

Long story short, the technology alone will make your jaw drop, the seamlessness is perfect and it plays just like a AAA title should. It's well designed, fun to play, very immersive and a MUST HAVE for any Sci-Fi enthusist. This game and Star Citizen almost single-handedly revived the Sci-Fi game market.

reviewText:
This game isn't for everyone.  It rewards patience and setting your own goals.   It can be slow sometimes as you explore or trade, but can be fast and furious when you're involved in the Community Goals, especially combat as you tackle ships much bigger than yourself.

The game is beautiful and I love it as it is, but it's still in development and will continue to be so I hope for years to come.

Someone in the forums asked what's the difference between Elite: Dangerous and Star Citizen.  Elite: Dangerous is out there now.  A much much lower budget, but a much more thoughtful game.

I particularly love exploring.  Right now it's what I call an Asimovian Galaxy.  There's no-one here but us and I love just exploring and discovering the extra-solar planets and star systems, for the sheer SCIENCE of it.  I understand why that wouldn't appeal to everyone though.

This isn't a game for just logging in and fighting.  It requires thought and allows you really to fulfill your fantasies of exploring space.  Real space.  Not sci-fi space.

reviewText:
I'm going to start off by saying that I woudn't recommend buying Elite: Dangerous at the moment. This is due to the fact that soon, Elite Dangerous Horizons will be released, an expansion of Elite Dangerous which will include the base game in the package, aswell as the expansion, for the same price of £40 (or your regional equivalent). Wait for the release of Elite Dangerous Horizons and buy that instead.

With that out the way, would I have recommended Elite: Dangerous if this wasn't the situation?

yes.

it's an excellent space exploration simulation, with great controls and combat system, excellent sound design (some of the best in the genre), and beautiful visuals, when piloting your ship you do genuinely feel as if you're there in the cockpit. The game is continually being updated with new content for free (with the exception of Horizons).

Please don't waste your money on this, you're much better off pre-ordering or buying Elite Dangerous Horizons when it's released around December time 2015 (no official release date yet), I implore you!

I'll post a link below to a recent EGX conference where Frontier discuss the new features introduced in Horizons:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3Em7TLwFifE

(I don't own this video or anything in it, it was posted to YouTube by EGX on September 25th)

reviewText:
In some ways, it's like every space shooter going back to X-Wing, but the graphics are modern,  the AI is competent (only killed two sitting ducks), and I'll be damned that I haven't been this hooked on a game in a while. Three ways to make a living and it's hard to do any one without doing the others to some extent, Exploration, Trade with a sub class of miner, and Combat subbed by bounty hunting, piracy, or a military career. The game is awesome in that you make it what you want. You can configure a fighter's hull for mining or a traders hull for combat, while those may be poor choices, it's all up to you. I use a Flightstick Pro and combat is pretty easy for me except for the deadliest targets as long as it's 1v1. Those odds can change when a mark has help show up and that dude is a beast.

True story... I come out of FTL travel and there's these cannisters of GOLD just floating there in space. Out in the middle of nowhere this gold is just floating around for the taking. Obviously I deserve this gold and I fly and scoop one up and I don't know if it was a humans trap, but I'm thinking it was not... it all happened so fast... my ship exploded literally within 3 seconds of putting the first can of gold into my cargo bay. Something uncloaked and lit me up like a Christmas tree.  There were no ships on scan before I touched that crap LOL.

Great game, get it now! Hard to figure out at first then it all seems 2nd nature. Still learning...

reviewText:
Played this game since full release last year, bought it on Steam again to support the developers.

Elite Dangerous is everything I could ever want in a spaceship game.
It's the perfect space simulator that's just as much a visual and auditory feast, as it is technically in regards to details.
Not super complicated to be a turn off for more casual gamers, but just enough details to make simulator aficionados squeal with glee.

If you've played any of the previous Elite Dangerous games since the 1980s and onwards, then you will find plenty to love here.
Heck, if you liked Freelancer or any of the X games, this game will blow those games out of the water.
There's a lot of love but in this game.
It's polished, feels great, and conquers so much more than other space simulators before it.

Great with keyboard and mouse or gamepad.
PERFECT with a flight stick and HOTAS.

Even better, try it with an oculus rift, and you'll never want to exit the game again...
Truly amazing.

As it stands right now, the content in the game makes for a vast sandbox full of bounty hunting, trading, exploration, and mining. Plenty of action if that's what you desire, or plenty of Euro Truck Simulator" in Space if that's what you want...

The developers keep releasing updates on a consistent basis too.
Fixing bugs
date:
tweaking stuff....and even adding awesome new features.

This is a solid spaceship simulator that will interest and hold casual and hardcore gamers for lots of different reasons.

Check out the developer's youtube channel and start watching some stuff

reviewText:
I thoroughly enjoyed every moment I played in this game, though it becomes very repetitive once you've exhausted all sorts of play styles, be it trading, bounty hunting, exploring, even PvP. Hopefully that will change in the future, and I'm sure it will, but be that as it may, I paid 60 dollars for this game and with the upcoming expansion costly 40 euros, I really didn't like that, though they may have their reasons.

If you do enjoy space, crashing into the letter box of a station, waiting forever for someone to leave an outpost so you can dock, space battles that have you on the edge, and beautifully, well done open space environments, go for it, I highly recommend this game to you, I got my 60 dollars worth, and its even cheaper now.

The only reason I wouldn't recommend it is because the extra content will end up costing more if you're not patient. I got tired of doing several trade runs, and tired of going into conflict zones and killing the same NPCs, and I'm sure landing on planets will have its limitations as well.

Hope my opinion has helped some of you to make a decision, this game is fantastic regardless.

reviewText:
If you like the idea of Microsoft Flight Combat Simulator [Star Wars Edition] then buy it.

+Fun dogfighting, satisfying weapons
+Many professions/roles (no selection, just play your way)
+Ship customization
+Form wings with friends, split money earned
+Intercept and hold-up ships in FTL travel
+Evade interception from pirates and bounty hunters
+Bounty system independant of different factions
+Scan for desirable cargo, kill warrants, FTL warp trajectories
+Fly close to suns to scoop fuel from them
+Make money from exploring undiscovered systems and selling map data

+/- Zero handholding, tutorial only teaches the very basics of ship control
+/- Slight learning curve
+/- Billions of systems, in a mockup of the Milky Way galaxy
+/- Difficult docking on non-stationary platforms

-It is slightly empty, because it is of course in OUTER SPACE and there are so many systems. Some systems are much more populated than others.
-Don't bite off more than you can chew, you need to pay for ship repairs/replacement
-No clan system in sight
-Devs discourage territorial and group behaviour, while we watch NPC's do what we can't

Hopefully they change the last two cons.

As it is, buy this if it looks like something you would really be interested in already, otherwise wait for more developments.

reviewText:
I was quite excited to play a space sim game, which I thought was along the lines of Freelancer. I was dead wrong. This is more of a $50 space flight simulator. The game has stunning graphics quality, but graphics can only do so much justice.

For a new person to the series, the game is extremely confusing. The controls are weird and flight is hard to control unless you have a joystick. The game is overall unfriendly to new players. There are no objectives, no real guidance on how to play. The very first mission I picked up had no indication on where I could aquire the parts to complete the mission. There are tutorials that give you basic controls, but then tell you to go to youtube to actualy show you how to play.

It took me over 2 hours just to finish the tutorials and by that terms, I'm out of my refund range. Which means that after I discovered that this is just a flight simulator, I'm out of $50.

Overall, unless you want to fly through space and run into space stations, or out of fuel in the middle of nowhere, I wouldn't recommend this game. It feels unfinished, almost like you have to make your own game, which is expected for a sandbox style game, but this game is too bareboned.

reviewText:
This review may be a little different..... I've only written a couple Steam reviews but this one I needed to write.

Elite Dangerous is the most important game in the market right now. I say that as a technologist who has spent the last 20 years in software and as a futurist, I do not state that lightly. I own a Vive, Rift, HoloLens dev kit, and a few other juicy upcoming devices. My colleagues and I regularly show off the capabilites of VR using Elite Dangerous.

While there some innovative VR titles out there, none transport you to the degree Elite Dangerous. That mental transportation is the most important aspect of VR.

I won't go into the bugs, features, etc, etc, etc of Elite Dangerous, just suffice to say it is an important game that will shape our next 20 years.

reviewText:
This won't be everyone's cup of tea. It has a certain pace to it, it requires some thought, a little imagination and the playing arc is a long one. Instant gratification is not on the agenda, neither is having your hand held through cut scenes and story lines.

It is: beautiful, hard, engrossing, detailed and full of possibilities. The dogfights are brilliant, heart-stopping stuff when your ship (and all you own) is on the edge of being blown up. The flight mechanics are superb, handling the ships can be hard work but the result is a real in-game skill, and not some computer assisted variant thereof. To really get the most out of it you probably need a flight stick - but I'm playing on keyboard and mouse and after getting used to it and setting up the preferences, it works really well.

Does it have limitations? Yes, as clearly there is the scope for masses more content to be added and it will be via paid for expansion packs and the regular free updates.

As someone said further down, Know what it is you are buying
date: before you buy". Some people reviewing this clearly got the wrong end of the stick and got something they didn't like. To some I'd suggest playing it for longer than a couple of hours. Your patience might well be rewarded......"

reviewText:
Spent a long time deciding whether to get this game.


I looked at the reviews which all said really good things. I watched some gameplay, and noticed a few people complaining about the game charging for new content when it was released as if early access. I understood why they were annoyed, but I though hey it's a kickstarter game company, they must need the money to fund development and I can get behind it.


My first 2 minutes of the game were spent signing up via the launcher/website, and being bombarded with in game purchases I could make. Seeing that some of the 'only 8 pounds' offerings were tedious things like changing my ship to green or yellow made me very wary. But I plowed on and started the game up. I picked my commander name and spent a further few minutes being told that my usual go to names were already taken, which was a first but not surprising as they're space themed. I settled on a meh variation of my usual and started.


Realising there is no default third person option was very very jarring for me. I play almost all of my games in that view, and to be honest it's kinda expected nowadays. I spent some time getting a feel for the controls, but they were really messed up as I later found out my mouse had loaded off centre. I reloaded the game but again my mouse was off centre, meaning I struggled to actually click the menu controls etc. At this point I gave up.



I really don't like badly polished games, games that are 'EA like' in their money farming, or games that lack depth. I'm sure this game has loads of depth, but with the other two in mind I just can't bring myself to have paid full price for a clearly buggy unfinished game that's already trying to squeeze every penny out of the players. I've asked for a refund and hopefully will get it to spend on some of the options that at least are still developing content for players without charging them.

reviewText:
This is a review based on 1.3 PowerPlay.

First of all, I love space and futuristic game.  Elite: Dangerous is quite a nice space game with lots of potential.  What I mean is that, currently this game is nice, beautiful and good to play at the beginning, but there are some mechanisms not completed yet or need some improvement.

+Gorgeous graphic and beautiful universe.
+Nice navigation design.  Normal flight, supercruise and hyperspace.
+Immersive UI design with easy hotkeys.  You can easily switching to left or right panel with single click, or just stare to open the panels if you have VR such as Oculus Rift.
+Nice Universal Cartographics.  Very easy to navigate and very informative.
+Random signatures give more unsure possibilities to your flight.
+Decent background music and AI voice.
+Persistance Universe is very cool.  Game time sync with real time, A.C.2014 as A.C.3300.  Makes you feel like living in that universe.
+P2P + Server-Client connection mechanism creates a no lag MMO experience.
+Really nice optimization.  Currently the game only need 5.5GB harddisk space.  And about 800MB RAM while running.

-Few ships design.  Currently only 20 flyable ships and some ships have quite similar appearence.  i.g.  Sidewinder, Cobra MKIII and ASP Exploerer.
-Few space station / starport design.  Currently only 1 type for small station, and 3 types for large station with all the same interior design.
-PowerPlay makes no sense in some place.  i.g. Zachary Hudson controls tons of Federation systems with Independent capital?
-Lots of missions but most of them are low profit.  If you want to make money, illegal and smuggling is the only way to make money fast.
-No or few coop/team mission.  Team play is very weak, mostly single player missions in the universe now.  So does PvP.
-Poor training tutorials.  They help you to understand how to fly the ship, but not telling you how to get started, even no UI instruction.
-There's no mechanism for player to own multiple ships.  You can only fly one ship at a time, and all your other ships can only park at the shipyard and do nothing. (X series can remotely control your ships to trade or fly to station.)

It's really fun at the beginning.  But you'll gradually find that the ships and the stations are all the same, and the multiplayer is not completed.  ♥♥♥♥♥♥meplay with Persistance Universe, Elite: Dangerous could do more than this.  Lots of potential for Elite: Dangerous and it needs some little tweaks.

Generally speaking, Elite: Dangerous is a nice game if you like space and futuristic game.  I believe it'll be even more completed with the upcoming patch in the furture.


這是對 1.3 PowerPlay 版本的簡評。

首先，我喜歡宇宙和未來設定的遊戲。Elite: Dangerous 是一款富有潛力的太空遊戲，我的意思是目前遊戲整體玩起來還算不錯，非常漂亮又有趣，但有些地方感覺尚未完成或是仍待改進。

+精美的畫質和壯麗的宇宙。
+流暢的導航設計，普通飛行、超光速飛行和超空間跳躍。
+融入感強烈的介面設計以及方便的快速鍵，你可以按一個按鈕就輕鬆切換左右面板，或是如果你有VR顯示器，例如Oculus Rift，也可以盯著適當的位置自動開啟面板。
+好用的宇宙星圖，很好操作而且資訊充足。
+隨機的太空訊號讓遊戲增加更多不確定要素。
+遊戲背景音樂和AI語音十分到位。
+永恆宇宙非常讚，遊戲時間與現實世界時間同步，西元2014年開始同步遊戲西元3300年，讓你感覺就像住在那個世界一樣。
+P2P + Server-Client 的連線設計提供一個不會lag的MMO多人連線體驗。
+非常棒的優化，目前遊戲只佔5.5GB的硬碟空間，執行的時候也只消耗大約800MB的RAM記憶體空間。

-星艦設計貧乏，目前整個遊戲只有20艘可飛行的船艦，而且很多船艦外觀看起來十分雷同，例如Sidewinder、Cobra MKIII、ASP Explorer。
-太空站設計貧乏，目前只有一種小型太空站和三種大型太空站，而且所有太空站內部設計都長一樣。
-PowerPlay有些設計不合邏輯，例如Zachary Hudson的母星系是獨立星盟(Independent)，但他統治的領土幾乎都是聯邦(Federation)的星系？
-遊戲中有很多種任務，但是大部分利潤都太低，如果真的想賺錢，非法任務和走私是唯一的快速管道。
-沒有或是很少的合作/團隊任務，目前遊戲團隊合作機制非常差，幾乎都是單人任務居多，而PvP相關機制一樣貧乏。
-模糊的教學，教學只告訴你該怎麼飛太空船，卻忘了教你新手該怎麼起始遊戲，甚至連介面都沒介紹。
-目前的設計讓玩家沒必要擁有多艘太空船，你同時只能開一艘太空船，其他的船只能停在太空站內什麼也不能做。(X系列中玩家可以遠端操控其他自有的太空船進行貿易或停靠太空站。)

一開始的時候的確很有趣，但隨著遊玩你會漸漸發現船艦和太空站怎麼看起來都好像，而且多人遊戲的部分感覺也不夠完整，MMO多人連線加上永恆宇宙的設計，應該可以做出更多的變化，Elite: Dangerous還有很多潛力並需要一些調整。

整體來說，如果你喜歡宇宙和未來的設定，Elite: Dangerous是一款不錯的遊戲，我相信在未來的更新中會慢慢的讓遊戲更完整。

reviewText:
Elite: Dangerous the title says it from the get go and all the trailers make you feel it stepping into the vast empty space between worlds ready to take on anything that comes your way. There are games out there that fail to deliver on what they promise but this isn't one of them. I've spent the entire 50 hours of this game playing it with my best friend cruising around through space and there have been heart attacks and mockery and laughing beyond count, also shared by utter moments of terror.

This game doesn't hold your hand and in all honesty it benefits from the fact that it doesn't, you are exploring the vast space something that is suppose to be new and foreign and exciting and sort of blundering your way through everything makes it just that much more enjoyable if a little frustrating at times. The learning curve is extremely steep but the challenge is what's really enjoyable. The controls at first are extremely overwhelming but as you spend more time familiarising yourself with them you will learn tricks that at first you thought weren't possible, some of the maneurvers you can manage to pull off fully utilizing all the directional thrusters can make for very exciting dog fights. It'll feel really counter intuitive at first especially using a mouse and keyboard, once you get use to it though you'll find the default setup and controls are really effective. That being said I'd still recommend playing the game with a joystick if you have one nothing beats the feeling of maneuvering with a joystick.

The game is a challenge it's not an easy or quick advancing game, you will need to put hours of work into it to get where you want to be, 50 hours in and I've manage to put together a nice little fighter in the Cobra MK III which is one of the lower ranged ships and it's utterly satisfying having achieve just that small task. The selection of ships at the moment is adequet though the jumps and options between them could be a lot larger, there are plans and concepts of new ships that are in the works and you can have a look at them as well so the game is being worked on to expand the variety which is reassuring that you will get more choices and chances to have different experiences down the track. You will also spend a lot of time outfitting and finding the right kind of weapon combinations and different alterations you can make to your ships load out so that it feels just right.

A lot of the reviews indicate the game as a space trucking sim and it can be if thats what you want it to be, it does make more money the further you progress through the game but you don't have to do it if you don't want to. You can spend hours aimlessly jumping from system to system scanning for planets and finding  new exciting things if you want to, or you can go to a hot spot and fight off pirates defending miners to earn bounties, if you are up for a bit more of a challenge you can go hunting special character bounties or drop into fleet battles and try to tip the scales in a battle, you might be the person that just likes to kick back relax and just shoot rocks to make some money mining or you can spend hours on hours jumping between systems hauling cargo from one port to port just chilling with music enjoying the beauty and vastness of space. The point is that the universe is huge and you can do whatever you like out there and this game gives you the different options to.

The graphics in this game I can only run at medium settings because my system is a little lacking but even at that setting everything is utterly gorgeous. It's grandeous in every aspect and can be quiet terrifying. The feeling of hauling a load of cargo worth almost as much as your ship is to somewhere you haven't been before to try make a big score on credits only to drop out into the system ontop of a white dwarf and have it pull you into it's gravity well. Fighting against the pull of the sun that's trying to suck you in and vaporize all your hard work on your ship and your investment in the cargo. Something simple as just jumping between systems became something unexpect and dangerous and that's what this game can be summed up by. Space is vast and you never know what is going to happen to try ruin your day and on ocasions it will. My advice is get the game with a friend or 2 and play it together from the get go you will have a lot of fun and laugh at each others mistakes and in the end learn and enjoy the game more.

The best moment my friend and I have had is fighting in amongst an asteroid field and I accidentlly hit my boost key and he's just watched as my ship has gone full throttle straight into an asteroid as i've tried desperately to pull up, bounced off it and for a moment he thought i'd lived before 2-3 seconds later I exploded in a glorious fashion. If I had to score the game it'd get a 8.7/10. It's a lot of fun needs a little more options in regards to stepping stones in ships and weapon variations but it is a lot of fun.

reviewText:
Buyers beware!

After Powerplay update:
It's a step in the right direction. There's allegiances now, with more options to make creds. But the question remains: 'To what end?'

This game is STILL lacking content. I have about ~30 hours in this game, 20 of which was flying back and forth doing trading runs, till I realized shooting down some random baddies at a Nav beacon is a thousand times more lucrative. Now I have a badass ship... with nothing to do. I don't need the credits anymore.

TL;DR: Consider this game 'Early Access' with Powerplay finally adding 6-7% of the content you'd expect with the pricetag. Only 93% to go! Come back in a year, or wait for a sale.
