reviewText:
So, for simple economic reasons, avoid this version of the game. All the following prices will be quoted in NZD.

If you buy Elite: Dangerous at full price you'll pay $51.99. Or you can buy Elite: Horizons for $84.99. Elite: Horizons is the 'enhanced' version of the game with all the original content, not a simple case of DLC.

As a current owner of Elite: Dangerous I can purchase Elite: Horizons at a 25% discount, paying $63.74.

The difference between $51.99 and $84.99 is - for a newcomer who doesn't own Elite: Dangerous already - just $33. So, as a newcomer, you can essentially pay just $33 for the additional content, whereas someone who has owned and supported the game with a launch purchase (and a handful of cosmetic upgrades from their store) has the privilege of paying twice what a newcomer does for the additional content.

In total, as a present owner of Elite: Dangerous, if I wanted to upgrade to Elite: Horizons it would mean I've paid a total of $115.73. Or I could have waited a year and bought the 'complete experience' for $84.99. Does anyone see why this might be incredibly insulting?

Don't give them the satisfaction.

Edit: Oh, look at that. They changed the pricing model for Horizons after being catastrophically rounded on by the community. My numbers are now wholly inaccurate, but I'll leave them here as a reminder of how Horizons actually launched.

reviewText:
The base game (Elite: Dangerous), is very beautiful. Flying by a ringed planet? Drop out of supercruise and fly around the icy ring, dodging huge chunks of ice and rock. Very nice, very detailed environment. Want to land on that planet? That'll cost you more than you paid for the base game.

The base game is fairly basic on features. I certainly wouldn't pay full price for it. If you're trading, it's difficult to use the market features to find good prices (which essentially requires the use of the clunky map and a lot of clicking. Some kind of market data screen like EVE would be fantastic). If you're doing missions, it's very difficult to know the prerequisites for a mission or how to complete certain types of missions. Going out and finding bad guys to kill is probably the most fun thing you can do, and you'll end up grinding that for a while to get enough money to upgrade.

Beyond that, I'm pretty disappointed with the way Frontier Developments is expanding on the game. I was thinking the game would continue to develop and expand when I purchased it. Well, it is, except it requires the purchase of DLC that costs more than the original game. These expansions should be included in the original game.

reviewText:
I was very sceptical about purchasing this game as I have seen both negative and positive opinions about it everywhere I looked... In the end, I decided the only way I would be able to have any kind of judgement on the game would be buying the damn thing and playing it myself. One thing I can tell you right here and now is that I DO NOT regret this purchase.

Elite: Dangerous is a true joy to play, being my first ever space simulation game I expected a lot from it and I was not disappointed. I wanted intergalactic travel and dogfights in asteroid fields, I wanted to feel like I was in a f*cking Star Trek movie and you know what? I got just what I f*cking wanted.

Don't get me wrong, this game is an absolute b*tch to learn to play. The control scheme for a mouse and keyboard is probably the hardest part about the learning curve, there are so many controls that need adjusting and key bindings to change to suit your play style but once it's all done and dusted and you know the controls off the back of your hand you can finally enjoy yourself.

One thing to note - Elite: Dangerous is not a game where you will see hundreds of people everywhere you go. Being in a universe with 400 MILLION GALAXIES there will be times where you see nobody, and there will be times where you see a sh*t ton of people all at once. The game can get rather quiet and lonely at times, which is why I HIGHLY recommend playing with friends when/if you can. Playing solo isn't terrible by any means, but you need to really be dedicated to getting something done if you want to have fun with it for a prolonged period of time.

Graphically, this game is gorgeous. The first time I jumped into hyperspace I was like holy f*cking crap" because that is just how awesome it is. Upon exiting hyperspace however
date: I sat back in my chair and giggled to myself because of how incredible it looked. The attention to detail
hoursPlayed:
they just blow you away.

OVERVIEW
------------

Elite: Dangerous is an ambitious and unhealthily addictive space simulation game which truly embraces the community that have helped build the game from the ground up. Sure

reviewText:
I'm probably an older gamer and I have very much enjoyed previous incarnations of Elite - In particular I spent many hundreds of hours on Frontier over several years, whenever I was bored it was a game I could always go back to and find something new to do or set some new challenge for myself.  I was really excited about Elite: Dangerous and it is a game I have really tried to love.  Technically it is very impressive with a huge game universe and nice graphics and decent combat.  But at this stage I have to say that out of the last decade or so this is the gaming purchase that I most regret.

In practice this has taken the worst elements of the older games (grinding, repetitive generic missions, predictable NPC AI, etc) and combined them with an innovative range of modern annoyances (crackpot developers, troll players, sometimes toxic community, shared online universe even in 'solo' mode, etc).  I'm not saying the game is terrible - but overall I found it disappointing, lacking both features as an MMO and content for it's (sort of) single player experience.

Now, however, with the release of Elite Dangerous: Horizons I believe it is time to throw my toys out of the pram.  Horizons being a season of DLC for Elite: Dangerous in the format of a new AAA priced game.  I can't see how driving around empty planets is going to adress the games more basic flaws, and I don't have much interest in the games other allegedly upcoming features.  I won't be purchasing Horizons - but I'll still be sharing a universe with Horizons players with an economy that I imagine will become geared towards players who can loot and craft and so on.  I can't even be happily obsolete in peace in the non-existent single player campaign.

Apparently this is part of a ten-year development program.  So as far as I can tell it's an early access game for the next ten years and early adopters get the reward of buying the game full price ten times?  In the circumstances I am even offended by the 25% 'loyalty discount' I have available for the purchase of Horizons, given that I'd still be paying £30 for a season pass of DLC with much more to follow while I still don't have anything that feels like a complete game for the expensive title I already bought.

In conclusion, big jobs to Elite: Dangerous and then some.  This now obsolete version of the game isn't great as a standalone product, and anyone happily signing up to the ten year schedule of payments for a space MMO needs to be far more optimistic than myself that someday a lot of depth will be added to the game rather than just it's vast empty breadth.

reviewText:
A game that has all the makings to be something special, but never seems to deliver. There's a lot of good groundwork in this game, but it never feels whole, and at a certain point you will find yourself grinding forever for that next ship or upgrade. Nothing fundamentaly changes once you have that next piece of shiny either. You'll just gain money from the three things there are to do in the game; trade, fight, or explore, slightly faster. Another reviewer noted that the early portion of this game is the best part of the experience. And this is largely true, although the game does nothing to guide you toward what to do first. This is fine too though, I think there's a place for games that don't hand hold. The game does have some decent tutorials to get you through the basics of flying, landing, and fighting.

Once you have a handle on things you can upgrade to a few new ships fairly quickly. The ship design is probably one of the strongest aspects of this game. Each ship is rendered beautifully, and is balanced for it's particular role. Some ships are better for combat, while others are obviously only good for trading, and some sit somewhere in the middle. They each sound and feel different as well, larger ships have an obvious heft to the way they maneuver, but also sound heavy when the engines kick in. This really gives each ship a bit of a personality, to the point where I found myself getting attached to a particular ship.

There is a point where this game turns into a much different experience from when you are starting out. It's the point at which every step you want to take turns into an insufferable grind. It feels like the result of developers creating too big of a universe to actually fill. And to fix that, they made the progression artificially long. This really only serves to highlight the monotony present in this game though, because now you're engaged in the process of min/maxing for progression. If you want to make credits, forget about missions, most of them don't pay well enough to be worth the time. Forget exploration too, that definitely doesn't pay well. You'll spend your time at a resource collection site blowing up the same enemies over and over again, or if you feel that isn't soul crushing enough you can run a trade route, which typically boils down to flying back and forth between two systems in a slow heavy ship where nothing much happens. And don't get me wrong, combat is fun and has some depth to it here, but it's ultimately repetitive especially after 100 hours or so in the same ship or maybe two. It also doesn't give you the same sense of scale some old space sim games like Freespace do.

So, I think it's time for me to take my leave from this game. The grind is just too much of a time suck and doesn't have much more to offer. The combat is fun, so I might continue to dabble in that here and there. Exploration is cool too, but a whole galaxy to explore isn't much more than a marketing bullet point. There really isn't much out there and what is there takes way too long to get to. If you're going to make the conceit that you can travel faster than light, why can I only jump a limited distance? I'd like to make a trip to the center of the galaxy, but I don't have a spare 50 hours to spend watching loading screens. There needs to be some sort of challenge to exploration, right now the only challenge is to your attention span.

I can't fully recommend this game. It's fun for a while, but it gets pretty repetitive, and turns into a major time sink after a while. They would do well to add some more variety to the game, make missions viable, more varied and complex, make exploration a bit more of a challenge somehow. Enjoy the first 20 to 40 hours or so, but try not to get sucked into the black hole that is the progression grind.

reviewText:
Elite: Dangerous is not a good game - there are simply not enough game components for a player to actually play.
It is a space simulator of sorts and if you look at it this way, it's kind of cool.

However, and that kills it for me, the Dev decided to apply a, in my opinion, very shady way of doing business.
If you bought the main game (Elite: Dangerous) prior to the release of Elite Dangerous: Horizons (EDH), you have to pay full price again to get the expansion.
Buying EDH gives you ED and EDH, so to speak.
There is no way (at the moment) to get 'Horizons' as a DLC.
So, the Devs would like you to kind of pay full price, again, for an expansion.

The fact that 'old' ED (without H) is still available, nearly priced the same (!) as EDH speaks volumes.

Now, what keeps the Dev from doing the same move next year? Or next April? Or next Wednesday?
They did it once - they will do it again.
Stay clear of this Dev.


--- If the state of this matter changes, I will change the review accordingly - Date: 17th of Dec. 2015 ---

reviewText:
-- UPDATE 2 --
It's at this time that I'm really, really sad. I've made a stupid decision. I spent 10 hours making 10mil to get enough money to upgrade from a Python to Type9 fully kitted to trade.
Then I got the type9, really excited, took screenshots of the new interior just as I always do when I get a new ship. Then I bought my upgrades.
Then I launched out of the pad.
And then I tried my hardest to fly.
Holy hell.
I tried harder.
Holy crap my grandma could probably walk faster on her cane in comparison to the speed of this ship boosting.
I finally make my way outside, and I already know what's going to happen.
I make it to the station that I have to end up selling my stuff in and then take about 7-10 minutes to land because I ended up on the wrong side of the port. After selling everything, I sell the interiors and then the ship and rebuy my old ship.
I lost 10 mil.
Which means I lost 10 hours.

I quit the game and opened up YouTube and am now watching Elite Dangerous trading and pirating videos as I type this. At least I learned a lesson: Python > Type9 cringe-worthy agility. Perhaps next time I'll watch some gameplay of those ships lol
-
Goes to show how great this game is, though. I spent 10 hours to get a new ship, got it, hated it, sold it, lost 10 hours, and still love this game and plan to play it again immediately after waking up.
10mil/10hours would be stupid again

reviewText: Elite isn't a game for everyone, but if it clicks" with you
date: not many other games come close. Many will say it's "a mile wide and an inch deep
recommended:
and although that may have been true in Winter 2014 when it released, the constant free updates Frontier Dev have pushed out have really helped given the game depth. It's only going to get better in 2016 with Horizons, including atmosphereless planetary landings, character customization, multicrew, deployable fighters from the bigger ships, and more.

For me, the game is a solid 9 or 9.5 out of 10. My main complaints are with the randomly-generated missions, which tend to be repetitive and sometimes confusing to new players. But those aren't even necessary to touch and are supposedly getting a co-op and multi-level update soon, so maybe they're getting better.

RECOMMENDATION: Go to the subreddit /r/elitewings" and join a playergroup with an active TS. I'm a member of The Code

reviewText:
The game is massive and will take you a LONG time to get used to every mechanic it offers.

If you enjoy space exploration this game is for you. It has good combat/trading/exploration options for varying degress of space enthusiasm. You can lose youself pretty quick or run out of fuel and not know a close space station to dock at. But if you take your time and learn the game, you CAN get your moneys worth. You must be invested, it is not just a sit down and beat it quickly type game. You can spend several hours and not make a dent, or get attacked by space pirates and are forced to take a loan to get a new spaceship to continue your adventures.

The game offers basic to expert level tutorials for all space travellers and video guides to show you how to play (external links to youtube, not ingame videos)

If you think you can handle the extreme, the void and the great beyond... Then get this game and invest some time into it, You (probably) won't regret it if you learn how to use all the games mechanics to your advantages.

I personally spent 2 hours when i started learning the basics of the game through the tutorials (and cursing alot too when the mechanics proved to be difficult to master) and I am now several hours into the game and it is still frustrating, yet the more I play the better I get, and the more fun and further I can travel and explore. I'm still in the learning phase and It is still throwing new mechanics and gameplay at me.

So much to take in and learn when you start playing, but from a review standpoint, $70 is expensive if you don't plan on investing time into learning how to play and getting the most out of your time spent playing. So visit the forums, ask questions and watch the tutorial videos and play the tutorial missions (You will need it and won't regret doing it!)

reviewText:
I want to recommend it so much, but I just can't. The flying mechanics are beautiful, the graphics are beautiful and the sounds are BEAUTIFUL.

What is actually in the game so far is very, very well done - but that's just it. The game has been out for just under a year now, and it's recieved 4 major updates (with a 5th one very close). Although these updates add cool things, it just doesn't feel like it slots in properly and they just feel unneeded on the whole. When you get down to it, there is a distinctive lack of things to do.

Before the game came to Steam though, I put a conciderable amount of time into it (close to a week, I think). In this time, I exhausted the game of everything it had - I'd traded, pirated, bounty hunted, mined and explored, in almost every ship available until I was bored senseless. I really want to play it again, but there's just nothing for me to do.

The largest problem though, the one that really gets to me, the one that turned this review to negative, is Horizons. If you don't know, Horizons is the upcoming update adding the ability to control a rover on a planet. Planet transitions were promised since day 1 of the alpha - since people were backing the game on Kickstarter. So why then, do existing players, even if they had the Beta of the game and paid £50 ($75) for it, have to pay the full price of the game to recieve the update (which to be honest looks a little underwhelming) when new players will recieve the update completely free of charge?

So really, if the game sounds appealing to you (and you can wait for No Man's Sky), wait for Horizons. Otherwise, even if you're slightly unsure, just wait for No Man's Sky. It'll be worth the wait.

reviewText:
Firstly I'm an old gamer, played the first Elite to death, completely ruled my life for 24 months, every waking moment.
So its with a heavy heart that i report that this games is a hollow clone of the first master piece, but it would be remiss of me not to mention the colossal potential that this tech demo has.

They delivered a skeleton of what was promised with the core game, unfinished and desolate if i want to use my imagination i would read a book but i want to play a game so id appreciate that it has some meaningful game mechanics, and to top it off they then release DLC that is as expensive as the full game and ask that we take them for their word that they have a ten year plan to finish the game...... i have a radical idea why not finish the core game before f@%king over your player base with another pipe dream.

This game may well be the best space sim ever developed but that's not gonna be for another 2 years and by that time there wont be a bridge left standing for their short sighted cash grab to burn.


Pick it up Xmas 2017 on sale for $10, if it still exists, they might have something finished by then.

reviewText:
This is arguably one of the very best space/flight sims I've ever had the pleasure of playing. It's immersive, it's vast, it's exciting - you never quite know what's going to happen once you jump into a new star system. Yeah, there's a bit of a learning curve as people mention, but I don't think it's nearly as bad as some critics would have you believe. One bit of advice though: A good HOTAS is its own reward. Was pleasantly surprised to discover they already had a profile for the Saitek X55, so all the agony of binding controls was taken care of for me. This made things much easier to learn, and I'd imagine it'd do wonders for anyone just starting out.

Another thing I have to applaud is that this is not a pay-to-win sort of game. Microtransactions are the bane of modern MMOs in my opinion, but this one hits it dead-on by avoiding all of that. Yes, there's DLC, but we're talking paint schemes and decals for your ships, not overpowered superweapons or XP boosts. When you buy the game, you're buying *the game.*

The level of immersion might be the crown jewel though. I have a TrackIR, and being able to look around and interact with the cockpit's instrumentation and menus as though I was actually sitting inside of it has probably been the biggest thing I love about the game. There's a feeling of badassery when your ship is transported to the docking area of a space station and you take off for the first time, and being able to look around and take it all in just makes it that much better.

Oh, and the ability to play by yourself with computer NPCs? Yeah, that's the good stuff. Sometimes it's nice to enjoy a game like this without worrying about griefers or trolls coming by and ruining your day (although you'll discover in due time that NPC pirates like to try and do the same thing.)

Overall, I recommend picking this title up. There's no shortage of things to do and I'm honestly very excited to see what future developments bring.

reviewText:
This is a long read.

Elite:Dangerous is probably a game you will not enjoy. Wait, what? Yes, statistically speaking you probably will not like this game. It's not like other games, this is a game for a few very dedicated players, and pretty much no one else. This is actually why I LOVE this game. The community is exclusive, but tight.

The game is dying. Well, you certainly could say that, but you would be very much wrong. With 6.5 years left in the lifescycle, this game is barely even born yet. As for activity, just look at the E;D subreddit, and you will quickly see that people not only play this game every day - much like I do - but have a love for it which few games earn.

If you read all the negative reviews, they typically come from three types of people:

1. The player who put in 200+ hours and is complaining that the game is now boring. Two. Hundred. Hours. That's a lot of playtime before you get bored. I love Skyrim, but I haven't even squeezed 200 hours of of that one. Basically, if you've played 200+ hours, you've at least gotten your money's worth, compared to 90% of games out there.

2. The player who bought E;D on sale, expecting some sort of Star Wars adventure game. This is not an adventure game, it has no story, it has no real plot and the missions are pretty much all the same. It's a simulator, which I think is the part a lot of these reviews don't get.

3. The player who complains about the expansions costing money. No ♥♥♥♥, people are working, probably full time, to roll out expansions and they have a small team. They have to eat too.

The game is grindy. When you play any open world game, there will be some activities which must be done repetitively. My favorite is when people try to tell me that this game could be more like WoW. Really? Because WoW isn't grindy? I played WoW for years and stopped reading the quest descriptions after like a week. Just click quest, kill, click quest, repeat thousands of times. Run the same dungeon and battleground a thousand times to get some gear. Do daily quests, literally the same exact quest every single day, for months to buy a sweet mount. Come on. Yes, E;D is grindy, but it's grindy becuase it's simulates a real world kind of environment, where you have a job to do - if you want to - and you have to do it a bunch of times to buy better" ships

reviewText:
I decided I will be giving Elite: Dangerous another shot after the update. Major disappointment.

As an owner of E:D, I was really disappointed when I learned that they are charging new customers the same price for both E:D and Horizons as they were charging us, old customers, for Horizons. I decided that I won't pay the money for Horizons because I didn't think planetary landing was something incredibly special that would justify the price. As it turned out, I was right to do so. Planetary landing offers nothing special for me, to me it's just another setting for a base.

Given the controversy that the expansion created upon launch, we had Frontier telling us that the original game will continue to be developed alongside Horizons and many people, like me, accepted this as a compromise. As long as we play in the same universe with people playing Horizons and as long as we're not at a disadvantage against Horizons players, everything's OK in my book. That's not the case with 1.6 and 2.1 anymore. Frontier, being the greedy bunch they are, decided that they will give an edge to Horizons players by making the engineers" unavailable for people that don't own the expansion. This means that if you don't own Horizons

Disappointing.

reviewText:
Updated 02/14/2016 - Horizons Review Included

Do I Continue to Recommend this Game?

Yes, within reasoning.

Elite Dangerous is a game with massive scale, however the perception of depth is different to the individual. I've seen varying responses as to what the game lacks and what the game consists. Furthermore let me start off by saying that this game is still early in development and a successor to the Original Elite. The game does not contain a campaign, and optional campaign, or any of the such, instead it relies of interactions with the universe around you as a whole. You are only a mere cog in the gears that is the milky way galaxy. What lies ahead? Well certainly anything, which is exactly the point that Frontier Developments wants to make.

Yes you are paying full price for a video game and after that an upfront cost of seasons. However the case is that we are paying for future development of an ongoing game. Frontier Development has taken this game across leaps and bounds since the kickstarter phase in 2012. The game itself is 1:1 scale of the Milky Way galaxy, and utilizes a Faster-Than-Light drive or the FSD. Which is an Alcubierre Drive[www.andersoninstitute.com]. This works in coordination with the ships, which are essentially giant quantam computers..... Yes, they calculate coordinates in realtime. The FSD works in two modes, Supercruise, which is a form of interstellar travel, and Hyperspeed, which gets you to the point of largest mass in the next system. The Flight Model also works in conjunction with this, and has two modes outside FSD. Atmospheric-Simulated and Newtonian-Assisted flight models come with every ship. Essentially its Flight Assist on, and Flight Assist off. The reason why i say this is that, Flight Assist on, you are basically flying through a simulated atmosphere of space, capable of still moving in multiple directions, and azmuiths still however. Flight Assist off you are full newtonian, with a little bit of assist, there is still some slight yaw resistance and a speed limit, these are for safety reasons, as newtons third law would surely disagree.


The game engine is the Cobra engine, which was an inhouse engine that Frontier plans on using in their second game. The game uses StellarForge[www.space.com] and you can just stare off at the depth and beauty of the universe, watching as planets, stars, even blackholes orbit around you. Fight through cloudy thick asteroid fields[www.polygonpi.com] with 7.1 surround sound blowing you away as a Federal Corvette boosts over you. Visualise
nebula and other entities like never before. Land on various planets as they become available in time. Influence political powers as humanity slowly turns a cold war into a hot war. Watch as various anomalies and unknown artifacts get discovered. Listen to rumors of Thargoids........ Maybe who knows you might just find a barnacle or two while doing donuts in your SRV.


All in all, in my opinion this game is very much worth the price tag, as we are all but sure there is more to come. Frontier Developments does post weekly newsletters, updates, and the like. They are a public company and do post public monthly finance reports. Therefore its just a well structured game with a good company at its head with a bright future. So yes, I do recommend it.

8.5/10

reviewText:
**Review if you've never played space simulators at all**

I enjoy playing Elite: Dangerous, however as someone who has little to no experience with space simulators I find it difficult to get into. Why am I required to look up tutorials of the game because the in-game tutorials aren't sufficient for newcomers? Nonetheless, I really want to be good at this game.

I haven't gotten into online yet, as I still have trouble navigating and locating a mission/contract way-point. I've gotten the hang of combat, but I still have much to learn.

Pros:
+ Beautiful and smooth, even on my garbage laptop.
+ Audio and soundtrack is extraordinary.
+ Has a solo mode so beginners can get the hang of the controls, navigation, and screw around.
+ People have said exploration would only be fun if you're familiar with astronomy. I can't speak for everyone, but I enjoyed cruising around different galaxies and systems despite my lack of knowledge of astronomy.
+ Once you've mastered combat, it gets really fun.

Cons:
- As others have said, in-game tutorials.
- Navigation is confusing sometimes, such as looking for a place to dock.
- Customization is okay, however I haven't reached the point to purchase good parts.
- Beginners will have trouble adjusting to a genre they've never played before, although I don't see it being easy to learn since there are many elements in the game which make it magnificent.

Hopefully, by the time I've had 5 hours of gameplay I will be able to answer most of my questions about the system, functions, and navigation of the game. For now, if you're like me and have never or rarely played space games, then expect spending some time learning the ropes. Otherwise, if you really want a simple space game, go play mass effect.

reviewText:
It's not a bad game at all, for me it's close to what I wanted from a space sim.

The thing is that the positives of this game can be negatives as well; for example the complexity. This game is very physics based and because of that navigation can be tedious, if you have patience with that then you're golden.

After you've figured out how to not zoom by stuff when going at light speed you also have to figure out docking and tailing a target.

If you were going to make a real life based space simulation where light speed is like horse and carriages then this would be it.

After that complexity then we get to the complexity of understanding your ships gear. Just basing it on the arrows isn't enough as some stuff costs more but are crappier than the cheaper stuff.  So in the end you will end up on youtube looking at what weapons do before buying one.

Combat is normal flight sim stuff the UI makes it pretty simple to know where your target is, you can also target specific subsystems which is nice.
voteText: 30 of 49 people (61%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
First of all, the time played is not correct. I played this game before it was on Steam and it totals in approximately 950 hours at the time of writing.

Do not expect this game to guide you. There are no tutorials that explain the gameplay mechanics, watch tutorials on YouTube or ask people to help you.

In Elite, Cash = Progress, so go get that money! How? Be a peaceful trader, feel the tension of smuggling, kill criminals for their bounties, explore the vast space, pirate other people - It's up to you, all those are pretty balanced and give money scaling with risk.

I play this game since 31/12/14 and I've surely sunk some time in it. If you are looking for a space game in which you can feel really immersed, this is the game for you. If you are looking for a bug free game, this might not be for you.

The game has instancing issues (It uses P2P for player interaction), NPC AI is pretty bugged at the time of writing (2.0.08/1.5.08), there is a bug in the mission generation system that can be abused to get tons of cash in a short time, and a few more. Those are not really gamebreaking but many of them will be fixed in 2.1/1.6 that releases in June. It overhauls the mission system, NPC AI and a few other things. The instancing issues can be overcome by relogging most of the time so it is not really gamebreaking.

It also has compatibility for Gamepads, Flight sticks, TrackIR, Oculus Rift and HTC Vive, this game is basically must have for VR, it is made for it.

TL;DR: Good space game but expect bugs and a lot of learning.

reviewText:
I'll start off by saying the game does a wonderful job at making you feel like you're realy in space. Graphics, sounds and all the fiddy-bits that people either love or hate just make it imersive (at least to us who have never been in space). I'm not afraid to claim they nailed it, toss in a VR headset and triple WOW.
Now, yes space is a big place but sadly playing the game feels so empty. They need to figure out a way to personalize an engagement mechanism for the players, other then some community driven event that seems to happen somewhere on the other side of the universe.  Myself I kept on playing cause I didn't put myself myself in the grind to buy the most expensive ship. I've did a bit of roll playing as a miner, bounty hunter, trader or pirate but those are short lived lives which did pay for my ships. P.S still can switch between those jobs with my ships to suit my mood.

Now what I dont like is their roll out plan, (canada right now is) $40  for  Elite Dangerous , + $40 for  Hozions , + unknown more money for who knows how many more  passes/DLC  are in the pipe? My guess is as many as it's profitable, I feel like it's the Half-life 2 episodes all over again. At least none of the 3 were at full triple A" price (which I think anyone can google to find out how that concept/back story went).
So there lays my problem
date:
I feel  Elite: dangerous  is a unfinshed product which I can't recommend paying full AAA price for.  How much will we have to pay to play the game fixed? reviewText:
The developers of Elite: Dangerous have made a huge, huge game. There so much length and width to the universe it's pretty amazing - however, they forgot depth. There isn't really alot of content. Basically, it's a huge, empty universe with the same assets re-used over and over. Wings exist, but they can only be four players deep - dash your hopes of starting a huge inter-stellar guild or company. You can't trade items or money to other players. For a multi-player game, Frontier seems to have gone to great lengths to make it feel almost entirely singleplayer.

But, there are some good points to the game - It's a huge universe. You could lose yourself in it; I have once or twice. The assets, like I said, get re-used over and over, but they are very pretty so it doesn't get old for awhile. Combat is repetitive but still satisfying, it's not a 'true' space sim in that they use gun sound effects (whereas in true space, the sounds of explosions or gunfire would be soundless. I am a space nerd.) and the physics are made deliberately nerfed to increase difficulty (yawing, for instance.)

All in all, I cannot recommend the game to any but fans of space games. There is a decent trading and combat system in place, and alot of potential for explorer-types.

reviewText: Elite:Dangerous is a space sim that will cause you to become enveloped in our very own galaxy. That's right, it is a 1:1 scale of the Milky Way with 400 billion star systems, and i've maybe seen 200 in the hours i've played (kep in mind that the last dozen or so hours i was bounty hunting and then i was involved in a war that i believe i caused) but nonetheless its huge. Yes, trading will net you hundreds of thousands or more, but that really depends on your ship which is what a lot of Youtube videos leave out -  the initial cost of your ship and subsequent outfitting. Getting the smallest trade vessel, the Hauler, will only allow a maximum of around 20 or so cargo spaces if you want a decent Frame Shift Drive that will allow you to travel farther distances so that you're not just jumping across stars for 45 minutes. Travelling around 160 light years from your initial system will allow you to net the most cash for your goods (recommend rare commodities at this point). 160 light years is a long, long time if you are just flying. Refuelling also costs time or money, and certain modules on your ship can cause the ship to overheat very quickly (bigger guns, more guns, lasers over projectile weapons) all have a certain power draw effect, although you can play around with the modules to turn some off completely.\nThere is a bit of a learning curve to the game, but it can be played quite well with mouse and keyboard with a bit of rebinding for us budget-constrained gamers who dropped full price for this game. Bounty hunting has to be by far my most favourite, with Nav Beacons or Resource Extraction Sites being prime locations for many bounties. Now you might destroy a sidewinder and be like Oh great
date: that was like 3000 credits WTF can i do with that" but nay

reviewText:
I'm pretty hard on game devs, I tell it as I see it. Elite Dangerous is a very entertaining game, and I really enjoy it. I actually purchased a Oculus Rift DK2 and Saitek x52 Pro just for this game. The gameplay is OK, the graphics are very good, and it looks really nice using Nvidia surround (3 monitors). In small doses, the game is fun.


The game seems to be in flux at the moment, with game altering changes occuring fairly often. Elite Dangerous still seems like a beta in regards to the amount of bugs, it's underdeveloped, missing alot of content, and can get boring if you play too much. The changes they're making don't really really make alot of sense (PP).

Overall, it's entertaining and I enjoy it & recommend people try it. 1 to 10, I give it a 7 - it's good but not great

reviewText:
What can be said that is not already in all the other fair reviews of this game. Its really a shame that the game is not better than it is. I has all the core things needed to be one of the best space flight sims ever but it falls short on so many levels but ill do my best to give a fair review.

The Good:

1. The game looks really good, though im not sure how it would look on a system that is just making the min req. My rig is pretty high end.

2. The combat it self is pretty good and is very fun ( for a while ) the controls are easy to get used to but not so dumbed down that it takes away from the game. ( the way the ships in EA Starwars Battlefront are a total joke to pilot )

3. A few options on how you want to advance in game that are different from each other ( more on this in the bad section )

4. The size and scope of the game is pretty nifty ( more on this in the bad section )

5. The weapons are fun to use

6. ummmm the game looks good .....

The Bad

1. Once you have done something one time you have pretty much experenced the most fun that thing will ever be ( example: going out to explore was almost fun, It took a lot of grinding to buy and equip a ship that would be able to do the job well but once I left charted space and flew around a few systems scanning thigns I wanted to smash my face on my desk because it was so boring )

2. what ever you end up doing its going to be a grind to get anything cool, and TBH the best ways to make money are offten the least fun, hauling cargo pays well once you have ship that can hold a huge load of goods but its zero challange  ( as a example )

3. The mission system is garbage, offten times you fly places and nothing happens or they lack the info needed to find objs and you end up just flying off to do something else. The pay outs are also so crappy you will never earn any cool ships/gear doing them before you lose intrest in the game

4.Huge lack of varried fights, with only a hand full of weapon systems to pick from a lot of the combat ships feel the same to both fight and pilot. So while at its core the combat was done pretty well once you have killed 60 ships or so, or taken part in a NPC fleet battle mission you have pretty much seen what combat has to offer.

5. zero depth, some of this I have already said but just to not end up pointing out every flaw it just boils down to zero depth" nothing is fleshed out at all the game feels stale like they just gave up and said "well we have all the basics and it looks really good so lets pack up shop and call it a day"

6. Broken promises from the company
date:
So many big claims as the game was in the works and starting to come out only to change things up and go for the cash grab with all this paid DLC crap when the base game still needs so much work. when Horizons was revealed and they were asking for 120$ USD for the season pass I sent the company a email asking what the hell was going on. In the reply the guy told me it was " A surprise to them as well " Then they end up offering the entire DLC with base game for less than the price I got the base game for in the frist place. It just rubs me the wrong way how flip floppy the company has been on the way this game is suported and marketed. Its left me with zero faith in anything they have to say.

Final Thoughts
Save your money
recommended: wait for reviews of Nomans Sky or for Star Citz to come out

reviewText:
Played on both PC and Xbox One. While it has a lot of promise, it also suffers from one of the harsh realities of space - it's big, mostly empty, and it takes forever to get anywhere. Elite sticks a bit too closely to its venerable lineage by being a bit too shallow in an age where we all want depth. Firstly, while Elite can be a very pretty game, it's also awfully sparse and boring for a lot of the time. Exploration yields some very pretty vistas, but after you've seen a few of them it all looks the same. There's really nothing to do except look at things. The trading mechanics are shallow. Many systems look the same. There's no character in the game world to speak of. There's some backstory floating around and supposedly driving the universe but it doesn't matter a single bit to most players. Combat is pretty boring even with the Newtonian mechanics.

If I could sum up my problems with this game, it boils down to this - it isn't much fun, and I play games to have fun. The exploration aspect is pretty awesome but even that will wear thin, and most of that will be spent jumping between systems that aren't memorable and aren't interesting. You can acquire a load of credits but it doesn't matter, there's no real purpose. This is a big sandbox but the sand is only half an inch deep.

Elite: Dangerous has a lot of potential - it has a vast universe, the new DLC adds planetary landings, the universe has the elements to be quite dynamic, and they could do quite a few things if they wanted to. But it's too big, too empty, and too shallow for me to recommend, and I doubt the developers will ever achieve the potential here. The universe is too sterile and they don't seem interested in injecting any life into it. Freelancer suffers from shallow gameplay but was enjoyable because it had a lot of character and didn't adhere too closely to space is big". Elite does
date: and it's all the more boring for it. Keep an eye on this one

reviewText:
People that are looking into buying this game should know this isn't for everyone. I would actually say this game isn't for the most people. It involves a lot of imagination, damn you will have to imagine everything, almost. But let me start with the good things because there are some but also few of them.

There is a HUGE universe to discover, the map is insanely large. This can be good but also bad. So we've decided to talk about the good things first. I don't think you'll ever see the whole map, that's how big it is. Graphically speaking it's good. Not the best but it's at that level that it doesn't bother you or brake the immersion. Sound is also good, with some problems here and there depending on your configuration. Well that's all I could find good about this game.

Now let me tell you why I don't recommend this game. IT'S BORING! I know, most of you stopped here, but if you are still reading let me tell you why. All you can do in this game is: be a trader, explorer, miner, mercenary, smuggler, pirate. All that sounds good at first but once you understand what every of those “jobs” mean you'll move on to another game.

Being a trader involves getting cargo from one place to another. That's it. You will have to remember where that good seels at a higher price and where you can buy it a lower price, there is no in game feature to tell you or remember where you found best prices. Then you take the cargo from a space station that looks like the other one you've been on, there are like 2-4 models, and you pilot your ship through space. You might encounter someone that tries to stop you and kill you and so on. A little pew pew, you kill them and move on.

Being an explorer. Well you must think with that huge map this must be the most fun of them. Well it's not, it's the most boring one of them. Why? Because all systems are alike, you've seen that type of sun, that type of planet before and you'll see them everywhere you go. You enter in a solar system, press one button to scan and that's it. You've discovered, mayb,e a few planets!!! WOW! Now repeate.

Being a miner, you get your mining laser and try to find some asteriods to mine them. You get the resource and then try to sell it.

I won't even bother to explain the rest cause I think you got the idea. There is no story, you have to make your own, most people would say that's the fun part. But in reality it's not, because you don't have the tools to do so. I could've imagined the same thing without the game and I'd have the same amount of fun. It's a sandbox without the sand. If you ask me I would've prefered a map with 20-40 solar systems but with more than having millions of solar systems that look alike and nothing to do.

Most ships look like boxes, nothing interesting to see there. Check Cobra MKIII as an example. Although I understand why they used this kind of desing, they wanted to keep the feeling of the old game and I must say this wouldn't bother me if the game would be fun to play. In the end you rarely see your ship from outside. The interior is almost the same on every ship and GUI is actually the same on all of them. Sound will crackle from time to time, depending on your configuration.

I've seen there is an expansion, almost more expensive than the actual game, that allows you to land on planets. That sounds cool until you realize that every planet is empty, just dust, nothing to see there. I don't understand what the developer is thinking. How is this fun? Ok maybe the first time it's fun to land on a planet, but if you do this 10 times, than it's becoming boring because it's the same story. I'm already bored of repeating my self, but this is the game.

If you really like space games, for 10euros it's a good price, you'll spend a few hours having fun and then you'll forget it even exist, but it's worth for that amount I would say. I don't recommend buying the expansions because there will be more of them and in the end you'll realize you've spend over 1000 euros on a game. Maybe not that much, but I don't think it's too far since they presented what they want the game to be and what they actually released in this expansion. I mean it's way too far from what they are wishing for this game, it will need another 10 expansion packs like this one. Remains to be seen.

I sincerly wish to like this game, I really want to play it but there is nothing fun to do in it right now that I haven't done before. I love how they gone into detail with ship systems, but I don't see the same attention to details in the actual universe. Right now it feels like an early alpha. Maybe that's how I should take it, but at the same time when I see that expansion and for that price... it's a shame.

What I can say to developer is thank you for trying at least, dunno if this is what they intended the game to be but there is still time to fix it, although it's hard to change a first impression, but not impossible. There hasn't been a space game for a long time and we needed it. At other developers that are looking to make a game like this would learn from their mistakes.

reviewText:
People who don't own this are not gamers, plain and simple.

If you want reasoning behind this, i will provide plenty in between small breaks i take from the tutorials.

I never played a space sim before, always wanted do, but since i enjoy most tactical rpg or turn based strategy, this kind of games always looked kind of daunting, a moutain to climb, an ocean to drown in. But if you think the hours i have spent into learning all the tricks and curves there are in turn based strategy, well f*ck it, i'm gonna try it for this game.

Everybody has played the original Elite (1984), and if there are people who have not, i recomend they read about it before even thinking if they should buy Dangerous or not. People talk about classics like, diablo, tomb raider and various other 90's titles that made people jump up and down like monkeys. I laugh at those titles, i sh*t in their mouths, the sheer simplicity and low thinking scope that made franchises worth millions, with corrupted developers making fun of their customers, offering supposedly GRADE A material that usualy comes out broken and is bearable after heavy patching, and maybe a year or two of waiting. A little i have read about this release, tells me that it was made with a very low budget, compared with other releases, and that on official release game (meaning not beta) it had minimal to no bugs and glitches, now this ranges from RARE to NONEXISTENT in our gaming age, since every game comes out with it's own quirks and forums of frustrated users begging for a fix, much like junkies beg for a fix :)

Beyond that, the first battle i had in the tutorial in which i had to destroy a similar vessel with my own with just a pair of silly lasers that would not seem to help me on aiming, turned into a 15 minute epic struggle through an asteroid field.  That of course happened after 2-3 hours i spent tweaking my controls. I have read people's reviews about how difficult the controls are, even with a xbox controller and i tell you, it's all turds and lies. People love to complain. Besides the first elite, as i said, i have never touched another simulation game. That is not entirely true, since i own evochron mercenary and all the X3 serrier. i played about 14 mins each game, and then i abbandoned them because of the effort it needed to learn those games. But not with this one, i will give it all, even if i am SH*T with this kind of games, i can figure out how to support my team leader in multiplayer open world, so maybe i am not an ace in combat but i can surely help in a bad situation. If i can do it, everybody can, don't be afraid of this game, once you tweak your controls and you figure what everything does, it will start to become natural and player-friendly.  Also this is the first time i am going to spend good money on a joystick/throttle combination, and this happens not because i don't like how the controller works, but because i want to feel it, be in it, role-pay it, hell, if i have money on my hands i will gladly get a vr system for this baby, and usualy i am AGAINST vr.

Now we move to the most essential part of this review".  I will not go behind numbers of ships (stop crying

reviewText: Unemployement can be a wonderful thing. I've spent the last week doing little else but play Elite Dangerous. As a programmer I enjoy the discovery of a complicated, well-designed piece of software. This software is a contender in the big-universe genre of games such as Eve Online and Star Citizen.\nEvery piece of software has to start somewhere. This is always the first thing" it does before it does anything else. Call it the seed of the program. In Eve
date: it's relationships; the game is inherently social. In Star Citizen it is the immersive avatar that can walk around and climb into ships that can travel from planent to planet like a genuine space marine. The seed of Elite Dangerous is a space combat simulator. It is from this simulator that they are creating a game.\nOnce i overcame the steep learning curve of operating a space ship in a realistic flight simulator
recommended: I eventually managed to complete some missions without exploding for the usual reasons: pressing the boost button inside a hanger with no shields
hoursPlayed: running out of fuel on the way to wherever
voteText: shooting the wrong space ship with my guns
helpfulPercent: flying in space without guns
votesHelpful: etc. If you have ever played this game then I'm certian you can certianly relate to these troubles. For a time I was confused by the flight mode transitions; I didn't realize there were just more buttons to learn.\nEach step on the learning curve opens new dimensions of gameplay; each bit of information on the screen has meaning and there is skill to develop to absorb that much data. From the maps of the galaxy and star systems to the tables of commoditites for trade to every last panel on a ship's dashboard. Mastering the controls with the Flight Assist enabled has been it's own challenge. It is core to the seed of this game. I think i have played enough to grasp the physics of managing power
votesTotal: heat and momentum
votesFunny: and munitions in a space dogfight. I have learned which panels mean what and which ones i should look at when. I feel like a goram fighter pilot! Then I see videos of smugglers loading contraband under the noses of system police in Silent Running mode
commentsCount: then watch them land with their illicit booty without any flight assist. Suddently I feel like I've barely started to play the game.\nThe game that Frontier has built around the seed of a space combat simulator is an RPG. There are a miriade of ships available and the roster is growing all the time. The prices of the various ships go up as their capabilities increase. The cost of the weapons and various modules in the loadout can increase your ships value emmensly
column16: and the configuration of your modules with can change the dynamics of ship dramatically. The barrier to the best ships is money. The game is earning money to upgrade to more effective ships. There are a lot of ways to do this and it make take some figuring out. The game is well designed to prevent making more than a certian number of credits. I think these decisions fit seemlessly into the gameplay and actually help create a more dynamic experience that evolves at a reasonable pace. Do more things to make more money to get better ships so you can do more things. The seed has grown into something very intricate and beautiful. I'm excited that it is still growning
column17: too!\nPlaying this game requires that you experience a space flight simulator. It is captivating to shut down the engines and drift among the ice rings of a planet to watch the sun set behind it all. It is exciting when the target scan shows 'WANTED'. There can be some urgency about getting back to the air in a space station when your canopy is shot open and your life support clock is ticking down. It is vindicating when you land

reviewText:
I started the game, fell in love with the graphical effects. I started doing some basic missions, they weren't exciting, but I loved the controls; One of the few games where I can use my X52 properly.

I gained enough money with the missions and bought and outfitted a small miner. After following a friend's recommendation I found a very rich mining location. No hostiles, lots of painite and other expensive ores.

I got enough money to be a bit more flexible now! So I decided let's try something else that could bring me profit. I bought and outfitted an explorer ship. I went to distant unexplored stars, I explored for hours, I explored nebulas that were surprisingly boring once you got in them, I scanned suns, planets moons, asteroids (which later turned out to be completely useless), and after hours of doing nothing but looking at stars, planets, moons and after looking up some coordinates: blackholes, I was getting tired of doing that, so I returned to civilized territory to sell my scans. I received two hundred thousand. Disappointing, maybe I just wasn't meant to become an explorer then.

I started realizing most ships are rather unappealing. (There are always doors between the engines which I don't get, you get a door under it, and often on the front landing gear too. Why a door on the back, that even has a welded railing on it?)
I bought a Viper which looked somewhat decent. I figured I might become a mercenary. After experimenting with weapons I found an okay combo, and could destroy the enemy if they were alone. After killing several, my rank was still at Harmless" which I found rather insulting. But I found a mission that pays well
date: let's try that one! Rescue someone who was taken by Some Pirates. I search the star system and found the guy they were talking about. I shoot down the shields

reviewText:
I wanted to like this game, I really did. I had fun at first and the idea behind being able to play multiplayer/single player is great for avoiding griefers. Flight itself was fun, combat is fun except the AI isn't a challenge. I find AI is hard no matter what you try to do with it, it's either too good or not good enough so i can't fault the game for it to badly.

What drove me away from the game was two parts:

A-My friend from Australia could rarely get into group with me and wings only support 4 people. I have 8 regular playing friends. upwards of 20 depedning on what were all doing. PVP would be great but it would take us half an hour to get groups going and one guy never got in period no matter what we tried. Then if you all weren't dropping in at the same exact time then poof we would have to go through the process all over again.

B-There isn't really enough substance. Grind out ships, undermine for merits to get a paycheck, trade for real money ...snore. Mining would be fun but doesn't pay enough, exploration would be awesome but again doesn't pay and supposedly you can only go so far away from Sol.

C- have to add this one I know I said 2 parts but...influence of powerplay could be done in 1 player/private modes so you could literally pvpve without any way for anyone to get back at you so it turned into hauling wars basically...snore. Don't get me wrong I like being able to mine without asshats acting liek their gods for blowing up a vessel that has no guns but some of it shouldn't be in solo mode.


I hope the planetary stuff brings more to do. I also hope they start to allow ship items to be stored or at least 1-3 alternate loadouts per ship. sucks to refit to do sometihng then not be able to find the items you once had to buy again because each station only has x type parts. Also allow for ship part trading also, you can buy and sell items but not ship parts?

To be fair community goals and the news aspect of the game is awesome, and flight is fun. If you are a solo player this game will work great for you. If you came here looking for multiplayer coop....sorry.

reviewText:
This game is fantastic but needs to be taken off the store. Simply put the way the devs plan on selling this game is to sell a year worth of expansions and then re-release the game at full price with another year of expansions. Don't buy this game, even with a discount. I'ts only half the current game and 1/10th of what they plan to have in the game content-wise. If you really want to get this game either buy horizons (the newest version of the game at the time of me writing this) or go to Frontiers websight and cough up the $200+ to buy the lifetime expansion pass.

Update: So as of 02/16/2016 it appears Frontier has gotten a grip on there head and has started to pull it out of their ♥♥♥. To my understanding they're re-releasing (again?) horizons as a DLC, as it should have been, and are now using Elite: Dangerous as the base game. So far they've managed about an inch of head ♥♥♥ removal, which in my book at least shows they're trying. Still waiting to see if they've learned from their mistake and the price drops to a more realistic DLC level. Untill then, I hold my judgement.

PS: For those of you complaining about the lack of content, I wholeheartedly agree with you, but I found a video that helps explain it and has lots of useful pointers for Frontier.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ymyEZHP5mrk

reviewText:
Very buggy game. Controls reset everytime I try and change them for a second time, game frequently crashes and some minor graphical issues.

I've grown up playing the Elite and Frontier games (back on Amiga and PC), and while this one is graphically impressive, I am disappointed just how buggy the game is. It's ironic that people attacked developers for when the 90s versions were released with bugs and flaws, yet with limited ability to patch these games and redeploy them to gamers they still managed to run smoother than Elite Dangerous.

Very gutted, even for the sale price I wouldn't reccomend this game.

reviewText:
In the 80's there was a game called Elite.

It managed to take the feeble power of early generation computers and provide you with an incredible universe of wonder and intrigue. It was, and always will be an outstanding moment in gaming history.

Years later, Elite : Dangerous was made,and it made a lot of old gamers very, very moist.

It provided the original game, with a much larger scale to the universe, and replaced the wireframes with beautiful graphics.
But it also changed the way weapons work, bolted on a poorly implemented attempt at an MMO-style multiplayer, which at its core is exploit-able, made single-player an 'always online' affair.

Its not a bad update, its just the vast majority what has been updated has been cosmetic, and additions seem poorly guided and inserted lazily, in a way to get the multiplayer badge slapped on.

If your expecting Elite : Beautiful, it does provide that, it terms of gameplay, it doesn't quite hold up to the original from the 80's.

reviewText: Great game. I was a bit worried it would be a bit too good and drive Star Citizen out of the water, but I dont think I have to worry about that.\nElite was a great game for the 160 hours I sank into it, but I find my opinion of the game changing. With the recent update, they are providing the base game for free to players who pay $60 for the expansion; and screwing their old, loyal fanbase who helped the game onto its feet by asking them to pay nearly the full amount again. I loved Elite, but I won't take any more of this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t from greedy developers. Frontier disappointed me greatly, and I dont know if I can forgive them while they still ask for money in a game already without a load of features. DLC should never cost as much as the base game, and it DEFINITELY shouldn't be that expensive when it's adding much needed content to a staling universe.

reviewText:
It would be great if I could reccommend this game but I cannot. Flying the ships and docking etc work well, graphically it's reasonably pretty and there appears plenty to aim for within the scope of the game. Trading seems to work reasonably well too, small but consistant profits can be made

What lets the game down badly is that it's REALLY difficult to get started. There are NO SAFE AREAS IN WHICH TO TRADE EVEN PLAYING SOLO! When you are shot out of the sky 3 times in a high security system in the space of an hour by NPCs, losing everything and dumping you at the start again after 10 hours play makes you think that there is a serious balance issue to be addressed. The ships attacking were waaaaay tougher than the start starting ship you get and you don't have the speed to run either. It's not like I haven't played several games of a similar style, for example X2 where I ended up owning dozens of stations - cannot do that without having a scrap or two!

I'm glad I only payed a tenner for this game and would have been gutted if I'd payed more.

reviewText:
WELL SAID RHETTORICAL !


I really want to love this game, I really do. Sadly, the devs have caused me to never want to play again. Let me explain the pros and cons.

Pros:
- A vast galaxy to explore. I estimated that in an exploration-fit ship, you'd be able to reach the other side of the galaxy in about 95 hours. That's not including the return trip, and that's assuming you don't stop to scan anything along the way.
- A robust combat system. I'm not sure how you can really get more robust than flying around and shooting things with fixed or gimballed lasers or cannons or rails or plasma accelerators, or homing and dumb-fire missiles, launching chaff, etc.
- Beautiful graphics. This game looks astonishingly good. You certainly won't forget your first black hole or neutron star.
- Simplified flight model. It's not 100% realistic, but that makes for a more approachable flight model. The ships fly like jets in Battlefield, if a bit more responsive.

Neutral:
- Lots of frontloaded content. Your first 20-40 hours will be fantastic. Around 30 hours, you'll start to notice content slowing down. Around 40, things start looking familiar. At 50 hours, everything looked the same to me.
- Ship customization. There isn't a lot of reason to try to come up with a clever build, since the time you waste min/maxing your build equates to about 2.3561 more seconds in combat or 8.65 seconds shaved off your trade route. It's fun to customize, but ultimately pretty pointless.

Cons:
- Lack of depth. People will argue that if you got 50 hours of fun, you got your money's worth, but I find that to be a really dumb argument. This type of game is designed to be fun for hundreds of hours, yet I found myself struggling to find reasons to play after 70 hours, and finally gave up at 100. There just isn't a lot of compelling things to do. It's where the frontloaded content really starts to be a problem.
- Dev response. The devs tend to add things to the game for the sole purpose of checking off a box, like They want social interaction? Let's add the ability to group up to 4 people at once!" The community wanted guilds
hoursPlayed: and all we got was the ability to add a small number of people in a group at once

reviewText:
although i like this game and play it religiously
i cant recommend it for the price due to a few reasons

pros
graphics are amazing
the gameplay is really immersive
PvE is just as fun as PvP
it has rift support
you can explore every part of the milky way (literally over 100,000LY)

cons
it uses online only DRM so even if you are playing in solo play mode a momentary
hickup with your internet will crash your game

if you are in australia you WILL have instancing issues when playing in open play mode
(the fuel rats had to get an AU rat to save me when i ran out of fuel due to instancing problems that prevented a USA rat from being able to see my ship)

forced updates (not all of us have infinite hard drive space or want to wait an hour for an 8GB update)

updates are often bigger than the base game
(the INITIAL download size for the game was around 6GB and the next update was over 8GB bringing the total size to 14GB!!!)

when you buy the game you are required to give the devs your email address or you cant play
(which paves the way for subscription based play ie. WoW AT THAT POINT I WILL GET A REFUND AND STOP PLAYING!!!)

this game murders your upload bandwidth

the game crashes when you try to go to salvagable wreck beacons

getting the SOL permit is a pain in the ♥♥♥ (after 250 hours of working with the federation i still dont have it)


bottom line

its a great game but i cant recommend it for the price of $40AUD until this always on DRM is removed for solo play
(i normally play in open play but yesterday my internet was down due to a storm and i found out the hard way that even singleplayer mode needs an internet connection)

if you can find it in a 50% off steam sale like i did then sure go ahead and buy it
its a lot of fun as long as you have a very reliable high speed unlimited data plan and a lot of hard drive space for all the forced updates

i get 45FPS on my Alienware 14 running it in 1080p with high graphics settings (supersampling set to 1X)

reviewText:
I will briefly sum the game so you can read other reviews in the shortest time necessary:

Elite Dangerous is a fun game. For the first 100 hours for me at least since I got help from friends. I can buy many cheap ships on the first day.

Then things get slightly repetitive, where I have to continuously grind for money to buy and outfit a decent ship. At here the game is still fun, but not exciting anymore.

And then comes the worst part. O grind for an end-game ship and modules. Everything you do in this stage is boring and repetitive because the only way to earn lots of money is to trade. Very boring. In fact I probably spent 300 hours in this stage.

And finally, once I had money for the best ship and modules, I went on a shopping spree. This is the stage where the game suddenly becomes very exciting again, where you can sit back and kill any player in any ship. Then after this things get boring.

To summarize, the game goes like this: Stage 1(FUN) Stage 2(Decent) Stage 3(Extremely Boring) Stage 4(SUPER FUN)

Most people I know who play ED stop playing the game at stage 2 to the beginning of stage 3. In fact, I think the only reason that I played so long is my ambition to  pilot the ultimate battleship in ED.

Will I recommend this game? No. The fact that Frontier charges 50$  for the original game and another 50$ for a dlc is preposterous. This game is a mile wide, but an inch deep.

Go save your 100$ and spend it on Star Citizen. I think as Star Citizen has a hyge potential to be a mile wide AND a mile deep.

reviewText:
I played original Elite almost 30 years ago. Since then, I've been playing Elite-like games, most recently X series. X3 was my favorite, while X Rebirth was a disappointment at release, while now, few year later and after 4.0 patch, it is a fantastic game. Unfortunately, the same can't be said for Elite Dangerous.

I've really tried to like ED, but game is fundamentally flawed. Which is a shame, as I have very fond memories for the previous Elite games. Like all other people say, the game is empty. It doesn't matter if you have 400 bil starts if they all look all the same, and you have 3 types of stations where you can land. Rebirth has completely the opposite approach  - easy system is an art itself, and the stations vary in shapes. I'm flying around the stations just to see all tiny details, it's mesmerizing.

Traveling - it's boring as hell and it takes you 10min in real world to dock to another station is some other system. And since you always see the black screen, I dont see this can be fun.

Save games - while other games, like Rebirth, allow you to save games when you dock on stations or even mid flight, this is not true in ED. Server will always save your position and state. So if you travel for 10 mins and then some pirate intercepts you, you better defend yourself or you will lose ship (or at least money if you have insurance). What it does is, it discourages you to experiment, but to fell anxious instead. No fun in that.

Combat - maybe the best part of ED, but far from Rebirth. In Rebirth you can capture capital ships where you must disable turrets, engines, shields and then send marines to board. In some way, it feels like taking over the outpost in Far Cry. It's very rewarding.

The only part I like more in ED than in Rebirth is sound, especially engine noise - it's fantastic. Other than that, ED is an empty, boring game, not worth its name. Go buy X Rebirth instead, and have fun.

reviewText:
Watching people still defend this steaming pile amuses me greatly. Braben is up there with Molyneux in terms of snake oil salesmen and honestly should have had the “are you a pathological liar” treatment thrown at him at the same time ol’ Pete did. Elite Dangerous took a great platform and proceeded to do virtually nothing with it, instead selling promises which have managed to con a great number of people out of a great deal of money (first on kickstarter, and then via horizons) which have kept Frontier afloat. Braben is trying to do the *exact same thing* with the Planet Coaster mess, an always online game that you’ll not be able to play despite being an ostensibly single player game in the past. All in the name of wringing out more monies for Frontier.

When the whole thing comes crashing down, I will be stood with a bag of marshmallows and a cup of hot chocolate. Frontier deserves no less, along with 22Cents. Both of them represent the absolute worst of current dev practices. Over-promising, under-delivering, treating their consumers as disposable money presses to be bilked and having no respect for the larger gaming ecosystem.

The faster they collapse, the better for all of us.

reviewText:
Since this game requires internet access at all times, when it eventually collapses under the weight of no one playing this game will cease to exist for everyone. That isn't really that bad of a thing.

I think a lot of people got suckered in by the games positive review rating and video's, bought it on sale, then realized it's a glorified early access title. There's virtually no content, and it has the mechanics of a single player flight simulator rather than a vibrant world you can actually interact with as one might expect of an MMO title.

This absolutely should have just been a single player game with coop and direct IP connection. I suspect that since the developers only seem to have expierence doing that style of game that they just seriously underestimated what most players expect from a cooperative/MMO style game.

We'll see if the next two or thee expanions change any of that, but something tells me not many people are going to buy them at the price the developers seem to think they're worth.

The only pro's to this game are that it is very pretty and the Hyperspace mechanics are also quite pretty. However, the in-system 'Supercruise' works in ways that don't make a lot of sense and requires a lot of sitting there doing absolutely nothing to get from place to place. In a game with faster than light travel, you might expect that you could actually get where you're going quickly but in fact it can take you up to an hour and a half of real-life time to get from a star to the furthest station in a given system.

This game is a fan-driven kickstarter game, and believe me it really shows. If you aren't a fan of each of the previous Elite games, you will probably quickly grow bored of this title unless you enjoy sitting quietly and doing nothing for your entire gaming evening.

The options the game have are:
Exploration, not reliable. Scanners have a range, the most expensive does not. And detects all bodies on the sector (?).
Even if you ignore game-play mechanics, it does not paid. No rewards but money. And it's a very little cash. Killing 2 bounties will reward the same amount of credits that a week exploring. (2 bounties is 15 min hanging around navigation beacons killing random bad guys for no reason).
Trade, you need to depend on an external tool since the game has nothing relevant for it.
Power-play is, I don't know what is it. It feels dead and does not make much sense. The only reason is for the week incoming  of a few credits.
Damn, even the physicists are wrong!
I get and I agree of maximum speed. But the turning rate... It feels like a planes on space.

Devs needs to give love to explorers and other classes. They re-created the whole galaxy just for combat?

reviewText:
if you have ever played and enjoyed other games in the space trading/combat kind of genre, like the escape velocity games, or the actual older elite games, or even freelancer, then i think you'll find this enjoyable.

back in the day, i let myself get consumed by escape velocity nova, and then again by freelancer, and this game has grabbed onto me in the same way.  i'll play it a ton and i'll probably overdo it.  i originally bought this because i've been wanting something like this again and i've been impatient for star citizen, which i'm eagerly anticipating.  this has filled a gap for me very nicely.

overall, i do reccommend this game, but i feel like there are some elements of it that have yet to be fully fleshed out.  the developers seem fairly responsive and are continuing to work on gameplay elements and balancing things within the universe, so i'm comfortable with expecting that the game will only get better and better over time.  for example, the recent powerplay" update adds a lot of interesting features that were previously unavailable in the game

reviewText: Sorry but this game is really quite boring and shallow. There is really nothing to do other than fly around and haul stuff or shoot stuff - that's it. The trailers are very misleading in that it gives you the impression that there are npcs to interact with and missions and things to do. The missions are nothing but lame old fedex and kill x missions from a terminal. Grinding for money to get a bigger ship is really all there is to do, and once you got a bigger ship you just grind money for the next bigger ship. This game might appeal to those that like FPS games but otherwise it is far to shallow for anyone expecting deeper gameplay. If you really want to experience a deep game involving space exploration with cool missions and stuff I would definately recommend Star Trek Online over this.

reviewText: Ok. So at first this game was awesome. Completely open world, you can be anything you want, pirate, bounty hunter, trader, explorer, the list goes on. Combat and travel is also great, really makes you feel like your in space doing what you want to do and answearing only to you. After you get over the iniatial HOLY CRAP! factor thats when it gets maddening. Even with a decent starter ship (mine was the Viper after i got rid of the default Sidewinder) with good upgrades you really cant do a whole lot until you get a mid to medium high tier ship. This applies to all career choices. For instance my Viper could only take on at most a cobra and if there were 2 enemies it was iffy to beat them if they were decent low to low-mid ships. This also restricted the kinds of missions I could take. So i didnt get very many decent paydays. So final reccomendation? ONLY get this game if you have the patience to grind for several months to get to the mid tier ships.(may be shorter or longer depending on how much time you have and how good you are at the game) After that you'll probably love it.
