reviewText:
Theres a lot of anger being thrown around because of this game and it's developers; Namely the way you pay for the game. It goes thusly -

People bought the original E:D for £40, and with that came an entire years worth of updates. After that year ended, you had to pay an extra £40 for another year of updates. The first years worth of updates is called E:D, and the second years worth of updates is called E:DH. The yearly updates in 2017 will be called something different. And so on.

Now here comes the fun bit. Because E:DH builds on E:D, and therfore includes everything from E:D, people are viewing this entire thing as shafting the original customers, all for different reasons. Some don't see it as paying for yearly updates, they see it, understandably, as having to pay twice for the same content. Technically they're not, they're buying content that hasnt been created yet - however this new 'yet to be created' content also comes with everything they've already paid for - and brings with it the illusion that they're buying an 'expansion pack' with little additions for a full £40.

Some other people realise that the people that pay £40 for a much later version of the game (say, the one coming AFTER Horizons) will get much much more 'bang for their buck' than the people who, up till that point, have had to pay £120 in total for each version.

Personally, im not angry - its a horrifying way to sell your product, but all in all, I can't get angry because the game is absolute turd-pancake anyway; It stretches for miles and miles, but the depth of the game is an inch thick. It doesnt matter much to me where i am in the universe, because the missions are the same, the ships are the same, it all looks and feels the same.

Maybe - MAYBE - after all this is done, and the game has many many years of additions added to it, it will be worth exploring, worth playing. As is, I'm not paying another £40 to find out.

reviewText:
I was so happy having a new Elite as it was a love between me and that Original game I had on Amiga.

But this isn't 1980's anymore and the new Elite feels empty, so empty it comes to massive botherdom... Fly from 1 station  to another trading or killing a few ships on the road and that's it. grinding until you next upgrade or ship and start over... Their is no soul, no campaign, no story it is a empty boring Universe.
Each planet has just one station and you see over and over agin the same station, Just the name changes. even the Welcome text in each station is exactly the same, Funny how thousands of stations have the same paint falling of in the word Welcome and all have the same color....
No external views and the combat is just awfull flying in circle trying to follow the ship.
The bounty hunting is to flat and repetitieve it is to cry for....
Jumping on the sun on each jump over and over again is getting seriously annoying, infact each system is a copy and paste of another one, just less or more planets.

Can't go on planets, like in Elite 2 but hey wait they just announced that you will be able to go one some planets soon but as a 45 $ dlc... If this game was good and had full of features already sure I would agree. But in This half baked state (beta state) it is not even a good game. Train simulator or flight simulator is 10 times more fun and challenging. I am amazed how bad this even ended up and they gone make you pay for all their changes... kickstarters who helped them to make a new Elite and being backstabbed this way is really  low. The planet landing should be free. Only thing we received is the awfull Power Play.
It's a pity because I was so happy to have a new Elite, but it end up to be a greedy unfinished game. Very Sad

Guild Wars 2 Came with same pricing lately, but at least that game is great and full of content, can be boring sometimes if you play too much but nothing compared to this.

reviewText: I was first so excited to be playing this game. The little noises here and there. The hums the ship would make as you turn. But then... that was it. Sure you could go and play 100 hours so you can finally shoot someone and not die in a couple hits, but why? The game is so boring. I mean...really boring. At first, you're captured by this whole new world with all these ships and all these systems to travel to, but each one...is the same...The same. Sure it's a different color but in all reality, its the same. I even paid $60 for the game because I believed in this game and I believed Frontier would do the right thing and make it a better game with more ships, more mission variety, but no. Instead, for all the people that are paying for this game right now, they will get the finger because all of the cool stuff Frontier keeps emailing you about, the plantery landing and the other updates, you have to pay another $60 in order to get that. I'm sorry what? I spent all this money and my time to try and make this a better game and now I'm just left to rot unless I pay another $60? I am so dissappointed and just frustrated beyond relief. Like our parents have said at one point in our lives, I'm not mad at you [Frontier]

reviewText:
As others have said, it's a grindfest. There is a lot less to do in this game than it seems. I played for hours straight at first, and then quickly got to that point where there was nothing new to do except grind for money to buy a new ship and upgrades in order to grind for more money. It's hard to find other people to play with so it's like I'm just grinding all alone in deep space with nothing but shallow AI all around me.

And now, I find out that the one cool thing I was looking forward to -- planetary exploration -- will be introduced as less-than-half complete and for a lot of money, and the start of a trend of expensive mini DLC upgrades.

Considering how long I played before quitting out of boredom versus how much I paid, it just wasn't worth it.

reviewText:
I loved this game I still ♥♥♥♥ing do but hey do you want the expansion that adds super cool ♥♥♥♥? SORRY BUY THE WHOLE DAMN GAME AGAIN! NO THANK YOU! You have forever lost a customer for the ♥♥♥♥ business model you guys have went with. Is it so hard to just release an expansion for the damn game without it being a standalone game each year?!

The game is damn amazing I'm telling you I LOVE SPACE GAMES and this game is just beautiful the settings and options are top notch everything you'd want to see is there. The audio is great but you know dull as well because you know deep space not much sound out there. Exploring is awesome, grab a mate or two go out have some fun... hell bounty hunting with friends is so damn fun I love it. THE FIRST TIME YOU START UP A SHIP OMG THE FEELS THE GOD DAMN FEELS... then trying to get it out without ♥♥♥♥ing up oh my I wish I could go back to that, I can say the game does have a fun learning curve, oh and when you nail down how to use hyperdrive my god does the game feel amazing!

Now the bad stuff... first off the game almost has zero content you will play it for like 10-20 hours then realize it's the same damn ♥♥♥♥ for the rest of your life. The ships are so damn overpriced I might as well grow old before I even attempt to buy one of the end game ones. It's grindy as ♥♥♥♥ when you get down to it not even in a fun mmo way it's just lame and annoying. The tutorials were meh not that helpful you get more info out in the inter webs than you do in game. If it's not enough that you have to be ♥♥♥♥ with your business model you had to go and have the nerve to add mircotransactions to the game... what do you think I am a cow that milks money?!

All in all I love the game but since the developers went that route I'm gonna say no to this game till the end of times until they fix and change their expansion business model that and now I'm left with a great game with almost no content... thanks guys really you didn't screw me over at all!

Edit: I'm glad to see that they have fixed this expansion problem but in no way will I change my review to good just yet... I finally see a reason to start playing the game again but since it's all unfinished work I will wait till a sale for the expansion. This is how an expansion should be and always will be for every other game... please stick to this way and never I repeat never go back to that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t standalone piece of ♥♥♥♥ you were doing before! At least in my eyes you have won me back as a player but not as a customer, also now I can finally reccomend this to other players to try just the base game since no one is going to get screwed over by your business model anymore. Honestly thank you for fixing it, it takes alot for a company to make good on their mistakes and this is just one step further... keep on working and you might win my trust back forever!

reviewText:
One of the first games I dared to pre-order. Was not one of the backers though! However, seems like it was one of the best decisions I've made so far when it comes to pre-orders (Played over 1000 hours already, easily).  Is it good? Is it worth your time and money? Yes and no, depends what kind gameplay you're expecting from something as huge as elite dangerous. A game with over 400 billion star systems ain't really something you come across everyday.

Big it might be but how about the actual content? Is there always something for you to do in game or are you just going to wander around all the time? See this the interesting part about the game, there is -always- something you can do in elite dangerous though it doesn't really tell you what. There's trading, being a pirate, bounty hunting, smuggling illegal goods, stealing floating cargo, mining, hunting wanted targets, exploring the ridiculously huge galaxy...a lot of things to be done. How is it lacking content then? Well it's not really...though it's up to you to find that content.

For a starting commander the tutorials might seem extremely confusing but there's a lot of youtube videos which covers the very basic if you find it hard to get into the game. I must say though, if you're not into -simulators- elite dangerous is definitely not your game. You need to manually land your ship, manually collect the cargo (Unless you use collector drones), manually do a lot of things! Perhaps that's just one of the many reasons why I love this game so much.

There's also quite the selection of playable ships in the game, nothing OVERLY huge except the anaconda which is basically a freighter instead of a small fighter ship. That said, there's no real big ships to be destroyed in the game either...unless you find one of those high intensity conflict zones with a capital ship jumping in, one of the most amazing things you can find in elite dangerous!

A lot of things are still not in the game so expect this title to grow and grow. Perhaps even someday claiming the spot as my favorite game of all time which is currently Freespace 2. Space simulators are coming back. <3
voteText: 17 of 26 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Some people say its boring, some people say its the most amazing thing ever. My advise is to watch lets play and review videos rather than take my word for it. Personally, i'm happy with the game, it runs well, looks FANTASTIC and it still has a lot of future potential.

However, if you just want a high action space shooter, this isn't for you. This is more for the long haul, for those who want to grow with it. Not that is doesnt have its exciting moments, the battles are great when you get one and knowing that all the hard earned credits are in your cargo hold when you get attacked by pirates is enough to get the adrenaline flowing as there is NO reset button. If they kill you and steal your stuff, thats it, you start again!

Best described as a victim of its own hype, NO game can be as good as the fans and even Frontier's own PR dept say it was (just look at the cinematic videos, the game is NOT like that) however, just because its not fantastic, doesnt mean its still not great.

reviewText:
As of writing this review, I've played for five hours, had no idea what I was doing, and still had fun. As it turns out, my insurance did not cover flying into the sun. But I made up for it when someone pulled me out of warp, threatened to ♥♥♥♥ me, and then tried to attack me. Five minutes into the noob fight I was victorious... just kinda sitting there wondering what to do. I felt pretty proud after I docked successfully on the first try, what with everyone else crashing into the station around me. 11/10 Would explore the sun again.

Edit: Updating this review to reflect the fact that I now have over 60 hours in this game.

On the serious side, this game is a simulator. The reviews both good and negative will tell you that. You're in a space ship, and you do stuff. Your path is your own. Since I've written my original review, the powerplay feature was added. This basically allows players to participate directly in the games evolving story by doing things like completing events and pledging allegiance to leaders. The in-game news, Galnet, has actually featured special player groups and so on. I even saw a story with a guy with a 35 million credit bounty on his head (that is a metric ♥♥♥♥load, for those who aren't aware). As such, I've made it my end game goal to make the front page of Galnet and assasinate the Emperor.

In my time playing in open play (cause I'm not a peasant) I've had plenty of interesting encounters with other players. I've been invited to join wings and go bounting hunting by randoms, I've had chats regarding the situation of the system's economy, and even been sexually harassed. My favorite to date is when a friend and I had just arrived at a star port from a neighboring system carrying a haul of polymers to trade. We noticed a bunch of other players at the port, and decided to mess around in the chat. I proclaimed myself the Billy Mays of polymer salesmen, offering to sell my dank polymers" for only 1999 credits. Only one guy inquired as to what the ♥♥♥♥ I was babbling on about.

12/10 everyone should hang out at Eravate
date: best of the 400 billion star systems."

reviewText:
Elite Dangerous, by itself, honestly feels like an unfinished game now.

It used to be a lot of fun for me to play before they introduced Horizons as a DLC, when in reality it should have been patched into the game as actual content. The least they could have done was not include aspects of the DLC -at all- in the standard Elite Dangerous gameplay, but now I find that I'm stuck with 'Engineer Data' that I can do nothing with (Not to mention getting SHOT AT for having), and a currently useless Planetary Approach addon to my ship. Why do I need these things if Horizons is DLC? Is Frontier trying to imply that I shouldn't be playing without it, and if the answer is yes, then why charge for content I -need- just to play the entire game?

I will be begrudingly purchasing Horizons just so I can stop being frustrated and actually enjoy a game I already paid 60 bucks for, but I'm (very) sadly going to give this a thumbs down for now, if not just for Frontier's poor sales tactics. I'm disappointed, Frontier, and I really wish you hadn't rubbed my nose in this DLC until I felt that playing the game was pointless without it.

reviewText:
Sadly I can not recomend this game. As always I played for several hundred hours before writeing a review.

The game itself isn't a bad game, it has lots of potential, and could one day be great but currently, in it's current state it has some severe limitiations, as well as some severe community issues.

Pros:

- 400Billion star systems ( unfortunately 99.9% of them are empty excpet for the systems around the core player area.)
- Missions
- Factions, and Power play (Pretty neat ideas, though currently very shallow)
- First person Cockpit twitch game
- Few noticibal Bugs.
- Interesting ships to chose from

Cons:

-  As stated above the Star systems are virtually empty (of content) except for the NPC human populated area's which make up less then 1% of the game.

- Very little actual content beyond whats listed above, and that content is very very grindy.

- Toxic Community, a lot of fearmongering about social groups and guilds, includeing the moderators.

- No in game social Structures or guild Support.

- Gustapo Censoring Mods. Especially on the topic of Guilds, a few reads through their posts and it's obvious to see how either you agree that guilds are horrible evil entities bent on ruining all games, or you are a pyria and a black sheep of the community.

I posted a week long debate in this thread for guilds: https://forums.frontier.co.uk/showthread.php?t=166180

Even came up witha brand new mechanic never before seen in an MMO which would fit perfectly with ED's and FD's views on guild managment Here: https://forums.frontier.co.uk/showthread.php?t=174869

As you can see, the post was censored and closed (About an hour after I posted it). Hmm So much for FD's statemtn on We love our playerbases Opinions and Creative ideas!.

I was also banned from the forums when I reported the Mod for censoring the thread and poll

reviewText:
I want to love this game. The production value is outrageous. Every ship has a distinct feel an sound. The scope is massive. Any star you can see as you're flying around, you can visit. The lore is interesting and presented in a kind of passive way through news stories where the player can just choose to ignore it and do their own thing. Elite Dangerous has the frame work of an excellent game. Unfortunately, the experience offers nothing beyond the surface.

The first parts of the game are magical. Docking for the first time is an excellent experience. Grinding to get out of the most basic ship and start to specialize professions is entertaining for the novelty at first. The flight simulation is easy to learn, tough to master. I enjoyed myself a lot at the start. Then I had finally saved up enough money for the ship I wanted. As soon as I had the ship of my dreams, the game took a sharp downturn. There was no more reason to grind for money. So what else is there to do? Not much. The end game content is shallow, convoluted, and designed so that the player is supposed to feel important while not actually doing anything different than the first part of the game. The multiplayer aspect is basically nonexistent without joining a player group. The CQC arena shooter style mode is fairly lacking balance and functions mostly as a bandaid over the lack of action in the main sandbox mode. They added planetary landings to nonatmospheric planets as part of the Horizons season dlc, but it's confusing, poorly optimized, and offers little different from the main experience. Until recently, multiplayer features essentially didn't exist and what they have now isn't great.

I can't help but feel that this game should be in early access. So many of the systems are unimplemented, unfinished, and shallow. The pricing structure until recently was absurd especially to early adopters like myself. It's unfortunate because Elite Dangerous in 5+ years might be so much deeper and fully fleshed out. As of right now, I can't reccommend paying anywhere close to full price for a game you'll likely stop enjoying after you put in a bunch of hours.

reviewText:
This is my third revision, and final review:

Yes, this game is pretty.  Yes, it's massive, and is supposed to simulate the entire Milky Way galaxy (altho, currently only contains a tiny fraction of the 400 billion" star systems that it will eventually have according to the devs).

However
date: the ships I've tried maneuver like they are stuck in mud
hoursPlayed:
and I was flying one of the more agile ships available.

There is a "solo" mode where you can play by yourself which was fine for me as the game universe is so big that it seems unpopulated when playing in "open" mode.

Docking at stations is tedious and you are time limited after requesting docking permission and if you haven't docked in that amount of time
voteText: you get attacked.  Or if you "hit" the station by accident too many times

The more interesting hunt/kill missions are nearly impossible because the locaiotn is simply "space" in a particular system and the few times I mananged to fnd my target

reviewText:
ED looks good and sounds good. It's polished and the UI is slick.

But as I played, I realised that little has changed since I played Frontier: Elite 2 way back in the mid-90s. Sure, there's more complexity in systems in ED, but the mechanics are the same. Shoot there, trade here, transport this package to someone, somewhere. To what end? More credits?

Unfortunately, I just can't see the lasting appeal. I've been spoiled by The Witcher 3, which is massive, but there's a world there with stories and people. Humanity. Humanity that is lacking in ED to the point where it just seems like a waste of my time.

Glad I got it in the sale otherwise I would have forced myself to squeeze more out of it. As it stands, I cut my losses and uninstalled.

reviewText:
I want to be able to recommend this game.  But frankly I can't, with the state of the game at the moment.

Here are the good things it's massive when you fly around you get the immensity of space.  The distances are staggering the way they have done the transision from going from warp" to sublight is well done.  The ship designs are enjoyable and interesting.  The systems as they are pretty cool.  Landing your ship successfully for the first time is a triump that is an experience I think everyone should have.  When you get into a fight it's exiting and fast paced.  Knowing when you jump out is an important skill any pilot will need.

This is unfortunately where the enjoyment starts to end.  The deisgn is for it to feel like your in the cockpit and they do this well.  But once you've enjoyed flying around awhile and delivered your umpteenth delivery of foodpacks.  You start to see the thinnest of this game.  You really only have two things to do
recommended: or be a trader and run goods around.  What about mining?  Well that is so poorly done that almost no one does it.  The design for mining is horrible and after you spend two hours trying to collect 10k worth of minerals to find you friend made 400k bounty hunting you'll understand it is pointless.    In any case this quickly becomes a bore that leaves you wanting more.  on top of this the utterly steep learning curve is going to drive many players away as you really need to commit 10+ hours before you start have really an idea of how to play.\n\nI could of forgiven these short comings with the idea they are going to continue developement
hoursPlayed: but it it's now they are already pushing paid expansions.  Frankly this game isn't finished into something that is fun and emersive.  It's shallow and leaves you wanting so much more.  Many in time there will be some meat on this but for know unless you really want a space sim and are willing spend many hours on getting the hang of this
voteText: it's probably not the game for you."

reviewText:
PVP Enthusiasts Beware! Over 600 hours clocked prior to being available on Steam.

Well It may be called Elite: Dangerous, but the main player base is far from Elite" and the NPC's are definitely far from "Dangerous"

Where to start?! I won't talk about the game as such in this review I will only do my best to articulate as best as I can how bad the PVP has been deployed in this game. They may as well had left it out of the game as I think it was only added to appeal to the small player base that wanted it.

Here's whats wrong... Players can switch between Solo (Singleplayer) and Open (Multiplayer) mode as and when they want
date: this adds a few issues when it comes to players who play in Open mode and prefer the Danger (As suggested in the games title) that another players could just attack from nowhere. This does happen however
recommended: but if you happen to go through the players shields like a hot knife through butter
hoursPlayed: said player will then use his skill of keyboard commands and ALT + F4 their ♥♥♥ out of there.\n\n9/10 Traders will also make use of this easily preventable exploit that Frontier make numerous excuses as to why this hasn't been fixed. You can report these players but this litterally amounts to nothing
voteText: its a waste of time doing it not to mention you will do it for just about every fight with another player that starts to lose.\n\nThinking of being a pirate? Think again you will find this the most time wasting career choice in the game
helpfulPercent: you will spend time tracking down the very few players brave enough to do trading in Open mode. Only for them to do the above and combat log the minute you rip them out of FSD (Light speed)
votesHelpful: you are given tools to track players in this game such as the "Wake Scanner" which is totally pointless. It's pointless because traders will simply combat log and move into Solo to continue their journey with no risk of a player attacking them and with the AI being so bad they can even do their trading without weapons and even shields!\n\nThese players who play Solo will reap all the same benefits in Open
votesTotal: despite Solo being faceroll easy. Open in this is simply a sales gimmick the developers put in to persuade PVP enthusiasts. It will mention powerplay! This is broke by design since its impossible to defend an area from an opposing factions players since a good portion of them are in Solo. One could argue that the game is instanced so you would not be able to defend against them all anyway
votesFunny: but then I could argue that I could have a clan to guard the same area covering most if not all instances.. This is not possible due to the design choice of allowing Solo to manipulate the universe in Open.\n\nIf you like Trading or Exploring
commentsCount: this is the game for you.. Granted as an Explorer you will find yourself seeing the same few variants of procedurally generated texures for most planets and stars."

reviewText:
I enjoy this game quite a lot, but I simply cannot recommend it. The reason can be summed up in a single sentence:

Lack of content

It has been an oft-stated criticism of this game on Reddit and many other websites that the game is a mile wide and an inch deep, and my play of it has confirmed this. I have waited since late 2013 for this game to roll out enough content to be worthwhile and purchased a HOTAS setup specifically for it. I still don't think it's worth the money.

Elite has a few things it does right:

- Fun, skill-based combat
- Unique, specialized ships
- Excellent sound design
- Good if not great graphics
- Incredible universe (400 billion stars!)

There's also something to be said about how immersive the game feels, the world is built with an exceptional internal logic. For example, landing at stations requires permission and a careful approach with your ship to an assigned landing pad. It feels like you're really taking a spaceship in for a landing and can screw up and crash easily.

There are other elements that help this immersion along. Ship subsystems can fail and require a restart. You can and more likely than not will run out of fuel at the worst moment and get stranded. If you crash into another ship or station it can blow out your spaceship's glass canopy, leaving you running on a few minutes of oxygen and gasping for air until you get to a station. There are loads of touches like that throughout the game.

The simple fact is though that beyond all these great little details and features, there simply isn't much to do in the game.

Here are some of the worst offenders:

- Half-baked background simulation"  -

The game doesn't actually allow you to cause surpluses and shortages in the economy
date: a developer has to do it. There are "community events" where players can help build a new space station but this only happens if a developer allows it. A vast majority of the game's "simulated" events are actually started and maintained by the development staff and not a result of simulation. This is inexcusable when games like EVE and the X series run full simulations that allow players the ability to affect the simulation any way they want. System populations don't shift unless a developer changes them
recommended: so a protracted war or tons of slave smuggling does nothing unless they change populations manually
hoursPlayed:
you get the idea.

- No module or weapon progression -

Each ship can be fitted for different tasks
voteText: which is awesome
helpfulPercent: but there are only a small handful of modules and ALL of them can be purchased from stations. Weapons also come in only 2-3 varieties and then get more expensive the more DPS you want
votesHelpful: but you can buy it all. There's no rare black market modules to hunt down
votesTotal: no "loot" in hidden space wrecks
votesFunny: no specially-branded modules that have cool features/looks. There is no crafting either
commentsCount: you just earn enough money and buy whatever you want until you have the max class/rank for each.\n\nYour equipment choices are: gatling cannon fixed
column16: gattling cannon gimballed (it turns a little)
column17: gattling cannon turret\n\nCopy/paste this for maybe 4-5 types of weapons (cannons
column18: lasers
column19:
railguns) and make higher DPS cost more and that's it. No special features of any kind.

- Poor economic simulation

Sure
column20: you CAN be a trader
column21: but once you find a profitable route
column22: it will never change because the simulation is static
column23: you can run the same route forever and it will still be profitable. This makes dynamic
column24:
interesting trading impossible because you're just hauling things from one place to another instead of dynamically seeking shortages and surpluses.

- No engaging PVE content -

You will not destroy a station
column25: you will never be part of an intense assault on a pirate outpost
column26: aliens will not invade your system and make you fight for your life. The enemies all pilot the same ships as players (more or less) and are found
column27: predictably
column28: either at special instances or in asteroid fields. The enemies don't "drop" or provide anything of interest
column29: all they provide is money so you can buy better versions of ship parts you already have.\n\nIf you form a multiplayer group (wing) you can find instances where you can get into dogfights with a handful of enemies
column30: this is fun
column31: but it carries no reward or depth besides just more money.\n\n- Shallow

column34: so you'll see the SAME 15-20 missions texts on EVERY single mission. There's no narrative
column35: no choices
column36: no multiple-mission structure
column37:
no unique mission-specific areas.


- Summary -

This game is not complete
column38: to be completely honest after waiting longer than a year for it to become complete I don't think it ever will be. The developers recently introduced "Powerplay" which allows you to enlist and help a major galactic power. However
column39: as with everything else
column40: the stories

column44: which pays a measly salary that pales in comparison to what you can get trading the never-changing profitable trade routes.\n\nI said before this game has great potential

reviewText: I only have about twenty hours in this game and I thought it was going to amazing at first. And it was. But as I got over the nooby euphoria of it all I saw the true barebones of this game. Elite Dangerous has a massive scope in terms of size but very little content to actually coincide with it. You'd be better off playing Eve Online and using your imagination to compensate for the lack of a cockpit just to get some content or meet other players. As a player you feel like you have very little control or impact in this galaxy with 400 billion systems. The game is polished in terms of graphics but that'll only carry it so far. I hope they address some of these issues but until them I will not be playing Elite Dangerous.

reviewText:
NO.

You buy a shallow a game. You think it's an investment. They promise more content. They deliver more content, but you got to buy the game again. People are into the game (recently purchased) defend developers. Developers feel comfortable with their decision. People who defend it leave. New people come in, defend game. And the cycle continues.

It's a subscription where you pay full price of a game over again although the content is lacking. You get the new content, you have to pay full price again for another game". Buying this game you are supporting that behavior."

reviewText: Ive reviewed this game prior to this and given it ok reviews. After quite a few hours in it, Ive had to re-evaluate.  Truth is, its just too damn grindy. The game has real potential. Its fun in the beginning until you realize that you are just a big ole punching bag not only for those that want to make their living pirating the lil guy. (I suspect they are making up for other shortcomings). But the NPC pirates that actually have the ability to defy the physics that you are bound to.  Amazing graphics for the price, but it gets real draggy trying to get ahead and get that big ship no one wants to f**k with. Im afraid I would not recommend this game if you actually want to accomplish something.  But if flying around aimlessly trucking a few cannisters around and hoping you can offload for a profit is your thing, buy it!

reviewText:
I've played many space combat flight sims in the past and I think that this game combines many of the gameplay mechanics from some of the greats.  I've played all of the X-Wing series games including X-Wing Alliance, Freespace 2, and Freelancer immediately come to mind.  I believe that Elite: Dangerous builds off of the best of these games by having a well balanced approach to the following:

* Open world spanning a model of our real-life galaxy.  You can travel to the galactic core, fly around nebulas, fly inside the rings of planets, fly inside the corona of stellar bodies, and more (oh, and you can make money by doing so!!!).

* Ability to FULLY customize the weapon and system loadouts of each ship.  You can take the cheapest ship and make it fill many different roles (trading, bounty hunting etc.), but each ship has its own strengths and weaknesses that make it great for a couple roles and less than perfect for others.  Some ships like the Cobra Mk. III are multipurpose and let you change out components easily without having to constantly trade out ships.  You are never locked into a role like in other mmo's or RPG games where classes form the basis for gameplay (tank/heal/DPS).

* Its almost like each ship is a unique person:  Real" feeling flight model that is different for each ship.  Each ship has hardpoints and cockpits that require a unique approach to dogfighting
hoursPlayed: escaping
voteText: etc. per ship.\n\n* The combat in this game is amazing and isn't always about "who brings the most power to the fight" (unless you play solo or are fighting one-on-one
helpfulPercent: then its about power and balance).  Fighting on a team with other NPCs or players means finding that unfilled need in the fight and taking advantage of it.  Its often about fighting SMART and about fighting HARD.  You'll think about approach vectors and team tactics on top of managing your own ship systems when you've gained experience.\n\n* You have the option to play in "Solo Play"
votesHelpful: "Private Group"
votesTotal: or "Open Play."  Be warned that an active connection to their servers is always required.  This makes sense since even solo play is fully synchonized for events and trade data for all players.  This means that if players are competing for a resource in a station
votesFunny: then going to solo mode isn't a way to cheat the system
commentsCount: but a way to isolate your interaction with other players.\n\nOkay this game is amazing.  'Nuff said."

reviewText:
I just want to say that I really wanted to recommend this game, but I just can't in its current state. I preordered the game and was really excited for what this game had to offer and for a while I was having a great time. However, after your 500th time jumping into hyperspace or docking at a station, it definitely loses its appeal.

To be fair, since launch they have added some features and content which brought me back for a while but at its core nothing had really changed much.

Starting with the pros:
The game looks incredible. There is nothing like having a first-person view from inside your cool ship while you fly into a giant space station or drop out of warp speed and see a giant blue star in front of you. Flying through an asteroid field while dogfighting with space pirates makes you feel like you're watching a blockbuster movie and smuggling illegal goods into a spaceport gives you a Han Solo-esque feeling.

The sounds and music are pretty nice and give the universe a good atmosphere.

There are lots of options. The controls are completely customizable for keyboard and controllers and the game supports all kinds of flight sticks from what I've seen online which is nice.

The content that is released currently is quite polished and runs well (except for a few long load times here and there). I have a laptop with a midrange graphics card and I can still get 60fps at 1080p so I appreciate how optimized it is. They must have some crazy quality assurance testing too because I haven't run across a single bug that I can remember.

Bounty hunting is probably the best part of this game and is something fun you can actually do with friends in this game.

Now for the cons:
Once you get past the awesome visuals and smooth gameplay, there honestly isn't much left. I've tried long enough in my opinion (about 70 hours at the time of this review) to find something in here to get me to keep playing but I just can't find it. If I had to choose a few words to sum up my experiences over the last year or so of owning the game, it would be: be prepared to grind.
To get anything cool in the game (bigger ships, better guns and equipment, etc.) it requires an absurd amount of credits which are stupidly hard to earn. Since the launch of the game they have added more varied missions with increased payouts but it simply isn't enough to be worth your time. I know a lot of people have said this but I have found it to be quite true: this game is a space trucking simulator.

Trading
The  only  way to make a reasonable amount of money in this game is trading which is excrutiatingly boring and time consuming. In addition, the market system is quite weak, especially when you compare it to a game in a similar category like Eve Online. In Eve you can manufacture and sell your own goods, place buy and sell orders, and actually have a good time at trade hubs where you can feel like you're on Wall Street or something. Elite doesn't even come close to this in terms of complexity. Based on the system you are in, they demand and supply certain goods (with either low, medium, or high amounts of supply/demand)...that's it. The goods you are trading have absolutely no effect on your ship or progress in the game and you can't even buy or sell ship equipment like you'd expect. Additionally, there is no way to view surrounding market information without flying your ship over to the adjacent system and writing down the prices with pencil and paper which is very frustrating. You can try to use online trading tools but they frequently are outdated and don't give reliable information.

Mining
If you think picking up rocks for an hour is fun, then this should be in the pros list for you. Mining in Elite is tedious and unrewarding from my experience. You have to spend large amounts of time looking for a suitable place to start mining and even then when you start mining it's pretty much based on chance. You shoot your mining laser at a rock until a little piece breaks off and usually it is some crap mineral that sells for nothing, then you have to go fly over and pick it up without accidentally crashing into it and breaking it. Then once you have enough little rocks you can refine it into 1 unit of some mineral. So you can spend an eternity mining and make like 5000 credits. When you buy a mining laser it should come with a free handgun so you can blow your brains out once you realize how much time you've wasted.

Doing Missions
You'd think, being a sci-fi MMO, that Elite would have some awesome quests that involve stopping the alien threat in the galaxy, destroying the home base of a warlord space pirate, and building up a faction to conquer all other factions, right? Well you were so wrong. There are no alien invasions, no evil space conglomerates, and no way to build your own space stations to house your freedom fighters. Instead you get to fly to a station and choose from 10 generic missions (75% of which are locked because of your level) from some faction that nobody cares about. These missions are usually either: deliver a message, deliver some cargo, or kill some pirates...oh boy. These missions also range in difficulty and reward levels:
Low risk - Low reward
Medium risk - Low reward
High risk - Low rewardThe developers seem to want to artificially extend your length of playtime by giving you jack squat for your time and effort. This is unfortunate because it means I will never be able to experience everything the game I paid $60 for has to offer because I simply can't grind for hundreds of hours to buy the biggest ship in the game which I will talk about in the next section.

Getting Money
Its pretty sucky to say that I will never be able to fly the biggest and coolest ships in the game because I refuse to spend 200 hours grinding missions and trading when I'm not enjoying it. To make it worse, the developers, for whatever reason, don't want players to make any reasonable amount of money in a reasonable amount of time. Any time there is a whiff of a money-making opportunity they nerf it. For example, recently you could make a good amount of money (for me around 2 million credits in an hour) by flying hundreds of lightyears to the edge of colonized space and collecting highly illegal cargo and ferrying it to the inner systems. It wasn't a get-rich-quick scheme though because while you have the cargo you are being chased by cops and pirates and it takes a long time to travel the hundreds of light years (around 700 round trip) since you can only warp about 25-30 at a time. But of course, as soon as I start doing this I hear that they are going to nerf it, just like they have nerfed every other way to make money in the game. Just to give you some perspective, if I were to make 2 million credits per hour by doing this, it would take me approximately 104 hours to buy the biggest ship in the game, and that doesn't include any upgrades, so double that time. I'm sorry Frontier but playing" your game isn't my full-time job. And remember they are going to nerf these quests

reviewText:
Fanboys are crying right now at the sight of a NEGATIVE review. But, the God's honest truth is that this game just isn't worth the cash in your wallet.  It's grindy, probably on purpose, but there's little to be enjoyed once you've established yourself.

Good Stuff:
- Graphics are top knotch.  No gripes here.  It looks great.  Bases look well designed and believable.  The ships have great detail, albeit, they all look clunky and odd.

- Docking.  It's a small matter, but I love that I can dock my own **** ship.  Thank you for not resorting to cutscene style docking.  There's auto-dock modules for those who get tired of slapping their ship into the side of the station.

- Dog fighting is fun* (see Bad Stuff).  Through Interdiction (being pulled out of sub-light speed), or just passing by, the AI is challenging and is attempting to kill you and evade you, as expected.

- In-game menu's are clever, being implemented as screens within your ship.  Kudos to cleverness

- Maps are well designed.  Maneuvering the galaxy is easy.

- You can make money by exploring and wandering around, then selling it systems that are far enough away.  Pretty cool way to make money that doesn't involve lasers or trading.

- Bounty Hunting is fun.  Unfortunately, it's not very profitable.  An hour of this will probably net you around 200K space bucks.  Which sounds like a lot, until you get to the level where you're flying a Cobra.

Bad Stuff:
- Travel.  It takes a good chunk of time to reach certain places. They opted for a bit of realism here as some of the places that are 10K Ls (Light Seconds) away take several minutes of flying through an otherwise bland chunk of open nothingness with nothing to do in the meantime.  Generally speaking, places this far away tend to have somewhat desireable goods.  Ultimately, they're not worth the time spent doing nothing.

- Heaven forbid, I tried to go faster to cut down on travel time and I've overshot my approach to a destination.  I now need to pull a U turn" to get back there and approach at the speed of a snail (though I'm told I'm actually moving thousands of meters per second!).  Where the heck is my auto-approach module?  We are in the future

reviewText:
Dont waste your money on this garbage. I have low play time due to not buying it on steam i only got steam key recently i bought this game before release.

Graphics are nice etc but game is terrible. Huge huge game but its the exact same content copy and pasted over and over and over and over. Every place you go looks the exact same there is almost no content in this game, just the small few bits of content copy and pasted a few billion times.

Wherever you travel its just the same same same same. Its ridiculously slow and boring which might be forgivable if it wasnt the same thing over and over and over again.

When I originally bought this game i enjoyed it for a small few hours and then it was just the same over and over. I literally felt robbed. It was a con much worse than destiny which is another piece of junk con but this is actually wrose than destiny somehow. Developers made all this talk about the future of the game so I accepted this and thought well at least it will get good eventually. How foolish of me how could i believe that this would be a one time con that would eventually be worth it.

The improvements" to this empty shell of a game are going to be sold in expanisions. So basically they released a game with nice graphics and plenty of potential which was empty
recommended: nothing in it and then  they decide to sell the rest of the game to you in bits. Except for the graphics this game is emptier than an early access title but at least with early access (in most cases) you actually recieve the rest of the game as part of your initial purchase. With this destiny style sales plan they will sell you the game in pieces over the span of a few years or as long as they can keep suckers on the hook.\n\nA lot of people will rip me apart for this review because there will always be a subset of people who like that kind of thing but also because some people need to justify themselves

true believers etc.

This game is junk. It should be called the emporers new clothes just like destiny. Maybe one day when all the content has been put in after a few years and when its sold as one product at a low price it might be worth it then but id say until that day comes if it ever does avoid this like the plague.

reviewText:
I'm both impressed and not impressed...

Pros:
emersive 3d environment
stunning space" visuals
great ship mechanics

Cons:
Cumbersome hyper drive that often over shoots targets.
No way points for missions that require rendezvous...this often makes you lose missions by not being able to contact certain npcs.
No planet fall unless you get paid expansion...even with paid expansion all planets are lifeless/pointless.
No ship customization without paid expansion...which is a cheap way to siphon money out of customers...ie they should look at how cryptic/arc has structured Star Trek Online people still pay for things but have unfetterd customization and gameplay.

Overall disappointed as a first level pilot I have already accrued 100s of 1000s in debt due to player kills and high level npc player kills on first level missions making it nearly impossible to move forward not to mention the multiple deaths that occured before I learned about feul scoops and how its suicide to leave a port without one...lol"

reviewText:
I had bought this game when it was in Beta for 60 euros, despite all the mixed and negative reviews at that time that all of them was saying that the game was shallow and didn't have much content, but I believed that Frontier and Braben weren't lying when they were saying that all the promised content will soon be available.
Well, after all that time from Beta and seeing the game being sold for 15 euros just a few days ago and the Expansion being sold twice the price of the game and also selling DLC, a bobblehead and some paint jobs for 15 euros, which was the price of the full game, there is no doubt that Braben and Frontier were lying from the beginning and were going for the money.
The game is an empty sandbox, with no real multiplayer, no goals, nothing at all, just grinding for money and better ships and repeating meaningless fights against AI.
You can't play with friends due to the useless multiplayer system, even if you form a party with a friend, you just get lost in the way to a waypoint, your friend may end up to a different instance and search each other for 20-30 minutes.
Braben and Frontier are liers, do not give them money, they are money grabbers,just like Roberts and Star Citizen.They disgraced the brilliant games they once made.
If you want good space fighting games, then buy the old wing commander games or Freespace 2, which is the best space fighting game made in my opinion.
voteText: 14 of 21 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
First of all I'd like to say ED is a really cool game; the basic mechanics around flight, trading, mining, etc are all sound.  The graphics and effects are great, all-in-all I'd say the game is quite well executed.

The problem for me is the universe is completely dead outside the initial region of space where you start.  What is the point of having an entire galaxy to explore if there is nothing to do when you get there???  Seriously, every station in the entire game is located within 400 ly of Sol which is a tiny fraction of the explorable space.

The only thing you can do beyond that is explore... fly around.  Sure you can spend hours hauling your miner out to some cool undiscovered system, and if your lucky you can fill your cargo hold with precious metals, cool right?  Not cool, because now you have to spend hours hauling your miner back to a system with a station in order to sell that cargo.  Spending hours (real life time) doing a hundred jumps to make one cargo run is the opposite of fun in my opinioin.

I can't help but feel disappointed and frustrated by having an entire galaxy at my fingertips yet essentially being restricted a very limited region of space in which to fully play the game.  Sure, it's understandable for deep space to be initially empty, but the lack of any mechanism which can alter that state over time is the single reason this game will never get anywhere remotely near the hundreds of hours I logged in X2 and X3.

How can I be vested in a game of such epic scope and possibility if I can't build my own empire?  My only goals are to have a collection of ships and a large bank account?  Sorry, that's not enough for me.  If that's enough for you then please do support the developer and buy it because as I said at the start it really is a cool game.

And yes, I know the game is still in development, but the last I heard the devs had ruled out the inclusion of things like player owned stations.  Until something is done which adds life to 99% of the traversable galaxy this game will remain not worth the money despite its incredible potential - and I bought it on sale for $19.99

BTW, there are many very simple implementations of player bases or other interesting mechanics which would address this problem.  For example, giving each player the ability to purchase (at great expense) a single simple space dock, and be able to relocate that space dock as needed (also at great expense) to act as a forward operating base would completely open up the galaxy.  This would allow all the activities occuring in the core systems to now extend out into the reaches of deep space while at the same time prevent the spamming of abandoned player stations that would surely occur if you let everyone create multiple bases or create them at minimal cost.
voteText: 14 of 21 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText: This is not a game for everyone, with that said if you like immense open world gamplay with no direction at all with the freedom to play how you want in the sandbox then you should check this out. If you have played the Xwing/TiE Fighter series you'll be able to pick up the basics of the flight model very quickly. Learning the art of supercruising will be new, but it's fun and rewarding. Exploration, trading, privateering, hauling, smuggling, pirating, bounty hunting, assassination and mining are all viable paths to take. With more content coming, this game is a must buy for genre fans and worth the asking price. Did you like EvE but didn't feel like giving half your life away to enjoy it? Did you want to actually fly the ships? Then ED is for you.

reviewText:
I had high hopes for this game. Unfortunately, Frontier Development has opted to aim for our money instead of fixing and improving Elite, and so each year, if you want upgrades, you have to buy the game again. This winter is Season one Horizons, with planetary landings, coming at a full 50 euro price. Next year the same with something else. And the original game in the meantime is lacking in a lot of respects, enjoyable only if you like repetitive activities, like trading.

In your case I wouldn't buy it now, and wait for Horizons at least, or even a few more years to see if they keep their promise regarding general game improvements.

I simply can't recommend it now, and I feel like I made a big mistake that I bough it.

reviewText:
I wrote a review of this game a few days after purchase that was extremely negative, but now after a week or two I feel a fresh review is needed.

Elite Dangerous is a hugely ambitious (and terribly named) spaceship MMO, which has many good features but also a large number of fatal flaws.  Lets talk about the good points first.  It does, more than any other game I have played, provide an experience that feels as much like flying a spaceship as is possible in a game.  This is in part due to the large number of solar systems, astronomical features in space, but mainly due to the essential joystick control and the cockpit view.  It does in parts have amazing visuals too, getting in close to stars and seeing solar flares erupt off the surface is amazing, as is the detail on the stations as you dock / undock.  Also, the sound effects are very impressive and create a good sense of character in the game.

Now for the negatives.  This is an MMO, but it is so empty.  This is partly due to relatively low player base, but is mainly down to the fact that the game provides no social structure whatsoever (no ability to form guilds or corporations etc).  I am not even sure you can have multiple chat channels with real people.  Also, the overview" which shows you what is around in space is non-existant

reviewText: Elite Dangerous has taken the classic time waster of MMOs, virtual transit time, to an entirely new level of boredom and waste. If you ignore my advice and try this game, you will spend essentially all of your 'play' time crossing the vastness of space. This space is accurately depicted as empty and devoid of interest. You will learn to detest manually decelarating out of hyperspace travel--a lengthy, boring process. You will curse the number of pointless waypoints in even the simplest mission, as each waypoint involves a manually-intensive decelaration that destroys ten minutes if done well or deposits you  years of travel--literally--from your waypoint if you are inattentive. Never mind that any technology that could produce space travel would surely produce technology to automate it. If you must throw away your limited lifespan travelling from one part of empty space to another, at least do so in a game that is less annoying, like Eve. In Eve, at least you don't have to waste ten minutes at every waypoint. I do not recommend Eve, it's a ridiculous waste of time due to the space travel. But this game is 100 times worse than Eve. This game is the ultimate boring timesuck.

reviewText:
Updating this reveiw to best describe E:D as it is now. Frontier have actually added more stuff to the game such is the CQC Championships mode. More sites, more missions, and  AI's that actually have teeth and can be a huge problem if not set up for them. On this note the game is very well done now.

Graphics have been updated, and most connection problems have been fixed.

This game has always had very good graphics.

I wish steam has another option other then just the two. Really, the only reason I can not recommend this game to others on steam now is because Frontier is advertiseing Elite Dangerous as a MMO which is very far from the truth as they are use 32 player island with P2P(Peer to Peer)  connection to host the game. Atmost you will see about 8 to 15 other players at the same time.

Other then that fact this game has came a very long long ways from being very boring to now very exciting depending on what you are doing. If you are ok with only being able to interact with a small group of players at one time instead of the big numbers of players if you are playing any other (MMOs) and have a craving for space then this is you game, till a better one comes along.
Just be forwarned that Frontier will be releasing their DLCs at $60 a pop and this point it looks like they'll be droping one every year or there abouts.

I will not be able to fully recommend this game because of false advertisement.

reviewText:
If there is a word to describe this game it has to be 'lonely'. For a (self-professed) MMO, human interaction is next to nill. More voice acting --a news-reader for instance-- would make it feel less empty. Instead you're asked to read the news (something that pretends to be a story) as a side-thought while in space stations.

There are a lot of elements that are deliberaly tedious... not being able to record system trade prices for instance. It seems your computer has no room left for such functionalty after dealing with space travel.

I want to like this game. But because of a complete lack of visible human communication or organisation it doesn't feel like there is a purpose doing anything in such an empty place.

reviewText:
It didn't take long to see that this wasn't going to be an overly entertaining game. While there's a lot of merit, this game suffers from the unecessarily uneventful travel times to do ... anything really. The combat is fun, nd the game certainly nails immersion but ultimately lacks content especially for its original price tag. Sure, there are a ton of systems, but they don't really offer much. The lack of diversity of anomalies left me feeling like I paid for a demo.

Another problem was that since the activities were kinda dull, the fairly long grind required to get better ships is excruciating. It's possible that by the time you've afforded your dream ship, you've grown tired of the activities you wanted to use it for anyway.

I did enjoy the game for a while ( though requiring music to get me through traveling around eventually as it got dull fast ) and it might be a great game to pick up if you want a reasonably immersive game to pretty much live in for a while. That said if you're not willing to spend a LOT of your spare time just traveling around on your way to more eventful activities Id advise you just skip this game. If your gaming time is very limited, it's probably going to prove too time consuming if you like a wide variety.

reviewText:
Elite has a lot of flaws. There's a lot of grinding, a lot of emptiness, a lot of just staring at your screen not doing anything while you fly to your destination, the in-game tutorials are lacking, major content updates thus far are months apart and add a lot of width but not a lot of depth to the game, and over time it can become quite expensive, controls are less-than intuitive until you make binding changes, griefers are a known issue in Open Play since it's all unrestricted PvP, social aspects in-game are lacking, and to top it all of it punishes mistakes pretty harshly.

Elite is not a game for everybody and has a pretty specific niche appeal. To be honest you either love it, or you hate it. There isn't a lot of in-between with Elite, and unfortunately words in a Steam review can not accurately explain the complexity and subtleties of this game, so you'd really need to go out and look up gameplay videos or streams and just watch the game be played.

All that said, I love Elite to death. It's unique, it's massive, it's engaging, and I can spend hours just flying around taking in the gorgeous sights. It's relaxing, and yet can be extremely intense at times. The simulation of the galaxy is highly accurate and in fact I have made numerous time-lapse videos showing off planets orbiting each other, the rotation of a planet from its surface, the burning gasses swirling around a brown dwarf, and much more. There's a lot of subtle things added in to Elite that you don't even realize unless you're looking for them, and that leaves a lot of things to be discovered. One of my favorite things is that it makes you feel insignificant: you aren't the star of the show, you're just an average joe the 34th century trying to make a living, and the world and stories go on with or without you.

The player-made groups are also a major part of Elite. There's no integrated grouping or guild" system
date: so players are forced to seek out groups on their own
recommended: and when they do the results are fantastic. You get groups like the Fuel Rats who dedicate themselves to assisting players who have run out of fuel by travelling to them and giving them enough to get to safety. Numerous player-run activities like the Distant Worlds expeditions that see dozens of players all travelling across the galaxy together
hoursPlayed: or the Buckyball Racing Club which sets up races for players to win prizes in
voteText: or the newer Demolition Derbies that are being organized where players land on planets and drive their SRV's around in a crater like bumper cars. And then you have all the fan-made things like Radio Sidewinder
helpfulPercent: which plays sci-fi music and general popular songs while adding in custom advertisements for various products
votesHelpful: ships
votesTotal: services
votesFunny: groups
commentsCount: and other things in Elite.\n\nNaturally I should also mention that Elite isn't done being updated yet either. Once per year a paid expansion will come out that will add more content to the game. Horizons (Season 2) has seen landing on airless planets
column16: and will see a character creator
column17: craft/loot
column18: multi-person crews
column19: ship-launched fighters

column21: as well as be able to get out of our ships and engage in FPS combat on foot. The scope of Elite is enormous.\n\nElite is just as much a community as it is a game
column22: and while I wish everybody could find as much enjoyment out of it as I have

reviewText:
Visually gorgeous, accoustically pleasant, amazing flying mechanics. That's it, like a beautiful blonde, once you get used to the eye and ear candy you'll put the game down and move on. Repetetive, grindy. 2 Progression paths:

A) Go to a RES, kill ships over and over until you can afford the next ship. Get next ship, go to a RES, kill ships over and over until you can afford the next ship.

B) Buy commodity A at station 1. Jump systems, go to station 2. Sell commodity A, buy commodity B to bring back and sell at station 1. Continue until you can afford next ship with more cargo.

reviewText:
Korean grindfest general, point of the game is doing the same thing (most likely trading) for hundreds of hours to get a better ship and repeating until you realize it was a complete waste of time and uninstall the game. The space is huge but extremely empty, you can explore new systems with worlds and stars that will all look the exact same as you've already seen and devs charge you 60 bucks to look at rocks from closer, which somehow feels even emptier than space.
Missions are just as empty, they all consist of bringing that to that and maybe blow up a couple ships, and the great majority if not all of them will be blocked to you in the beginning leaving the bounty hunting grinding as your only real choice to proceed in the game.
PvP combat is actually pretty fun but even in the CQC mode it's still extremely based on grinding all day to get better equipment and use it outmanuver your opponent, and in the main game you will be lucky if you get to blow up a ship that isn't an NPC with a bounty.
Player interaction is also minimal, you can't even trade with other players. Game actually encourages you to play solo mode as you will be able to keep all the bounties for yourself, or carry around your cargo with only having to worry about the odd pirate NPC tryng to derail you and make you lose a couple seconds from the great Anaconda quest.
The ship HUD is amazing, that coupled with all the pretty lights you see at space stations is the real reason why this game became somewhat popular but it's definitely not worth the price, thank god I only wasted 12 euros

reviewText: Claims to be an MMO. But the basics of an MMO are missing. Grouping is limited to 4 players and there is no persistent grouping i.e guilds. That is right in a game that is primarily about trading they forgot about trading guilds. The economy is limited to trading with AI only, with no bartering or player to player economy. No player crafting for gathered resources. And there is enviromental zoning, so ungrouped players can be in the same place but not see each other because they are in a different instance of that zone with no options to set a zone preference. I understand that these are design decisions but I feel that they limit the game in such a way that I am left feeling like this is not the way an MMO should be.

reviewText: Where do I start? I've been playing Elite Dangerous since around May of 2015 and have invested around 490 hours into the game (there is an ingame counter considering it wasn't always on steam). I truly love the game but as time goes on I'm very rapidly falling out of love with it for two reasons really.\n\nThe first reason is the developers. Frontier has made something so incredible with Elite Dangerous and just how amazing the game is but when you look at what they've accomplished from the time the game was released" back in December of 2014
date: you'll see why I am hesitant to recommend this game. From Alpha to release the game was stuffed with content updates but when release came around
recommended: the real updates stopped. Sure they put out regular "updates" now but what you don't realize is that a lot of these updates are simply re-skins of the same tasks that need to be done over and over again until you get your next ship. Many people (including myself) enjoy the game immensely because we can make our own path but at the end of the day there are so many paths to make because of how unbalanced the game really is. Certain careers are much more profitable than others which leads to a massive buildup of player population doing one thing. When that happens

voteText:
I could go on for days about random things that bug me about Elite but I'll sum it up:

tl;dr: Elite's devs don't fix any of the major broken ♥♥♥♥ and just keep adding more grinding to the game that already has too much of it.

The second reason that I've fallen out of love with Elite is the community. At first glance
helpfulPercent: they seem like a ton of nice guys that love to help each other out but if you spend a little bit of time on the forums you'll quickly find out that isn't how it is at all. There are two major groups within the community. We have the "carebears" or "forum dads" group which is filled with PvE-centric players that have a combined amount of self entitlement whose mass could give a neutron star a run for its money. On the other hand
votesHelpful: we have PvP centric players or the "griefers" that enjoy killing others which are the minority of players. Carebears hate griefers because they enjoy killing other people and often whine to Frontier to try and make it harder to kill people. You'll often see insane suggestions on the forums such as "when one player kills another the player that killed the other needs to have his save reset". These suggestions are often the result of being killed in Open mode in a shieldless ship. That brings me to my next point. There are three modes within Elite Dangerous. There is Open mode in which you will meet all sorts of people that could be friendly or out to murder you
votesTotal: private groups where you can play with your friends or a bunch of carebears
votesFunny: and solo mode which allows you to play solely with NPCs. What ends up happening is players that have no desire to PvP play in open mode and when a player goes to kill them

reviewText: I like this game in theory.  The universe in which it takes place, its scope, its character, are all quite engaging.  Aside from a handful of glitches, it's a beautiful game on even my modest hardware.  I just can't shake the feeling of tedium and lack of immersion.  There are huge expanses of time which could be occupied researching some sort of whispered lore or negotiating dealings with various seedy personalities en route to the distant reaches of a rogue starsystem-- instead, there are a few shreds of mythology to grasp at and some disemobdied names vaguely attached to political strongpersons who we're instructed to care about, with the occasional loose-cannon-with-a-price-on-his-head thrown in for good measure.  There's no real weight to the universe, despite its size-- There's really nothing unique about any of the locations, and once you've mined/bounty-hunted/interdicted/scanned/cargo-scooped, you soon feel as if you've done it all.  It leaves you feeling lonely, and not in a frontier sort of way.  I'm not saying it's a bad game, but most of it takes place in your imagination when that doesn't need or seemingly want to be the case.  The Horizons expansion seems promising, but the fact that it's essentially a new game purchase seems to render the original Elite: Dangerous obsolete without an obvious reason why other than YOUSHOULDPAYFORTHISOTHERTHING.

reviewText:
Great game

getting shafted for the expansion, however. I paid $59.99 when this game launched with a bunch of different promises (when I say launched, I mean when the BETA was available) . Turns out, some of the promises were cut from the final game (Due to funding issues, which at the time was understandable) and is now being resold in an expansion, which is also $59.99 (although a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ discount for owners of the game).

Fun part: The expansion comes with the base game, thus new players get the entire package for $59.99 whereas older players are essentially paying around $120 ($105 with the ♥♥♥♥ discount). That's a pretty ♥♥♥♥ed business practice when it comes to customer loyalty. Not to mention the expansion isn't coming with everything right away, rather, it's an over priced season pass with content that should have been in the original game.

Now, I'm not mad about them selling the expansion with content that was supposed to be in the base game since Frontier saw some financial issues. However, with the growing popularity of the game, the price point is utter ♥♥♥♥. ESPECIALLY since it ♥♥♥♥s over older players. We have to pay $60 for the same game again, with some added features, new players get an invisible discount since they didn't purchase the base game.

People defending this are saying MMOs do the same thing. You're right, but even then most good MMOs don't charge full game price for their expansion, and if they did, the content is immediate and very extensive (whereas Horizons is neither), doesn't ♥♥♥♥ over current players and favor new ones (which Horizons does). Not to mention when I purchased the game (only late last year) the game was advertised as both singleplayer and multiplayer, not full on MMO focus nonsense.


Honestly the game isn't bad, if a bit bland in a lot of parts (would suggest getting it on sale if you MUST own it) but you're better off getting Horizons for the same price with the full game, which I was not warned would be a thing.

♥♥♥♥ Frontier
The game is okay, otherwise.

reviewText: I got all excited about Horizons.  And that was my fault.  At release I accepted the 10 yr plan.  But after about 6 months I just couldn't get into it.  Powerplay added a new facet to doing missions, but didn't really increase the fun of doing the same mission types I had already been doing.  So I stopped playing but I keep it installed and updated.  From time to time I log in, do some mining, collect a few bounties then log off.  What I was hoping was that the Planetary Landing would provide more variety in the accomplishment of doing things.  Like scouting mining sites for mineral deposits and making money off that.  Or invading territory as a Merc.  But it's just driving around and looking at rocks.  Then someone told me I'd have to pay $50.00  for the expansion.  Not 10, not 20, not 40, but $50.  But if I hadn't bought it at release it would be $50 and include the expansion.  So I'm being charged more for playing your game earlier?  I don't understand.

reviewText:
I love the conscept of this game but one thing is bugging me like hell... Why would spacecraft have to handle like aircraft???
When I've gone into play this game this blew my mind, sure I've played pleanty of space sims and flight sims but in a frictionless (well I'll avoid going into physics too much) environment why would a space craft have the same directional limitations as aircraft? When piloting a ship this means that you have to constantly pitch and roll, this works for aircraft due to being designed for atmospheric flight and having to generate lift, but in space you dont need to worry about lift...

I cant see any reason why the YAW is so gimped. I do think it would enhance the players ability to pilot these ships if they put more power into the ships YAW (turning on the Y-axis for those in the uk).

For this reason alone I'm really bugged by the ships controles, and I find it hard to get comfortable with just about any set up... which I'm really sad about because for me thats a major thing, and I really really looked foreward to giving this game a go... that asside I think for missioning, it would be nice to have an autopilot option... this is not sensible later on in the game unless you'd like to run into situations without any idea of what to expect, but early on it would really help orrient the new players to the game... far more than what the tutorials do.

people may dissagree with me and I accept that, there are some people who wont think about the issues of barely being able have blanced thrust on all 6 degrees of freedom and people who wont think about a new players experience. but for me I do think that these are issues that will cause me not to play even as good as it looks... if there ever look at sorting this out I will happily change my mind because everything else looks awesome!  I love customisable ships and I love the idea of open space. Even if they brought in just one ship that covers some of these points that would make a difference in my oppinion... but seriously... resistance on YAW??? what are the lateral thrusters compensating for that the vetral and dorsal thrusters arent?

reviewText:
TL/WR: In the first week I played for 44 hours. I don't even remember that weekend...

TL/WR2: I NEVER preorder anything. But I preordered the expansion for this...

It's a space game about space ships blowing up other space ships. If you think it looks cool, and you don't mind spending a little bit of time researching a few things on how to play, get it. It appears more complex at first than it really is, once you've got a couple of hours in (and have learned how to do everything you need to) you'll love it.

Some people say there's nothing to do, I say they have no imagination. It's a sandbox, you won't have your hand held while you follow a set story. You make your own story, in a fantastic looking universe, with lots of stuff to trade/shoot/blow up/steal/mine/attack/support/fight...

EDIT: FYI: I bought the game on 23rd September 2015... 13 days ago at the time of writing this... Call it two weeks... 2 weeks, 63 hours... That's more time than I've spent working. I've not been sleeping much... I haven't even played any other games recently, just this. The only reason I'm writing this edit to my review now, is because I can't play the game right now... The servers are offline while they upgrade to the latest update...

EDIT 2: Steam doesn't actually show all the hours I've played. Due to a Steam beta bug (mouse cursor getting stuck in menus), I've been forced to play the game through it's own launcher without using Steam for the last couple of weeks... So you can probably add another 50 or 60 hours ontop of what ever steam is showing.

The steam bug is fixed now, but I keep forgetting to launch it through steam and have been using the keyboard shortcut I created instead...

EDIT 3: It's the 15th of December. The Horizons expansion has just been released.

I preordered it, so will be playing later tonight and will update my review accordingly in the next few days. The fact I preorderd in itself should tell you something about how much I've enjoyed the game so far:

I NEVER preorder anything. But I preordered the expansion for this...

Steam says I have 186 hours in game at the time of writing this. Steam doesn't know how many hours I've put in:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=620662227

My maths could be off, but I'd put that at around 319 hours (so far). 70 or 80 of the missing hours were in Horizons when that was released as a standalone... The rest of them are from playing the game without steam.
