reviewText:
I don't want to write a long drawn out review but I don't know if thats possible.
If you want a space sim where you pilot a craft by yourself and you have a LOT of time to kill then this might be for you.  If you're a normal person with a job and responsibility you won't have time for this game.  There's just not enough gratification for small bursts of play.
Dog fighting is fun but its not a reliable way to make money. Mostly the game just turns into space trucker SIM 2015.  Buy cargo - travel for 20 minutes- deliver cargo - buy more cargo - fly 20 minutes- deliver cargo.  Rinse and repeat.   Traveling is supposed to be part of the fun.  You travel and random anomolies pop up.  This concept really drew me to the game.  The problem is I'm usually traveling to deliver some valuable cargo and these anomolies either lead to combat, in which case I may die and lose my cargo, or they lead to debris you can pick up in which case I can't because my cargo bay is already full.  The game has a lot of neat things. It's very exciting the first time you warp, its very exciting the first time you barely escape a fight with your life, its very exciting the first time you dock your ship, so on and so on, BUT its not exciting the Millionth time you do it.
Lastly, I have to mention the price of this game.  $60 is simply too much for this game.  This is a tripple A game price tag and I don't feel like I got tripple A quality game.  The most obvious example of this is the fact that when you view the ingame tutorials, it actually minimizes the game and takes you to youtube.   Aside from destroying any immersion you may be feeling, its just down right cheap.  To make matters worse, when you grit your teeth and watch the videos, you quickly realize that all of these videos are catered to players with joy sticks.  I found myself abandoning those videos and just looking for player made one instead.
The game also just feels so lonely.  Lots of NPCs floating around and I see players too, but we never interact, except for calling each other names at the space ports while we wait in line to park.( I'm not making that up. Once I was nearly out of fuel and two jack asses were taking up the only landing pads and refusing to move while a line of us were waiting.)
In the end the game might make some improvements and be worthy of its insane price tag, but until then the price needs to come down to about $30 dollars.  If you want a space sandbox with a great atmosphere and you have LOTS of time to kill or if you're just a hardcore space sim enthusiast this might be the game for you, everyone else however, stay away!

reviewText:
Having played many other internet spaceship games, I can say that I've had my fair share of experiences, positive and negative.

Elite Dangerous is strange in that it is the only experience I've had with a sci-fi game that is almost exactly in the middle. Not great. Not terrible. The most apt description of Elite: dangerous is that it is a mile wide and an inch deep. This is spot on.

The game is still to this day -- nearly a year after launch, full of minor annoyances that can occasionaly make it a pain in the neck to have fun with.

Previously, I had a system that was running an Nvidia GPU, but now that I have switched over to a radeon it has become unplayable due to a bug that has been apparently known for months wherein my framerates drop to below 5 in supercruise". Since this is the main form of navigation in the game
date: it is difficult to do anything when the framerate is this low. I have been told that this is a problem stemming from the gpu drivers and is not the fault of Frontier Developments. Either way
recommended:
it is a major problem.

Overall: 5/10
With the brand new and just as shallow expansion that cost a rather large sum I must say that the game itself could be improved and

reviewText:
I know this is in Beta still, I know that there is more to come. But seriously, I have read instructions, watched videos, asked freinds, but I still cannot get the hang of this immensley pretty but ultimately immensley frustrating to play and boring game.

I try to mine.....what the ♥♥♥♥ - I have to manouvre, pick up rocks, but then drop other rocks to pick those rocks up and it takes 30 minutes just to find the rock in the first place? - Eve Online does mining right, its a boring past time as it is, dont make it even more boring!

I try a bounty missions - what the ♥♥♥♥ - Cant even find him, no marker to even a rough place of where he is. Spending god knows how long bouncing around the system looking for him all for a measley 20k. What a waste of time.

I try sitting in belts looking for wanteds - what the ♥♥♥♥ - I kill him, get back to the station, no reward. Talk to my freind, turns out it was probably a reward from a certaion faction which I would have to travel god knows how many star systems to get the 9k given to me for it - waste of time.

I try courier missions - what the ♥♥♥♥ - turns out my ship wont fly that far or something to get there, waste of time. So I have to fly all over the place just to find a station that gives me missions that I can reach....I give up after 30 minutes.

This games is in no way fun at all. Not even in the slightest.

To the makers:

When mining, it takes long enought to get to a roid feild so make it nice and easy like Eve Online yea? Fly, mine, haul.
When doing bounty missions, maybe a marker to say where he is would go a long way in a simulaitons thats a 1:1 of our galaxy?
When shotting down wanteds try automatically crediting the account with the reward like EvE...im sure they would have that in the 34th century!
In courier missions try making enough so that lower players can actually be in a system where the stations have courer missions that the noob can fly to in thier range!

This game could be so much more, try concentrating on these very mninor but extremely important game mechanics instead of landing on planets and make this game fun to learn instead of a chore!

Tip: Move away from 1984, take some ideas from the masters of modern space sims such as Freespace, EvE, The X series, Freelancer and such.

I wanted to have the biggest ship, with the best systems and accomplish everything that's possible in the game and I did it. I started with mining, changed to exploring, later I did rare trading and in the end just mass cargo, some rare trading and smuggling.

If you're a space buff and can't wait for Star Citizen, Elite Dangerous is a good time killer.

reviewText:
I wanted to have the biggest ship, with the best systems and accomplish everything that's possible in the game and I did it. I started with mining, changed to exploring, later I did rare trading and in the end just mass cargo, some rare trading and smuggling.

The first 5 hours were pure joy and space feeling. Than it deteriorated quickly.....

It was grinding like I never did before. I watched Orange is the new Black, Marco Polo and a few other TV show seasons front to back during gaming. So I was quite entertained by that.

The missions are all complete boring. Seriously they are so boring to me, I don't even read the texts anymore.

If you're a space buff and can't wait for Star Citizen, Elite Dangerous is a good time killer.
voteText: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Mmmm this has all the makings of a great game, but it just does not give you enough help in game.  For example, if you pick a mission to buy and deliver 2 power generators to a system, the game does not tell you where you can get them from, or at least i cant find any way.  This means you have to jump in system or to another one, which can be very time consuming.  It would be very helpful if there was a database of what different platforms stocked so you can jump directly to it.  As i said, just not enough info is given out when you take on a mission.  For that reason, i cant recomment this game.

reviewText: Don't bother buying this since Elite dangerous: Horizons (the other version on steam) is the base game plus extra features, unless you want to pay a total of 90$-105$ when you decide you want to play newly released content when you could have gotten it for only 45$-60$. I'm not exactly sure why they would bother keeping this version up while releasing Horizons as it's own stand alone instead of just releasing it as reasonably priced dlc. If this what they're doing now then what is to say they won't do it again with other pieces of future promised content. Who knows, maybe they'll release 2-4 different versions of the game with only the newest versions" carrying all of the previously released content
date: each with a 45$-60$ price tag. With that in mind I would suggest just waiting and not buying this version or even Horizons at least until you're sure you're not going to have to buy another game or two for 45$-60$ each to play new content when you could have waited and gotten a single game with all the content for 45$-60$. The base game is beautiful and it runs pretty great though. As for the gameplay you can read all about it in the other reviews posted but I found it pretty boring after about 30hrs in because I personally thought the gameplay was pretty shallow and tedious. Only reason I played for so long was to grind money for the biggest ship after which I promptly quit because to me there was nothing else worth doing."

reviewText:
Fantastic game. Incredibly immersive. With beautiful visuals and equally fitting sound design.

I have to say though, if you have a friend who has this game, ask them if you can try it out first. In the event that it isn't your thing, its difficult to get to grips with the gameplay, jump into the utterly huge setting, get a taste of what is out there and earn enough money to advance your ship and equipment far enough to enjoy the game fully in under 2 hours. (i.e the time it takes for the chance of a refund to be lost). This game requires you to sink a lot of time and patience into it to get the full enjoyment out of it, and believe me, you WILL lose your ship and you WILL lose a lot of money at times. But the game is fair and forgiving when it comes to post-destruction and you will make the money back.
It is definitely worth the full price you pay, but if you can pick it up in a sale, then all the better.

Sure it can seem quite empty, but it is a space sim, and to be honest - space is pretty damn empty. So get used to it.

I rate 9/10, I can't play it every hour of every day but I have so much fun with it and it is an awesome break from many other games I play.

reviewText: I found the game boring, missions lazy and sloppy designed, limited ships, factions incomplete, EVE did it better they should have learned from the best..., targeting subsystems incomplete. With no real goal other than getting the next ship, which there isn't but a couple for each type of activity. There is no sandbox features about this game, you build nothing, craft nothing,  work on nothing, co-op on nothing. Most of the universe is nothing, One star, that you can't refuel at.  This game was better without players in it. They spent all their time on the creating a semi-dynamic universe with artificial borders aka the dead zones.  I can go on about its faults in more detail but in the end this game sums up to one line.\n\nThere is nothing to do.

reviewText:
I love this game but i recoginze it isn't for everyone this game require a time commitment whether it be trading,mining or bounty hunting. If you do plan on buying this game make sure you have a goal something to aim for  whether it be a ship, a high rank ina faction or going to the centre of the galaxy. This game has some awsome moments like when i investigated a signal source to see gold floating in space only to be ambushed by three anacondas or when i was hunting a bounty i killed the criminal but i took too much damage and had to rush to a station before my oxygen ran out.
PROS
This game is very pretty,
combat is fun
intense moments
CONS
can be grindy
the world can feel lifeless at times
I'd recommend this game but i'd also caution you to take extensive look at gameplay cause as i said before this isn't for everyone

reviewText: If I had written this an hour ago it would have been a glowing recommendation for a quickly growing early access game with lots of interesting content and the promise of more. However, with the announcement of Horizons we now have all future content behind a paywall, and existing owners of the game have to pay more money for the new content than those buying it now!\n\nTo be clear: to get all future content for E:D as announced, I would have to pay £160. Do not buy this game until it goes on a big sale or Frontier caves under community pressure.

reviewText:
I can´t recommend this game.

The problem is, it doesn´t feel finished, it has great graphics and the atmosphere is awesome, BUT it has nearly no content, only very few ships, very few weapons and to have a simple paintjob for your ship you need to pay real money.
You can fly around and kill pirates for money all the time, or trade (that means bring and deliver; no economy system like in x3) and you can explore the huge galaxy, which is awesome, but gets old quick.. That´s it!

It looks great, the sound is awesome, but is very shallow. There is no real content and the new Powerplay Addon is really bad and so confusing, that you don´t want to play it.

But there is a solution! They offer you to pay the same prize, that the game itself costs for possible upcoming content..
They have great plans/addons, but atm this is just fiction..
So they charge you the prize for an AAA game, in order to get a barebones game, that feels nowhere near finished and lacks on content everywhere.

They are even so generous to offer the existing backers/owners of the game to pay more for the upcoming addons then someone who buys it as a new customer.. Yeah, this is really true..
There is huge ♥♥♥♥♥torm going on in the forums right now, because of the insane cashgrab mentality of the devs..

If you are just seeking to have epic space dogfight sim, then this game is for you, but do yourself a favour and buy it only, when it is on sale. Never it is worth the full prize.

If you are coming from games like x3RU or X3TC, don´t buy this game, you will be very disappointed about how less you can do in this game.. it´s a joke, but at least a good looking one..

I´m soo disappointed, because i really love the immersion you get in this game, but it lacks severe on content and the devs act like cashgrabbers..

DON´T BUY IT!! You can get much better and finished products for your hard earned money.

Keep an eye on this game and follow it and, maybe, if they really do add some content in the future and lower this insane prizes it could be worth it.
ATM they want you to pay insane amounts of money for upcoming updates..
The problem is, i already paid money for a game that feels empty and not finished, to get more they want me to pay even more than the base-prize and this several times and there is no guarantee, that they will deliver..

I don´t trust them anymore..

reviewText:
(I do play with Official Launcher so Steam Game-time Hours are irrelevant)

400 billion stars and Real Milky Way i am talking about. This game is one of the best modern Real Space Sim/action game includes Combat/Exploration/Politics/Trade/Resource Management with next-gen graphics.

You can do whatever you want and become whoever you want in this Huge universe.

Now everyone maybe do wait for Star Citizen , but Elite Dangerous is unique own its own and more realistic in terms of Space/Galaxy/System knowledge that exist in reality so far have known by the Human. (NASA confirms that as even they worked together for creating Milky Way in Elite Dangerous)

There are tons of stuff ,missions or anything you can choose/do in this game , not even talking about Massive Scale of the Milky Way that takes around 300+YEARS Real time to travel the  Galaxy all around without visiting every single Sub Planets.

So this makes Elite Dangerous Unique. You ain't gonna  able to travel whole galaxy all around in terms of realism, Maybe your son and grandson can take the Flag and follow your steps. FFS! :)

Black Holes, Dark matters,Dark Energy,Nebulas all are there in real awating you to explore or maybe interact.

Some Links about it :
http://www.polygon.com/2015/1/26/7912413/elite-dangerous-exploration-milky-way

https://www.reddit.com/r/EliteDangerous/comments/2rhv81/how_long_would_it_take_to_explore_the_entire/

Exploration even own its own is a big deal ! FPS Combat is challenging and Cruise Control has its learning curve.  But there are tons of useful information out there on forums,internet and Tutorials that you can play in The Game.

Horizions DLC is coming soon this month and BETA is aready out so planetary landings/exploration/misisons is already out.

After all , it's your decision to get the game. But This is the closest you can get a chance to travel around Milky Way in your life time, so Why would you not give it a go ?

reviewText:
I had really high hopes for this game. To me it seemed like an evolution of the almighty Freelancer. I was hoping for a larger, more indepth version of the Discovery Freelancer community, but sadly, thats not what you get. Sure.. what the game does well, it does very well. The feel of emptiness in space, the amazing graphics, the incredible ammount fo controls   that are greatly enhanced with voice control along with a hots and rudder system.

Sadly though, the game is empty... really really empty. Ok, I know.. space is empty, but thats not what I mean. I mean feature wise. We have millions upon millions of stars and systems to explore. Sounds great, until you realize the exploring simple means flying into a system, pushing a button, looking at the map, and if there's one of a handful of planet types, you fly to them and push another button, if not, you zip off to the system. Once there, yep.. push your button, then move on. After a bit, its really nothing but the same think over and over.. A very slow and slick looking clicker" game.

I decided to fly back and give trading and piracy a try. Back in discovery Freelancer. Wow

reviewText:
Played the original back in 1984 on Commodore 64, loved it to death. My school work back then suffered bigtime.

Now here we are with Elite: Dangerous, I bought in at the very early stages and saw what was not much turn into something special. The 30 odd year wait was very well worth it, Currently since alpha sitting at well over 3000 hours in game (My wife is a card holding member of Elite Widows)

Now Elite is not for everyone, If you rely on following ! and ? to get anywhere in a game, Elite is not for you. But if jumping into a rickety old space ship and a few bucks in your pocket and launching into the unknown with no one to hold your hand and having to find your own way in the Milky Way, Then Elite is for you and you shall get a lot out of it.

There is a crazy amount of ships, weapons and modules to outfit ships to your liking.
Become a Smuggler and bring illegal cargo to and from stations for good profits.
Hunt wanted pilots (players and AI) for bounties.
Assist in war zones to help your supported faction win power in the system.
Trade your way to riches in the legal wares of the populated sector.
Explore out into the void, find unknown systems and have your name applied as the first founder of that star, planets and moons etc.
Join in on community events and reap the rewards
Head out mining and sit back with some music and head butt some rocks for decent profits.
Join a major faction and get involved in Powerplay and have the opportunity to earn rare equipment for you ships and credits.
Become a cold hearted killer, lay waste to every ship you see if this is you thing.
Or become a trusted soul helping others get to their destinations and protecting them from the above.

The above comments are a few thoughts on what you can do in Elite, and with Horizons coming very soon. Elite: Dangerous is shaping up to be one amazing game.

I can quite easily give Elite: Dangerous a thumbs up and it sure is only going to get better and better.

Fly safe Cmdr's!

Cmdr Jazzy 'Pickle' Rose - Commanding Officer of the Battle-Conda The Lady Jane" - Member of the Fuel Rats!"

reviewText:
I'm no legal eagle, but isn't this company commiting outright fraud?

This is how I see it:-

You buy a jar of cookies for £5
Get it home, and it's an EMPTY JAR!!!!!
Wait no, there's a slip of paper in the jar..... buy your first cookie for £2, offer ends in two months, your first cookie will then be £3 instead..... as you buy each cookie you will be entitled to buy further cookies (one per quarter of a year) at £3 each. Until you reach 10 cookies, and you've spent up to £50, then your jar is full - now sod off we're rich, you're not! hahahahahaha!

This is similar to what has happened with Elite:Dangerous,

The first version of this game was also just an empty jar.....
This MASSIVELY overpriced DLC is then the first cookie" to go in the jar.....
Then there will be more ever year for the next 10 years I believe.
This game could potentially cost you getting on for £1000 by 2025!

There were no warnings or hints of this situation back in July 2015

reviewText: A lot of people mention learning curve as an issue but my issue is this game is not very fun even if you have friends to play with.  Before you laugh at me for not having friends, I'd also like to say that even with friends, this was not much fun for me to play.  The only thing about being with friends is that you can laugh at each other dying or at murdering other players.\n\nThe simulation portion of it is interesting, i'll give them that.  But at the end of the day all this game is good for is just that: flight simulation.  Fly here, keep this other ship in your sights, etc.  The upgrades are very linear and boring,  They are in descending order A,B,C,D,E hmm which upgrade should I pick? The combat is basically just keeping the other ship in your sights, the navigation is questionable, the game feels flat and without character, it is just not that fun for me, and thus I cannot reccomend it to others.

reviewText:
I bought Elite: Dangerous, not Elite Dangerous: Horizons. Here is why I'm downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off:

1) Bought a game that is unfinished, with the expectation that things are getting better until it's finished, which is the primary goal of the developer. They release Horizons as a hugely expensive addon/dlc/expansion really doesn't matter what it's called or what it contains, they still have ED to work on!

2) ED: Horizons... cheaper to buy with ED for people who don't own ED. Wait a sec... let me say that again... if you own ED it costs you MORE to buy ED: Horizons. I'm feeling a bit of a sharp pain in my back.

3) The moment ED: Horizons was released, not only was I contending with #1 and #2, but I discover a 8GB update in steam. So... they push an 8GB update - to some people that's a good chunk of thier monthly bandwidth, to others that's $$$.

4) Lastly not I get news for updated entitled: Elite Dangerous: Horizons.... I DIDN'T BUY HORIZONS, so why do I give 2 rats a$$es about the updates concerning that. Separate the news, you'd think for the $$$ they are charging they could at least do that.

Conclusion: I'm shelving this game. I played a few hours on it, and it's more annoying than fun. Controller setups are crap, can't tune dead-zones correctly, I was goofing around with controls for about an hour and it's still not set up so it's comfortable. Missions are strange, fly to this system to get info.... then there is no further information on where in that system the information is; do I yield at this intersection forever or what? reviewText:
I bought Elite: Dangerous, not Elite Dangerous: Horizons. Here is why I'm downright ♥♥♥♥♥♥ off:

1) Bought a game that is unfinished, with the expectation that things are getting better until it's finished, which is the primary goal of the developer. They release Horizons as a hugely expensive addon/dlc/expansion really doesn't matter what it's called or what it contains, they still have ED to work on!

2) ED: Horizons... cheaper to buy with ED for people who don't own ED. Wait a sec... let me say that again... if you own ED it costs you MORE to buy ED: Horizons. I'm feeling a bit of a sharp pain in my back.

3) The moment ED: Horizons was released, not only was I contending with #1 and #2, but I discover a 8GB update in steam. So... they push an 8GB update - to some people that's a good chunk of thier monthly bandwidth, to others that's $$$.

4) Lastly not I get news for updated entitled: Elite Dangerous: Horizons.... I DIDN'T BUY HORIZONS, so why do I give 2 rats a$$es about the updates concerning that. Separate the news, you'd think for the $$$ they are charging they could at least do that.

Conclusion: I'm shelving this game. I played a few hours on it, and it's more annoying than fun. Controller setups are crap, can't tune dead-zones correctly, I was goofing around with controls for about an hour and it's still not set up so it's comfortable. Missions are strange, fly to this system to get info.... then there is no further information on where in that system the information is; do I yield at this intersection forever or what? I should have bought the large starbucks coffee... I'm gonna be here a while.

Shelved for now, and until they change the way they charge users for the updates.

reviewText:
Pros: Beautiful cockpit, fantastic sound design, above average space combat.

Cons: Lacks context, incomplete features, feels like it's still in alpha, and worst of all; an awful payment model.

For those of you who want the planetary landing feature, do not buy this game, you should buy the standalone/expansion/first season. Confused yet? Well this 'season' of expansions, Horizons, contains the base game. So if you bought this game, too bad, sucks for you because you're spending a lot more money than people who have only just become interested. Also,  at the time of writing, that's all Horizons contains. So they're making existing players pay a lot of money for the game they already own + one feature and an unspecified list of promised features. I don't think I'll be buying that without a major price reduction. There is a slight, emphasis on slight, loyalty bonus. This is not good enough. Next year it will be the same thing. A new expansion off the back of one semi-complete feature, a promise of good things to come and then an exploitation of the fanbase as they try and shift more units of the game.
voteText: 11 of 16 people (69%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
The game is beautiful, intricate and massive - just the sort of thing I expected when I bought it.

However, it's also a nightmare to start in, because of lack of explaination of how missions actually work. You'll spend the majority of your time visiting websites to find out whats expected of you.

You'll also constantly be given missions (particularly assasinations) that are WAY beyond your capabilities, requring you to fight multiple enemies in substantially more powerful ships, and requiring equipment that you simply don't have (such as frameshift interdictors).

And of course, player characters will destroy newbies without provocation, one-hit-killing them with vastly superior firepower - although this is an issue with any game that allows general PvP, so it isn't a criticism of the game itself (although it would be nice to see people discouraged from picking on noobs).

If you're willing to spend the time researching the details of every possible mission type online before you play, then this will be less of an issue. If you plan on only trading, that also would be fine. But there is a distinct lack of in-game tutorials on performing some of the most interesting mission types, which brings the game down significantly for time-poor players who don't have the opportunity to work it out over multiple failed missions.

If it wasn't for the completely unsupported learning curve, this review would be quite positive. If this is addressed in the future, I'd immediately switch my vote.

reviewText:
I'm conflicted on how I feel about Elite Dangerous as a whole. At first I thought I had found the perfect game, especially given my love of the genre. You can appriciate the amount of time and effort that had gone in to making it within your first 5 minutes of playtime, great visuals and not to mention the overabundance of great sounds that emanate from your cockpit in any given situation, truely they are fantastic. The feeling I had when I dropped out of hypercruise for the first time and saw a star zoom in to view in front of me, witnessing light getting distorted around a black hole, even observing our Solar System after working my way up for a Sol Permit... there was a lot that amazed me to begin with.

I did everything I could to get my credits up, (about 3-4 ways to earn cash, so a MASSIVE grind) and finally had enough to buy an Anaconda. After this, the game kind of trailed off. No matter, I'll wait for season 2 as it's going to add plane... wait, season 2 isn't included? Oh, in this DLC culture we have accepted, I'm suppose... wait HOW MUCH? If only I could replicate the joy and excitement I got from my first 10 hours of gameplay, I probably would still be playing this on a daily basis. Instead I feel ripped off that I need to pay Frontier £40-50 every yearly release (season) until the final (there are 10 planned!) to get the complete game.

The first Season that I own is empty and desolute after the first few hours and you would have seen/done mostly everything the game has to offer. I stuck with it however (130 hours) on the hope that the updates would add more to the game, and to grind my way to the biggest ship which was a goal I had set from the start. I'm betting the second season (Horizons) will be the same this time next year. It just seems to be shady business to me, to offer only 1/10 of the game each year and expecting the consumer to pay the full cost of the game each time.

If they had charged circa £10 for Horizons as an add on, and the same price for each subsequent season, yes I would of paid this gladly and continued my support even though I feel the game is sparce and empty at the moment. Frontier however, have decided to re-release the entire game each year with the DLC built in for the standard £40-50, while continuing to offer the old defunct season on the store to maximise their profits. I calculate that to be near enough £500 for the entire game, which is riduculous.

Rather than writing an entire review which mirrors all of the negative ones below, I'll just say this. Frontier have picked the wrong business model, and Star Citizen will be my prefered Space game from now on. This is unfortunate as Elite had a lot of promise and has a fantastic framework to build on, but I can see it being cancelled long before they get to Season 10 if they carry on as they are. Planetary landings? Perhaps they should have made sure there was more to do than just land and ride around on a SRV for 5 minutes before getting bored - especially for an extra £40. You only have to look at the sales for Horizons and compare them to Elite Dangerous to see I'm not the only one who feels this way.

reviewText:
Can easily see the immense potential in this game. Its gorgeous, its space, its our galaxy. Idealy this game could help make every nerds dream come true. Admittedly i havent put too much time into this game but thats only because the play sessions require too much of my time... and another glaring issue that ill get to in a minute.

Sadly i cannot recommend this game. I paid full price for the original game with the understanding that content would steadily stream and continue to enhance the gameplay. Little did anybody know that their 'Alpha' was the finished game and all subsequent content would be bundled into cute little Rover" packages and we'd be charged another 60 dollar premium to get it. Following that clever idea they decided it would be cool to let new players buy the expansion for 60 bucks and also get the content that i had to pay 60 to get. Explain to me how i shouldnt feel cheated out of my money?

If you haven't bought the game, I'll fill you in on why I've given it a thumbs down even after playing it for hundreds of hours.

1.  When you start off the game, there is no explanation about what you are to do.  You don't uncover this.  There is no mission briefing.  You don't customize your ship and then join some alliance battle against the evil tyrinoids.  You are just able to go to a bulletin board and are presented with the following options...

A.  Take these items to this starbase/planet base.  I'll give you some money.
B.   Take this secret message to this starbase/planet base.  Don't get scanned.  I'll give you some money.
C.  Go kill this guy in this sector.  I'll give you some money.
D.  Go find me an item.  I'll give you some money.
E.  (Rarely) Go destroy something for me.

Choose an option and off you go.  The game's physics are good, and the game engine is decent.  You have a lot of variety in the way you can control your ship.  Move vertical as well as horizontal, employ yaw, and zoom forward and backward.  It's like most any space flight sim, except (And this is important) that here you will turn incredibly slow.  But hey man

reviewText:
This is why i played Elite dangerous i bought Horizons DLC and why im not playing anymore.

Lets start with the positive ,there are very few of them so lets get that part over and done with.

Frontier development have created a giant sandbox space simulator with really great community of gamers
Who you can interact with. for me this was my first experience with massive multiplayer online games.
And i enjoyed it while it lasted. Just like a eks it was good while it lasted but this is not a girl you would keep for long.

Elite dangerous is best descriebed as a huge ocean which is 20 centimeters deep .
Meaningg its all about grinding grinding grinding bugs bugs bugs. go back here then go there, people at Frontier developments think they have made an addictive game but they just made a really boring one.
I now what you are thinking then why have you played 400+ hours on this game well that is solely because of the great gamers community which exists, if i hadent been part of a gamer community i doubt if i would have played more then 10 hours. There is no story ,no atmosfere in the game ,totally sterile , you would  think that a company that makes a space game would be creative and imaginative but no zero of that nothing zero imagination and zero creativity.
the economy side of the game sucks, and the spaceships are so ugly. They look like big metal boxes .

I had a break for 2 months from the game then they announced that Horizons have arrived. What a suprise they launched it in the middle of christmas, that was just so hard to guess, well i bought it even though it is hugely overpriced
400 kroner for landing on a planet in a game ,they just made it 20 centimeters deeper and they want that price for it,
ok i give you the benefit of the dought installed it , it does not work, . looking into the internet checking with others who have the same problem, trying different stuff for hours its always like that for Elite dangerous so gamers get used to it but hell no im not gonna use hours and hours for making it work because you have bugs and because you think you have to sell in christmas, for that price im just suppose to push a button and it is suppose to be running perfectly, therefore i got my money back thanks to steam.

You see Frontier development would like you to belive that that they are listening to the community of players but nothing could be further from the truth , they are just milking a cash cow thats the only thing they care about and the only reason howe they can do that is beacause its the only game of its kind so there is lots of players but hey stop ever heard about star citizen? if those guys actually make a finished produkt everybody in frontier would lose there jobs . im not a fan of star citizen frankly they should just stop talking about it and finish the game but i hope they do because Frontier does not deserve the gamer community they have.If they ever make it nobody would play elite , at least 80 % would drop out the first day. If there is 100 people working for frontier 90 of them are working with marketing, 1 is counting the cash 1 is hell i dont now what there doing they are not doing anything.
I have a news for you marketing genius , start praying for star citizen not launching because if they do you will be all out of jobs so start sending your resume to the used car dealer shops and EA games you can only milk the cow for a limited time, start listening to the players if you want a future im taking my money elsewhere and i recomend you to do the same.

This is already a game that many of us gamers waited for a decade at least.

And what had started as a fill-the-gap game before Star Citizen release became much, much more.

There are better alternatives out there.

reviewText:
It's fun for a while.  Then you look at the game properly.

It has a lot of content of the surface but a lot of it is repetitive.  I spent the first couple of hours just doing delivery missions until I could buy a ship wiht a bigger cargo hold.

I started doing my own freight deliveries once I purchased a Lakon Type-4.  They were lucrative but boring as every run, I'd end up running from pirates or other players who wanted a shipment worth 20,000 or my *huge* bount of 500.

The game is incomplete and lacking in a lot of social interaction.  The game is meant to be a simulator, which can offset some faults in the combat system, which is like watching 2 goldfish in a bowl with lasers, but it cannot offset anything.

Don't buy it unless you get it in a sale.  And don't buy it if you dislike the concept of Euro Truck Simulator in space...

reviewText:
buying games these days seems like spinning the roulette, sometimes you win, and sometimes you lose, and sometimes you just feel cheated. i try really hard to be contientious about my purchases. i don't pre-order games, i try and stay away from early access, and i only buy something after doing my research.

Elite Dangerous in a lot of ways is a great game, and i got a lot of enjoyment out of it. But it isn't what i signed up for, really. It's plagued with a lot of little problems and design flaws that add up to make a frustrating experience. flying through space feels like playing red light green light as you are constantly having to veer away from suns, and braking for your destinations always seems to be futile. i'm always having to flee for my life for stupid little piddly stuff that doesn't make sense, like accidentally shooting someone from the wrong faction, or not entering a station correctly resulting in DEATH. i feel like the game has a long way to go, and a lot of different ways to grow, and instead of developing the game in a logical way, we get a stapled on planetary landing update that we have to pay for.

seriously i understand people want planetary landings, but let's be honest, who cares? being able to land on a planet isn't going to make the game feel deeper, nor make the game better, it's just going to add planets i can land on. it just doesn't make sense to me. add more mechanics, update annoying stuff, make the netcode work better, half the time i get disconnected from my friends... but no, instead we get planetary landings.

all of that AND i have to pay for updates. PLUS they bring out updates for xbox one FIRST it seems, and if you are on the mailing list, you get to hear about all the cool new stuff xbox players are getting a month in advance. i feel like this game does everything it can to make you feel stupid for buying it. bought it to late? oh well, i guess you'll be paying for future updates. bought it too early? welp looks like the game is $20 for new players too bad so sad. and if you just want to buy the game? if you just want to buy the game normally like all games are bought, it's like 200 or so dollars. ♥♥♥♥ right off. this isn't star citizen and if it was i wouldn't buy it.

i understand it was said before that updates would cost extra, but i don't think this game makes much effort advertising the fact that what you are buying is *temporary*. you are paying for a certain amount of content, and then after that, you are paying more if you want more content, which would be fine, if the game felt finished.

on an unrelated note, if current players feel i have been unfair, and want to send me a message, please direct your message directly into the trashbin. i don't care. if you like the game, cool, but you aren't going to convince me that i shouldn't feel cheated. i WILL be deleting offensive comments.

reviewText: The game is beautiful, Sounds amazing, and was pretty damn impressive. I loved it for my 400+ hours. But, its's only replay value is centered around those who love the grind, and when I mean grind, It's pretty hardcore grind. Like, only 15 of my in-game hours total was used on anything that wasn't centered around ginding. It's crazy. The dlc is crazy expensive, and that just adds things games like space engineers adds for free. I loved flying through space in my decked out ships, but once I hit that wall where light (and I say that because 400 hours is considered light grinding in this game) grinding just wasn't enough, If I wanted to progress any further I'd have to literally hand over my personal life to the devs. That wasn't for me, if you like that, then this game is perfect for you. But I can't recommend this soley on being able to only experience a quarter of the original games content. It's mad huge with tons of grind walls you have to break down plain and simple. Destiny's grind system has nothing on this.

reviewText:
This game was 40 dollars for me. You are stuck inside a cockpit for the entire game, you can dock at space stations and remain in your cockpit while interfacing with a space station's services. You cannot land on a planet or walk around inside your ship. There are limited things to do and dispite the fact that the game is visually attractive, there is not a whole lot of immersion.
They released an update that will let you land on planets but you still cant walk around as a person at all, and the update cost is the same amount that an entire new game would cost.
It's 2016.. this is not acceptable to me for the amount of money they are asking, for the cost of updates that will be around 40 dollars each in the future, you just arent getting what you're paying for.
There are better alternatives out there.

reviewText:
It's fun for a while.  Then you look at the game properly.

It has a lot of content of the surface but a lot of it is repetitive.  I spent the first couple of hours just doing delivery missions until I could buy a ship wiht a bigger cargo hold.

I started doing my own freight deliveries once I purchased a Lakon Type-4.  They were lucrative but boring as every run, I'd end up running from pirates or other players who wanted a shipment worth 20,000 or my *huge* bount of 500.

The game is incomplete and lacking in a lot of social interaction.  The game is meant to be a simulator, which can offset some faults in the combat system, which is like watching 2 goldfish in a bowl with lasers, but it cannot offset anything.

Don't buy it unless you get it in a sale.  And don't buy it if you dislike the concept of Euro Truck Simulator in space...

reviewText:
Let me start off this review by telling you something flat out. This is NOT a game for those that absolutely must have a plot where you are the central character. You will not find that here. You are incredibly tiny and completely incidental in the grand scheme of things. Then again, you are one pilot in a galactic sandbox. What more can you expect?

What you will find here is interstellar travel and exploration, space pirates, bounties to hunt, mining to be done, and cargo to haul for profit. You start off with a very basic ship and what you do from then on is entirely up to you. If you like the idea of cruising through space, seeing the majesty and wonder that is space while living out your freelance space commander fantasy, this is a worthy purchase.

One thing that this game does not do is hold your hand. It is highly recommended that you go through each and every one of the training tutorials to get accustomed to the controls and to wet your feet with space travel. The best rule to remember? There is no up or down in space. It will help you to learn to be able to think of movement in three dimensions without the constraint of gravity. Progression can, at times, be a bit slow when you can't find a well paying mission within the scope of what you want to do, but there will usually be at least something to push you to another system for the cost of a refuel. Fuel is another important thing to always keep in mind. You CAN get yourself stranded in space if you are not careful about the course you plot or if you forget to spend the pittance to top your engines off at each port you dock in. Space pirates are far from lazy and will occasionally just pull you out of FTL travel for kicks, giggles, and target practice regardless of what your reputation in the system is.

All that said, these challenges are enjoyable to me. In an age of gaming where one is often railroaded through tutorials and plot in a game that can top up at 40hrs, I find it refreshing that I can spend just as much time being space UPS to buy that next ship that will give me a bigger cargo hold. My eventual goal? To make a pilgrimage to the galactic center and then to sol. After that? I'll see about making sol my home system and collect all the ships. Hours upon hours of content before me.

I do not lie when I say that I can sink the majority of a day into this game without even noticing the passing of time. My personal favorite way to play is in a private session with my friends and wingmates. There is an in game comm system linked to any mic you use that will connect you to wingmates, your party members, so there is no need for an additional chat client unless you'd rather use something else. However, just as there are many ways to make a living in space, there are just as many ways to play the game. Open mode will put you in the galaxy with everybody else. Solo mode puts you in by yourself, but fear not. There are NPC ships everywhere should you decide to become a bounty hunter or a pirate yourself. They are not dumb in a dogfight either. Create a group with your friends, and you can play in a solo style with them specifically.

So, If what I have said here interests you in the game, I highly suggest picking it up. If you are the kind of person that gets enjoyment out of following the plot of a game, this is likely not for you.

While I am certainly not far enough into the game to give a completely legit review, here's my take. reviewText: I loved Elite: Dangerous for a while.  I clocked in a bit over 60 hours on it, which for a man my age with a full time job, kids, wife and other responsibilities, that's a big chunk of investment. It was everything I wanted it to be in a space sim... well... it wasn't yet, but it was going to be! I believed the hype. I bought in early and waited for my just desserts. Nope. All those cool features they said they would have in the game have been repackaged into an entirely new $60 game called Elite Dangerous Horizons. Keep in mind. The two games are functionally identical. The only difference is one has planetary landings and the other does not. Keep in mind also, the one that does not (this one) was promised to have it to the early backers of the kickstarter and not revealed as a completely separate game buy for more than the initial purchase. Screw you Frontier. You took my money and my time, both of which I hold of value.
voteText: 13 of 20 people (65%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
After you figure out the best bounty farming location, you have effectively beat the game. The rest of the game is purely a waste of time if you're trying to progress. Of course you'll have to get past the incredibly difficult learning curve of what is the button configuration screen, and you'll literally spend hours of your time configuring your keybinds. Once you've accomplished this, you'll literally jump to the next star system and find a ringed planet to kill random NPCs or players for bounty rewards. Welcome to the grind of buying better and better ships until... well, you grind more bounties until you have so many credits you quit, ultimately realizing that you beat the game long long ago - when you finished configuring your keybinds.

Bounties are the most lucrative way of obtaining currency in the game, with credits being the primary facilitator of progression. Yes there are other ways, but you'll get 1/10th the reward. If you want to slave away in a game and accomplish nothing, guess what, there is a less monotonous way - working at mc donalds.

To the developer - congratulations on playing your consumers by releasing an unfinished game - and then releasing an expansion for full retail price that would otherwise provide a much more immersive experience. Finish your game first before you release other games.

reviewText: Quite possibly the most disappointing time I've ever spent with a game.
voteText: 14 of 22 people (64%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I'll start by saying that my steam hours played aren't accurate. I've been playing since beta and probably have around 200 hours play time and I’ve experienced everything the game has to offer.

You're probably thinking, how can you not recommend a game if you managed to spend 200+ hours on it. Well, I kept playing in the hopes that the endgame would make it worth it, spoilers: There is no endgame. I really regret spending this much time on the game, as I wasn't having fun and I really wish I could get those hours back.

I also need to say that this review is talking primarily about solo play, as that is the mode I mainly play. I was pretty annoyed when frontier turned around a month before release and said they weren't going to include a proper single player mode in the game, but oh well, can't be changed now.

Now about the game and my problems with it.

The main problem with this game is that you can see everything this game has to offer in about 10 hours, after that you are just repeating your actions. The main activities in this game include: combat, trading, exploring and mining.

Combat
The combat in this game is a lot of fun when you first start it. You can make money through combat via bounty hunting or going to combat zones, but the only proper way of making a decent amount of money through combat is via bounty hunting at Resource Extraction Sites. Now I need to add here how silly this is. The name Resource Extraction Site would imply that it is a place primarily for mining. Think again. Its only use in the game is for bounty hunting, which involves waiting for endless waves of pirates to spawn and die by your hand rewarding you with a sum of money depending on the class and rank of the ship. The design here is just stupid. You can drop out anywhere in a planetary ring and mine free of pirates, so why would you ever go to a RES to mine. It's really counter intuitive.

All combat actually involves is aiming the nose of your ship at a target and holding down the trigger until they're dead. There's no complexity or challenge to it and it gets old quite quickly. This is not helped by the limited choice of weapons. There are currently only two types of weapon in the game: Kinetic (multicannon, single-shot cannon, missiles, mines and railguns) and Energy weapons (pulse, beam, and burst lasers and plasma accelerators). Now when it comes down to weapon choice, there's really only one type of weapon worth using and that’s the laser weapons, as they deal a steady amount of damage and don't use ammo. Missiles and mines are completely useless and are never used, as you can only carry a miniscule amount of ammo and would end up returning to a station to reload every 5 minutes. But the weapon you use really doesn't matter, there's no difference between any of them, they all get the job done at a similar rate. Some actual weapon diversity would be nice, but currently all the weapons are pretty dull, offer no spectacular visuals and they all perform about the same (apart from missiles and mines).

Trading
Trading is the best way of making money in the game and IMO, it's really poorly implemented. It is incredibly boring and involves: Start at station, buy goods, jump to other system, dock at station, sell goods, repeat. There is no variance in that process, you carry on doing that until you have enough money. There is also no way of finding a good trade route in game. The only way to do this is via third party tools. A trade computer would be nice, but currently there is no indication of the price of goods in neighbouring systems, so you must rely on third party tools which in my opinion is unacceptable.

Exploring
I think I had the most fun in this game while exploring. This is mainly due to my interest in space, so seeing all the different astronomical bodies was pretty cool. But all exploring really comes down to is: jump to system, perform a system scan, see if there’s anything good, if there is scan, otherwise jump to next system. The process of scanning is just point the nose of your ship at a small white dot until it says scan complete, it is not fun or interactive in any way. This process gets very repetitive, very quickly and the payout per hour is really bad, probably one of the worst paying professions in the game time wise.

Mining
Mining has changed, but I still find it incredibly boring and I find myself questioning some design decisions. Like why in the year 3300 am I launching huge 1 ton drones which are made to do their work and then explode. Why not just have a drone module which launches, refuels and reuses drones. Currently you have to fill up your cargo hold with drones that are doomed to explode. This seems so wasteful to me. This also applies to scanning the metal content of asteroids, launch a drone at it, get results and then the drone blows up. Why not just give us a scanner. We have light spectroscopy and x-ray scanning in 2015, we can already scan the metal content of things, I can't believe that this technology hasn't advanced in over a thousand years and we're forced to rely on suicide drones to do our work.

Anyway, mining involves pointing nose at an asteroid, shooting mining lasers at rock, launching suicide drones to pick up rocks for 5 minutes and then explode. It takes quite a while to make a reasonable amount of money and is pretty boring.


Those are the main ways of making money and my problems with them, I do however have other reasons why I do not recommend this game.

One of these is missions. They are incredibly tedious and pay out pennies in comparison to other professions. The only use of missions in the game is to rank up with a meaningless faction which grants no benefits other than access to certain ships.

This brings me on to my next point, the ships. All of the ships in the game are the same essentially. Bigger ships just let you hold more weapons and/or cargo. You can achieve everything there is to do in the game in one of the cheapest 4 ships. The largest ship currently is the Anaconda at around 140m in length. The size has no bearing however, as all of the ships fly in the same way and act as fighters, pointing the nose of the ship at an enemy and shooting. It would make more sense to me if the larger ships behaved fundamentally different and made the switch to more broadside centric combat.

It would be nice to see some unique ships specific to certain professions as well. I'll try and think of some examples, maybe a big hulking mining ship which uses reusable mining drones and can extract more resources from rocks. Or an exploration ship which maybe rather than having a cockpit per say, has the pilot sat in the heart of the ship watching a screen with a projection of what’s going on outside, to eliminate the danger of a canopy breach. There's no imagination with the current ships.

The last thing I want to talk about is customization. Currently it’s non-existent unless you pay real money. I play this as a solo game, I expect to be able to customize how my dashboard or ship looks. It would be unacceptable if you had to pay Bethesda real money to change the clothes you wear in skyrim, so why should I pay to change how my ship looks. I understand Frontier have to make money some way, but why is every single customization option a micro transaction. I want to change my ships appearance with in game funds.

That about concludes by problems with the game. I would love to talk more, but the word limit is harsh. It really is a mile wide and an inch deep though. I've played horizons and it changes nothing IMO, it only makes the game another mile wider and no deeper.

This game has so much potential, and it really pains me to see it so mediocre, I’m hoping by highlighting the problems it can be improved.

Anyway, sorry for the wall of text. I hope it was helpful :)

reviewText:
The game is a pretty good flight simulator and you really feel like you are flying in space..

Potentially it could be a wonderful game but there is way too much disconnect between different parts of the game.

After a while the galaxies all look the same (as well as man made structures) and everything you do turns into a boring grind.

You need to grind for everything and most of it is extremely un fun and can take ages to get with out any rewards to keep you going...

If I was too sum up this game it would be a potentially great idea done in the most cheap and nasty way possible. So much potential lost because of the developer more focused on making a quick buck at the expense of more immersive content..

Mile wide inch deep...

reviewText:
I have not reviewed many games. This one made me step up and say something.

Game looks great. Graphics wise that is. That is pretty much the pros about this title.....the graphics. Most players will get to space trucking for a few hours, get attacked by a pirate, flee or fight the pirate until space police arrive, then deliver space cargo, get paid space monies. I dont know why, but ED feels like those extremely dry vampire or ganster text only games we used to play on facebook. Now we have graphics that show you getting from point A to point B. The game lacks any real excitment or better content than space trucking. The game claims that players affect the galaxy economy, but when in the game, you dont feel like you have affected any economy output whatsoever.

OH BOY. Lets not forget Horizons.........the game that Frontier wanted you to buy for 59.99. Where you get to break atmostphere and land on a rock planet and.... and ...and ....play ATV dunebuggy simulator? This game was all hype and very dispointing. Full disclosure tho: I do not have Horizons. I can only repeat the vomit I have seen on youtube videos. Like any game purchase, you should check this game out on youtube as well (the base game ED i mean). Try to avoid trailers and get some videos from actual players.

Yes, I have almost 100 hours playing this game, but most of it was all in hope. HOPE that the game had some sort of end in mind. Maybe even a slight story? There was nothing of the sort in those hours. I tried looking for better content in the missions, which are broken btw. Yeah BROKEN!!!!!! (I hope someone from Frontier reads that. FUDGING BROKEN). Example: Many have posted this one before. You accecpt a mission to find a person in a certain system. You go to system only to find out that he is not where the mission said he'd be. Here is the catch; you only have 20 minutes to find him, and it takes 2-3 mintues to travel to different areas in that system. Time runs out before you find him. I think I have found said person 0/6 times I have tried anyway.

Conclusion. Dont buy this game if you are looking for depth and something that grabs you from the screen to keep you playing like most other games. If you are hoping for that, and buy this game anyway, then you'll be like the rest of us who bought it sucking on a poop flavored lolly pop. I told my friends that after I had over 100 hours I would tell them yay or nay to buy this title. Unfortunetly I forgot and failed to warn them. (another reason why I feel like I need to write this) In direct result of my failure, 2-3 of my friends now have bought this title and probably hate me for not warning them. I can't recommend this game to anyone. Unless Frontier pulls their heads out of their butts, and gives the game REAL content FOR WHAT WE ALREADY PAID FOR, only then will I change my review. Other than that, I will never EVER pay money again to a frontier game. Unless they do change their business practices and give players what they already paid for.

reviewText:
In space noone can hear you yawn.

Its a beautiful game with practically nothing to do in it. The missions are dull. Go 'here' pick up'this' take it 'here'. You cant base your decision to buy off any of the trailers or videos. You will never see action like that in game since this is first person only. So those epic space battles you see are just a cool movie having nothing to do with what you can see in game. The only thing you'll ever look at is your cockpit.

Its essentially a ship grinder where everyone grinds hard to get into the best ship for each role. After you accomplish that there is nothing else to work for. Just try and fly through billions of systems. Fighting is quite dull too. You literally just circle endlessly until one of you is dead. The ships look as though they were designed by 5 year olds first learning shapes. Here is a square. Put guns on it and we can call it a ship. Here is a triangle, put guns on it and lets call it a ship.

Meeting people is near impossible. Even in the starting areas chat is dead. Venture out of your starting area and you will never see a real person in space ever again as long as you play. If solo is your thing you might enjoy this game for 50 hours or so. Save your money and wait for Star Citizen to come out. It will blow the doors off ED upon release.

reviewText: This game really is something special. Only a game like this could make spending 100 hours a bad thing. I'm gonna be honest, there are obviously good things about this game.  But this game suffers from the worst of al video game sins. It feels horribly unfinished. From trading, to smugging, to the combat the game seems to almost get there. But with lackluster A.I., poor instancing, and a general lack of player to player interface, this game comes close but leaves you wanting more in the worst ways. Games like this are meant to have hundreds and hundreds of hours sunk into them, and after the first hundred everything seems to just blend together into some bland generic grind for ships that save for a handful of them, seem to only be in the game to have them. This is not even counting them already planning out expansions that they charge full price for, essentially dole out in small increents over the year, and essentialy are adding more fluff, without any actual depth to the game. Or, worst of all, add things that should be in the game to begin with. All and all i would play another game or wait a year or two in the hopes that Elite: Dangerous decides to be Fun: Worth It

reviewText: I hardly ever write reviews but after 160 hours of gameplay in just a few weeks I think I can write an honest review. I'll start off by saying don't buy this game but I'll state that I liked it. The problem I have is more with the company and their marketing greed strategy than it is with the game. First off if you buy Horizons expansion you get this game for free. If you bought this game in the first year and supported them, you have to pay full price for the expansion as well (60$). I feel kind of ripped off by them. First off they were using our money to make an expansion they were going to charge us for and not adding any content to this game. It looks great, it flys great but they never added anything. It'd be like playing a single player game with no levels, content, and a few training bots flying around to shoot. It feels like they never finished this game and just put it out there to reep in money, and that's exactly what they're doing with Horizons now. Tricking people into buying that and then using that money to create some other game instead of making something out of this empty shell of a game. If you like practing landing in a beautiful space station all day, this is your game. if you want a reason to play a game look elsewhere. This thing is hollow and get's old fast. Wait for Star Citizen to come out and save your money

reviewText: Initially this game is spectacular! I have an older machine and it runs smooth as ice even though I don't meet requirements".  The graphics are clean and traveling the VAST universe is mind boggling...at first.  Then you quickly realize that there is almost nothing to do.  That being said
date:
I still enjoyed myself for a while and appreciate that there is a "Solo Mode" for avoiding griefers and player piracy.  Flying feels great and the learning curve is fun and interesting if you don't mind researching with a little bit of google.
I got VERY excited when Fronteir announced Horizons and the ability to land on planets and roam around in a little planet rover. My excitement quickly burned away as if It had hit the atmosphere of a planet too quickly when I learned that completely new players would get both the original & the expansion for $60.  I had paid $60 originally for the game and now they are asking me to pay an additional $45 for Horizons?  Putting me over $100 for the full game that I have to pony up while new players have to shell out almost half that.  I can understand Frontier needing to cover development costs and such and I would be happy to pay $10-15 upgrade cost to get Horizons but thier current pricing feels like I am being punished for buying their game earlier than others.  This is extremely questionable business practice. Therefor: Thumbs Down.   There is too little content  for a full-price game and very dissapointing getting dinged another $45 for the ability to land/drive on atmo-less planets.

Also
recommended: a note on your ships in game:  There are only a handful of ships and the ship design is BORING for 90% of them and only OK for the remaining.  You have one wedge-shaped ship to start with
hoursPlayed: then upgrade to a slightly different shaped wedge that is a little bit bigger.  After grinding away at repetetive missions/bounties you might upgrade to another
voteText: slightly larger
helpfulPercent: wedge shaped ship with nooks and angles!    But never fear
votesHelpful: you will notice when you land on stations there is a paintshop.  At least you can give your space-wedge a fancy paint job
votesTotal:
right? You will be enraged to learn to get ANY paint job for a ship you have to shell out $5 to Frontier for a pack of 5 colors for ONE model of ship.  Otherwise you will have stock coloring on your ship for all time.  $60 for a full game with 1/3 the gameplay features of a AAA title?  $100+ if I bought the original Elite: Dangerous and want to upgrade to Horizons?   And you're going to ding me $5 per paint job per boring ship?!  Is it too much to ask for two or three different paint designs by default or to find/buy them ingame?   These guys are greedy.


Edit: Wurds."

reviewText:
This is going to be a very long and detailed review with all the positives and a lot negatives (yes, there are many, even if the verdict is RECOMMENDED), I try to organize it and will put a TLDR on the end of it for those of you who aren't interested in short novels. I had a long review that became really outdated with the recent changes, alas I give you a new one.

Elite: Dangerous, isn't only a game. It's a dream of David Braben who basicly invented the genre with the original Elite decades ago and made it's sequel totally alone. Roughly 20+ years later here we are with today's technological possibilities, and we have Elite: Dangerous. But why should you care about this, as a customer?

DevelopmentED while is not marked as an early access title, it basicly is and is not. It is a complete, polished and very enjoyable game that however, is getting vastly expanded over time through yearly season passes. These deliver content partially exclusive to the specific season's owners, such as Horizons allows us to land on planets and do missions etc. there in a ground vehicle, but each patch also includes new content and general, often huge changes to the entire game, such as mission, reputation systems, more outfitting options etc. for free. Yearly season passes sure sound scary, and I won't lie it is an investment, but I'm telling you abot 99,9% of my playtime is spent with content aviable for everyone with the base game, so don't be discouraged to give it shot if you are looking for the best spaceship simulator even at full price. The current full price is half of what it used to be, and it was worth it even back then!

Audiovisual ExperienceCombined with the complex, yet easy to handle and very enjoyable ship controls (see this later), the audiovisual experience, the feeling of being really there in your own spaceship is the biggest strenght of Elite. Elite players are propably so used to it some would disagree, but for You who don't own it yet, it's the first thing you'll experience and it is a massive, professional and over the top quality thing in this aspect. The holographic interface's every centimeter is filled up with actual important and useful information, the ship AI always keeps you informed, and when you try to look around it's just breathtaking how detailed everything is while you know, everything has it's own use, it's not fake cool looking bunch of buttons you can't use". Graphically it is incredible

reviewText:
Played chicken with a pirate.  We both lost.  10/10 would midair (or midspace?) collision again.

In all seriousness though this game is strangely addicting.  That collision took place during my first dogfight aside from the training missions and I was about 15 hours of playtime in.  I spent the first 2 hours on the training missions and watching you tube videos about how to play.  So thats 13 hours of me just jumping from system to system exploring and doing trade missions, and I want more.  That's not to say you have to play that way, you can bust out of that first spaceport guns blazing at the first ship you see.

It's a sandbox game in the truest meaning of the word.  So if the lack of any kind of plot turns you off you and your lack of imagination are wanted elsewhere.

The controls make it easy to fly (with a joystick).  Although flight is unrealistic in this game as you don't have to counter thrust to overcome intertia (edit: recently learned you simply have to turn off flight assist).  That might be a good thing though as it could cause the game to be far more difficult to play and turn off any casual gamers who might otherwise enjoy it.

reviewText:
One of the new generations space sims. It brings a new gameplay which requires you to be patient but oh boy will it rock your world. You are a captain of your space ship and all you we do is fly your space ship everywhere you want. Landing your ship self or buy a module to auto land your ship if you can't be bothered to manouvre around space stations to find your designated landing pad.

Fully adjustable space ship, remove modules, disable modules, enable modules. Manage your power systems, more trusters or more shield or more to weapons. Deploy or hide your weapons. Go on a hunt for nice bounty or just go mining for precious metals to sell for huge profits. Or are you more of a trader or perhaps are missions more your thing?

But remember you are the captain of your ship and what happens if you run out of fuel and there is no refuel station around? Either prepare yourself you won't get stranted at an unknown system with no fuel to leave or there is only 1 solution but you'll have to find that out for yourself ;).

reviewText:
To start with, let me say that I adored Frontier: Elite II, and that is what brought me here, a promise of  reimagining of one of my favorite games of all time. I admit, I had some very negitive first impressions, but I decided to stick with it and keep my mouth shut until I had a better handle on what exactly Elite Dangerious had to offer. Now at 88 hours, with a nice ship, im still dissapointed.

So lets be fair about this,

Pros: Such a pretty game, eyecandy everywhere you look.
Dogfighting is engaging and fun.
The ability to customize pretty much every part of your ship is good, a little flat compaired to some games, but adds a tiny bit of much needed depth.

Cons: Game mechanics are sickeningly bad, and poorly thought out. Bounty system is rediculious, tedious, and painful. Basically a fury generator.
Almost no automation of any kind, expect to fly everywhere, no autopilot.
Factions are flat, similar, and lack depth.
Galaxy in general lacks depth.
Multiplayer seems more like single player co-op than an MMO.
Cant share money or trade with other players(short of ejecting things into space for them to pick up).
In order to 'protect the immersion' you wont get any numbers you can really use to make sense of what the systems, weapons and items really do.
Bounty hunting is the only way to make money early on, and the bad mechanics will come back to haunt you. Some fool will fly infront of your lasers, and you will get fined and hunted by the law for it. If you dont pay attention to the red blips attacking you, you will accidentally murder the fool in question, and you will be an outlaw for about a week, a realtime week.
NPC ships dont follow the same rules as PC ships.
So much of the games content is recycled over and over, which makes the game seem flat despite the massive gameworld. One day in, you will have seen all there is to see.
Game is run by devs who have the audacity to charge for content that should have come with the core game, and stand-alone it. You cant even paint your ship without shelling out $10, that would be acceptable in a F2P model, not acceptable in a paid for game.

Honestly, this game is the worst, most tedious parts of Frontier Elite, none of the good bits, and just very pretty. ONLY improvment over that old, old old FE2 is tracking turrets, really, only thing.

A nice dream and a nice vision, ruined by greed, narrow thinking, lack of content and Devs who have straight out said they dont care about what you, the player, wants. reviewText:
Certainly not what I expected for the money.

If you are looking for tough love, and enjoy figuring everything out for yourself, and being called names for asking a question, this is the game for you.
Unlike most games of the genre, or most games in general, there is a distinct lack of introduction to this game.
There are a few tutorials provided that are aside from the main game, but are very poorly executed, and appear to expect you to already know what they are showing you.  I don't know if the tutorials are out of date or just incorrect, but at times following the instructions simply does not achieve the result they intend, or any result at all for that matter, and you find yourself having to ESC out of the tutorial or be stuck there indefinatly.
While there is a large manual available from the launcher, it is not immediatly apparent, nor does it flow well as it feels very disjointed and cobbled together.  It is more effective purely as a reference manual for somewhere to go look up something specific when you need it, rather than ' read this and you'll know how to play'.
None of the usual 'this is how you work the interface' information is provided in a user friendly manner.
You will need to go to youtube and watch numerous videos, all the while being bombarded by advertising for Big Boobed Russian Women, a new ISP, local liquor shops, or, laughably, compeditive games such as EVE (I personally found this the most embarassing for the devs)
Even the presenter of these videos says 'press the key bound to landing gear' or whatever the function is that he is discussing.  If a player is advanced enough to have already changed the key-bindings, he is probably advanced enough to not need to watch these videos, or at least to know what key he changed it to.  The majority of the viewers have no idea what the default key is and expect the presenter to tell them.  Instead the viewer must return to the game and go searching to find the bindings section and write out all the keys, then go back to continue the video, then back to the game to try what they were just shown.  As I said, very disjointed and unprofessional.
All this leaves the casual gamer rather lost, and likly to walk away rather than slogging it out, and doing the hard yards.
In my opinion, a game should not be HARD or require such effort just to get started, to succeed and become an ace, yes, but not just to be able to leave the space-station and re-dock.  If I want hours of research just to get the basics, or hours of frustration when things don't function as they say, I would just go back to work, I already get plenty of frustration there, that's not what a GAME is about for me.
Most, more successful games, provide extensive in-game tutorials/quests/missions to walk you through the basics, which you can of course skip if that is not for you.  These quests/missions give you a feel for the game, so by the time you get into the meat of the game, you are THERE, not just sitting front of your computer pushing buttons.  I acknowledge there are plenty of people that don't like a full introduction and think it a waste of time, but I'm not saying the tutorials should be mandatory.  Most games default to the tutorials, and give the player the option to skip them if they choose.  This has almost become the defacto standard in the industry.
So while many games cater for BOTH player types, ELITE seems to specifically, either deliberatly or by poor design, target the later, those who don't want to do a tutorial.
The forums are full of new players complaining about the lack of tutorials, who are invariably set upon by existing players who attack them, with the usual 'it wasn't hard for me' or resort to pre-school standard name calling such as 'what a sook' or 'crybaby should run home to momma'.
What these people are missing, and the devs too, is that not everyone is the same, and while some players enjoy the struggle, others have a different deffinition of enjoyment.  Unfortunatly only the devotees seem to be catered for here, which is a real shame as the game has huge potential, great visuals, deep story line, etc, but a large portion of the market is being put off by the lack of accessibility.

reviewText: Kinda fun in the beginning but this game is by far the worse time hog I have ever played.
