reviewText:
This is the lamest piece of game design ever. Do you enjoy your planets bland and boring without an atmosphere? Do you like playing in a universe where light is eerily absent everywhere you go, even near to a star? Do you want clunky controls, a poorly imagined combat system and menus that chuck their potential out the window? Do you want a simulator that lacks any type of appealing game mechanic? Do you want a simulator that will make you sick with turbulance as you pilot a ship that can't hold a steady path even in the vacuum of space?

In a game where you do nothing but travel, I've never experienced travel that has been so poorly conceived. Terrible. Terrible. Terrible. But you should still buy this game. Why? Because the developers need your money. It appears they need at least 7.8 trillion dollars to build every imaginable anti-thesis of an enjoyable game before they can get around to actually building a good game. I should have backed Star Citizen.

Wake me up from cryogenic sleep when they've built something with some soul.

reviewText:
Allas one falls again for the startup campaigns of a sickly industrie. Let me first stress never to buy a non finished game. Wether you see games as an art form or a way to pass some time, one should be able to enjoy a game for what it is. As a long time player of games like privateer, freelancer or the more arcade style wing commanders i was hoping for an fun experience. Multiplayer space trade fun with friends.

What i got was an unfinished beta some rough edges and bugs that sucks the fun straight out of you’re chest. Flying around for a couple of hours not able to see or find you’re friend sucks.
Dropping out of a multiplayer game and have to restart the whole thing again sucks even harder.

The game itself is somewhat unforgiving and has a rather steep learning curve. Some will like the challenge and some will be put of by the notion. Fact remains it’s a game not ready for a release and will need quite some polishing. As it stands now it’s defiantly not worth a dime.

reviewText:
I really looked forward to watching this game develop. I bought in to it while it was still BETA. It's honestly awesome how much space there is to fly in. Being able to say I was flying around actual stars that exist was a bragging point for me.

I started out trading, which was extremely boring, but I needed to. I had to get a decent ship. Then I figured out that hunting people at stars and mining areas was more fun and profitable.

Then I realized that's all there really is to do. Either you sit around scanning everyone, waiting for a fight. Or you run cargo. You can also do the missions, which are similar to cargo runs, just lack the freedom of choice of destination.

The initial shine and warmth of this game wears off fairly quickly. The fact that you're flying around actual space locations becomes meaningless, and you're left with the repetative mission system, boring trade routes, and (most exciting part) dogfights with AI that have trouble landing their shots.

It's an impressive space simulator. It's a boring game. The future of it, by the way, is locked away as DLC, and even that is lacking.

reviewText:
To start with, let me say that I adored Frontier: Elite II, and that is what brought me here, a promise of  reimagining of one of my favorite games of all time. I admit, I had some very negitive first impressions, but I decided to stick with it and keep my mouth shut until I had a better handle on what exactly Elite Dangerious had to offer. Now at 88 hours, with a nice ship, im still dissapointed.

So lets be fair about this,

Pros: Such a pretty game, eyecandy everywhere you look.
Dogfighting is engaging and fun.
The ability to customize pretty much every part of your ship is good, a little flat compaired to some games, but adds a tiny bit of much needed depth.

Cons: Game mechanics are sickeningly bad, and poorly thought out. Bounty system is rediculious, tedious, and painful. Basically a fury generator.
Almost no automation of any kind, expect to fly everywhere, no autopilot.
Factions are flat, similar, and lack depth.
Galaxy in general lacks depth.
Multiplayer seems more like single player co-op than an MMO.
Cant share money or trade with other players(short of ejecting things into space for them to pick up).
In order to 'protect the immersion' you wont get any numbers you can really use to make sense of what the systems, weapons and items really do.
Bounty hunting is the only way to make money early on, and the bad mechanics will come back to haunt you. Some fool will fly infront of your lasers, and you will get fined and hunted by the law for it. If you dont pay attention to the red blips attacking you, you will accidentally murder the fool in question, and you will be an outlaw for about a week, a realtime week.
NPC ships dont follow the same rules as PC ships.
So much of the games content is recycled over and over, which makes the game seem flat despite the massive gameworld. One day in, you will have seen all there is to see.
Game is run by devs who have the audacity to charge for content that should have come with the core game, and stand-alone it. You cant even paint your ship without shelling out $10, that would be acceptable in a F2P model, not acceptable in a paid for game.

Honestly, this game is the worst, most tedious parts of Frontier Elite, none of the good bits, and just very pretty. ONLY improvment over that old, old old FE2 is tracking turrets, really, only thing.

A nice dream and a nice vision, ruined by greed, narrow thinking, lack of content and Devs who have straight out said they dont care about what you, the player, wants. This game is a puddle an inch and a half deep, and 100,000 light years wide. Unless you have endless money, time, and paitence, and a burning love for space sandbox games, I would not buy this game.

4/10 at best, and thats just for the eyecandy.

PS at 200+ hours;
Game patched to make it more grind, less action. Im just done.

reviewText:
This game is simply put amazing, if you even have thoughts about getting it then I advise you to get this game, it has some growing pains and some iritable gameplay mechanics but it's quite easy to get past that . - R34CT10N 74/100

Now for the full review:

EDIT: With the new expansion on its way, or would wait until the first portions arrive (Being moons) before purchasing.

I bought this game on Saturday the 25th of July and have already played around 20 hours of this game, this time has given me a very nice view on the game mechanics as well as a lot of time to explore and I did NOT get very far at all.  The game is pretty fun for a casual gamer, a very very fun for the hardcore gamer.

b] The Good![/b

This game is extremely fresh and has a lot of new gameplay mechanics that have been added to the elite series. Combat is really fun and enjoyable and if you're just buying the game for the combat you're probably looking at around 30 to 40 hours of continous gameplay however if you're looking into trading and doing the quest and missions then you're looking at 200+ hours and exploration, combat, upgrading, wishing you had more money, doing assassination mission, dying, dying again, exploring, trying to trade, failing at trading, and so on and so forth. This game is expansive, the galaxy is in a 1:1 ratio and takes several hours to get end to end. There are alot of updates as well (Most recent being the power play) The only problem is that it's addicting...

b] The Medicore[/b

While I will wholeheartedly recommened this game, there are some not-so-good features and while I expected some of these thing to be fixed, some of them are just gameplay mechanics that it seems the devs have overlooked.

My first complaint with the game is the quest/mission system and how certain mission aren't as fluid as others, the transport missions are great if you need some quick cash especially if you go further away from your strating system but the risk doesn't justify the reward, I did 5 Transport mission, all paid around 50,000 CREDITs and I got scanned once, ONCE! and once I got scanned the only thing that happen was a 2137 CREDITs fine, I understand this but it feels cheap money, I really wish I was interdicted once and pulled out of FSD and some pirate just tried to steal my cargo JUST so I could feel like I earnt my 50K, it really feels weird and sort of empty however I do belive this is something that will get added later as it seems the devs are going to try and add more detail in.

My second complant is with the assassination mission, unlike the previous Elite games you aren't given a time your target will leave a certain station nor are you given a certain place your target maybe or even when the will arrive in another system all your given is one thing and one thing only, which system it will be in. This is really annoying for me as I found my self looking around at any signal source and wasn't even told that the only place to find them was at Unidentified Signal Sources' which the game does not tell you. Again I feel that this is a depth issue and not a game breaking problem, however it is close, I really am waiting for them to add the ability to stalk my enemy and find the right chnace for me to kill them, I also really want the ablity for Federal Security Vessels to come and find me and kill me because I was trying to kill someone. Devs if you're reading this, this needs to be added, stat.

My Final complant is the lack of detail in the mission/quest screen. I picked up a mission to find trade data for someone and wasn't even told what type of signal I was looking for, this lead to my first hour being me trying to find something and LITTERALY dropping out every chance I get to have a lot around. I didn't get it in the end and this was a problem for me.

b] The Bad![/b

This is where I would explain to you the arguments against this game, but I can't find any,  the graphics are pretty, the OST is amazing, the SFX and shaders are super, everything feels like it's fitting in place....as long as you have a HOTAS and you are not playing with a mouse and keyboard. I started playing this game with a mouse and keyboard, I played my first 80 minutes of the game with them, then I ran and dug out my entry level thrustmaster T-Flight HOTAS that I bought back in '08 (Still make and sell them) I then change my settings and wow! this is so much better. Yes this game is worse WITH a mouse and keyboard and feels VERY clunky with one, please do your self a favour and get the same one I used during this time (Upgrade to the Siatek x55 WAY more expensive) you'll be doing yyourslef a favour.


h1] Conclusions[/h1]

This game is amazing, from the graphics to trading it is simply put mindblowing, it is however let down by lack of detail in mission and the requiement of a HOTAS, however minor these are problems that need adressing BEFORE it's perfect. This game is ONE HUDNRED PERCENT worth the 50 EUROs (40 GBP) that I put down for it and it's probably worth more.
-74/100
- LULZ R34CT10N
A Happy Customer

reviewText:
A game with beautiful heart. Wonderfully immersive cockpits and ship behaviour, realistically-feeling travelling system and docking.
Beautiful graphics and perfect optimalisation. Actually it runs better on ULTRA than on LOW graphics, from some unknown reasons (not complaining here!).

Unfortunately the game feels very empty and tedious. There are 400 billions of star systems, but I'll tell you that there ain't a single unique one.
The gameplay is a never-ending grind, you grind money to get enough money to buy the next ship, so you can grind more.

Once I bought the cobra, I stopped playing because I realised that I'll have to grind through that (largely unfinished, you need to use community tools to find deals) trading, planet scanning, criminal shooting.
You're completly free to do what you wish - of course, if you actually manage to find something interesting to do.

Powerplay is a nice idea, but it's very badly implemented.
Warzones are a stream of constantly spawning red/green ships that fight, the winner is faction with more kills at the end of week. While protection is just spamming of fetch & deliver quests.

Also, I tried to kill players numerious times. Spent hours flying around war systems - they always logoff or run away by spamming boost. Not cool. Managed to kill one player so far - he has my respect, for engaging in a fair combat and then getting murdered.

Most of the game, actually, feels like massively wasted potential, even though there's definitely a lot of effort put in this game.



Despite all of this, I still recommend this game. It's a great space simulator (not so much of a game/entertainment though), with immersive ship behaviour and beautiful cockpits that may make you busy for a very long time. It's relaxing and you feel like a little fish in (empty) space, and it's something completly different and new on the market.



The game keeps evolving through patches, so lot of this may change, and I definitely believe that it will.
I will try to play every update they release, and update this review (if I forgot - shout out and annoy me with it).



UPDATE: This game becomes so much better when you free yourself of the grind. I recently purchased a Clipper which was a ship that I was dreaming of for months. I equipped it just how I wanted it and still got a bucket of credits left. I don't need to grind anymore because money is pointless to me now, and I just do my random business, things that I feel like doing. It's so much more fun.

reviewText:
Well... to be fair... if your attention span is short... don't buy this game. It isn't for people who have to be force-fed content... now, on to the review!!!

I play with friends and meet people in game all the time. It's a good game, but DOES need a bit of polish. If FD starts delivering on things like planetary landing, and fps walk-around stuff, then I'll definitely never put this game down.

I already think that if you know how to entertain yourself and don't rely on a developer that spoon-feeds every single bit of potential that a game has to your baby mouth, then you'll enjoy Elite just fine... as for people who cry about having to ACTUALLY SEE OTHER PLAYERS... well... Elite has Solo and Private Group modes as well.

The flight/weapon physics in the game are awesome. If you are a bad pilot, even the simplest of encounters can turn deadly. If you are a good pilot, however... well, that's another thing entirely.

The Power Play is also a GREAT way to meet other players and come together to play Elite in a true multiplayer fashion. Facebook, Reddit, you name it, there are communities of people who ALL want to play the same Power Play pledge that you made... so there's always something to do.

Making money can be a bit of a grind as of now in E:D. However... I personally don't mind being mostly poor. It tends to fuel a drive when I fly to, you know, not die at the hands of other players.

Anyway... short story long, don't let poorly written, angry I shouldn't have bought a game that I thought would baby me and let me win all the time" reviews stop you from at least ASKING people who've put some hours in what they really think. Cheers

reviewText:
It's not a terrible game. But it also isn't a great or even good game. I would say it's mediocre at best. The problem I have is the grind for rank. It's terrible. There is really only two things to do for any kind of decent money. That's either trade or bounty hunt. While bounty hunting is really a lot of fun. How many times can you pew-pew a space ship down before that also gets boring.

Trading is okay...I guess. It allows you to make a decent amount of money in not so short of a time. It's just jumping from one system to the next.

Mining is horrible. It's slow, it's boring, it doesn't make that great of money. It isn't bad if you have other things to do, like catchup on a TV show on Netflix or watch the latest YouTube videos. Otherwise don't expect to be engaged by mining.

The game needs more content. I didn't cover exploring or missions. Exploring is only going to appeal to certain people while missions just don't pay well enough to do.

reviewText:
$60 for the early access (unfinished) Elite: Dangerous game
..another $60 for the early access Elite Dangerous: Horizons (unfinished) expansion
... make that $60 for the first and $45 for the expansion if you've bought the first one, and $60 TOTAL if you didn't buy the first.
I guess this pay model is the perfect example of why NO ONE should buy games declared 'Early Access'
Horizons is an expansion to this game released as a completely new game.
Anyone who paid for Dangerous is left out and has to repay for the game again if they want the 'update'.

They must have figured out that if they release the SAME game with an update under a similar, but different, name they can completely charge for it all over again.

I'm not falling for this. I refuse to participate any further.

Do I recommend this game? Absolutely not.

reviewText:
The simulation part of this game is a blast. However, I can't recommend it for the following reasons :

2) Aside from that, the game is quite empty. Piloting a space ship is nice, but not 27 euro nice. The space stations do not vary that much, the missions are uninteresting, and playing with friends does not bring much more fun.

Buy on sale if really interested.

5/10

reviewText:
NOTE: Alpha playtime is not reflected in Steam metrics

I find this game incredibly boring which might seem mystifying considering I love sims, particularly space sims. From WarHead on the Amiga to Independence War; to FSX; to Lockheed Martin Prepar3D; to any of the DCS sims.

So what makes ED boring?  It's the travel time. Regardless of whether you decide to be a pirate; trader; explorer; bounty hunter or anything else for that matter, the game requires you to travel to in-system star bases which can take up to 10 minutes of staring at blackness.  It's a bit ridiculous when you consider that a jump to a nearby star can be done in seconds!

Now before you go saying But wait
date: it's a simulator" I'd remind you that the "simulator" aspects of this game are quite crude compared to say FSX; P3D or DCS A-10C.  These latter sims also require you to perform lengthy travelling but at least in these sims there is something to do specifically in the form of detailed and complex navigation systems; systems that are no where present in ED.  I don't see any nav beacons; waypoints; flight planners; let alone an autopilot.   There's little or no systems monitors; engine startup procedures; engine status; damage control; emergency procedures (particularly considering you get to fly some big ships).\n\nIn all the other sims I mentioned
recommended:
I can be monitoring all of these systems to pass the time.  So what does ED offer? Some lame arcade-y "interdiction" mechanism that would be better served on a Nintendo system.

ED is a sim yes; but compared to FSX; P3D or DCS it's still an arcade game; a boring one at that.

Oh and the decision to put new content such as NEW HORIZONS into what is essentially a paid yearly subscription in MMO form is the nail in the coffin for this featureless simulation."

reviewText: I know I don't have many hours accumulated, but I feel my opinions are similar to those who have many and have not recommended this game.  At first I was in love. I had finally found an open world space exploration game with no rules and a giant universe (preceding no man's sky which I have been dying to play since its announcement) but after only about 15 hours the game lost its touch for me. The exploration aspect is great, although one can only jump from system to system so many times only to see the same exact stars, planets and spaceports over and over. You will lock onto a target and spend up to twenty minutes at full speed approaching it, only to inevitably overshoot your target and spend another 5-10 minutes trying to finally disengage. and then another 5 minutes once out of hyperdrive to finally reach your destination. once your 30 minute trek to a target is complete, you will try to pick up missions that you will also inevitably wait around for and end up realizing that your target is not going to show after countless time is spent searching random signals. You will be excited to upgrade your ship once until you realize that the next ship will cost 3 million credits. Like I said, I loved this game at first and was blown away by the sounds, and just overall realism and freedom in which you had in this vast world, but it became very repetitive and dull very quickly. I really wanted to keep playing but I don't have 1000 hours to waste and get nowhere. I love the concept but theres just simply not enough depth in the game and I believe it is just too difficult to earn credits and upgrade. Fun for a time waster of if your incredibly determined, but keep a smartphone or a book handy for those long flights.

reviewText:
Every sci fi fans dream game, nuff said!

On a serious note dont rage quit this game in the first hour!

It takes at least a day to learn basic flight and docking!

An a few days more to even get used to the basics of combat!

An a few days more after that to learn the trade, exploring, bounty, and how to setup your ship with the right setup for you!

An i probably have so much more to learn, this isnt a game for those with no patience, your going to see alot of bad reviews, or posts because people cant buy new ships or upgrades or they are not making millions of credits in the first hour of the game, (or even flying straight or dont know how to dock), it has a very steep learning curve but once you get the basics of it you cant seem to stop playing it!

Graphics are awesome, the sound from the space craft, stations, and just generally floating around in space really set the atmosphere, and i think the music tracks fit into the game perfectly.

Play solo with AI, or jump online with the rest of the internet, wing" up with your friends to fly together

If your a  super hardcore space simulation fan then my review is a waste of your time, I'm talking to everyone else that falls into my generael gamer bucket."

This game is not meant to be played by casual gamers. It's not meant to be played by even what I would consider your middle of the road gamers. It's meant for the hard core space simulation crowd

voteText:
hard on purpose? There is just no reason for it.

This game is not meant to jump in and play. It's fundementally designed to discourage this time of game play. Hours must be spent understanding aspects of the game before they can be used. Hours must be spent repeating the same manual boring tasks over and over again. Almost no player engagement. It's like playing a game that isn't really designed to be played. reviewText:
As a real fan of the original Elite, I was disappointed. This is not Elite - it is Frontier. Frontier is also a good game, but is very different.

Elite had an extremely simple interface, and was very playable. Spaceships exploded into tiny pieces in slow-motion, which was really cool. Docking was difficult but quick. Every control and feature played a part in the game - there was no wastage.

Frontier is a very detailed, but most of the detail adds nothing to the gameplay. Docking is 10 minutes of pointless intricate manouvers, which you have to do again and again. Spaceships explode but it's as if nothing happened. The interface is so cumbersome that it's difficult to get anything done.

Elite was fun, but Elite Dangerous is not - it's more like hard work.

reviewText: $60 USD for an early access expansion? ♥♥♥♥ing suck my ♥♥♥♥ Frontier Developments. Shipping bare minimum content out of the gate and asking me to trust you to deliver the rest later? I don't know about anyone else but the base game and its updates compared to the promises and designs in the beta don't exactly inspire confidence in me. As an additional kick in the balls, anyone who has NOT bought the game so far is going to be able to get all the content and the original game for $60. But if you've already bought the game, it costs you $105 total. And Frontier is wording it like you are somehow getting a DEAL for already having the game. That's not a loyalty discount, that's called screwing over the people who are already supporting you. What Frontier Developments is basically saying is, don't buy the game. Don't support us. Wait for the expansion to come out, and rely on the idiots to support us so that we can develop it for you, and get it for free. There is basically no information about what to expect from Horizons, and at this point I don't think it'd be worth it to find out. Take a long walk off a short pier, David Braben.

reviewText:
I had so much hope for this game, when I started reading about it. Open world with a more or less endless galaxy, infinite possibilities, do whatever you like, be whoever you like. Sounds amazing. I was watching youtube videos of different reviews and it looked amazing. When I found the game at 75% discount, I finally purchased it and looked forward to trying it out.

Started out in the sidewinder, and had good fun figuring out my very own keyboard setup and learning the basics. Initially I thought space looked amazing.

Unfortunately my view of this game cooled off pretty fast.

Some positive reviews point out how this game does a fine job in making you feel small and insignificant. That's true. No choice you make will really impact the game in any significant way. It's completely stripped of any story or characters worth mentioning. There is a story there, but it's just as boring as real life politics, and I quickly stopped caring about it. The fact that I cannot really affect the story in any way is interresting, but not too exciting. Feels like voting in real life. Voting is important, so I do it, but it's not like my vote really shifts real life politics. It's the same in ED, you can align with a faction, but it doesn't really matter. Other than that there are no characters you learn to love and care for.

In the start, my combat skills wasn't too good, so I more or less gave up and started trading in order to afford better equipment. A tedious few hours of grinding later, I bought a hauler. I had a few minutes of enjoyment flying a new ship with a new nice feel and new sounds. Then I continued flying empty space from station to station grinding more cash. After a while I gave up. It's just too boring, even with the occational interdiction where pirates were trying to steal my cargo.

I switched to doing missions. It didn't pay as well as trading, but at least it was different. At first. The missions I was able to do were more or less the same as trading. Sometimes it's actually exactly the same as when trading, but you simply use a different menu for adding the cargo to your ship and complete the mission. I tried some other missions, but combat was mostly too hard, and it seems the only other mission I could do was getting a canister of some cargo floating in space somewhere, and delivering it at a station. I decided to stick with trading until I could afford a viper and start doing some combat missions.

I finally got the viper, stopped trading, and switched to bounty hunting and doing combat missions. Fun for a few hours, but in a while it got just as tedious as trading. Fly around looking for some action. Scan ships, and take them out. It's fun learning an effective way of defeating the enemy, but once you learn it, it's all just the same. Wanted some more action and went for a combat mission where I got to take out an anaconda, the most impressive ship in the whole game. Unfortunately it was all the same as taking on any other ship, just took quite a while longer before it finally blew up. I got some help taking it down, but other than that... all the same.
I stopped doing combat missions and switched to exploring.

Exploring is more or less simply about jumping to a new system. Scan some stars, ice planets, rocky planets, earth like planets, and jump to a new system. Fill up with fuel, sell exploration data, scan, jump, sell, fuel, scan jump... Everything looks the same. Planets are the same, stars are the same. Every few hours I find something interesting or get sucked up in a huge firefight that makes the game a bit more interesting, but other than that. This too is just too tedious, but for some reason I just keep doing it, the game is very addictive. I decided to stop spending all my hard earned cash on new equipment for my viper and continue grinding in order to buy an asp. I'm now at 1.5M credits and start to wonder. What then?

In the initial youtube videos I watched, people kept talking about this being a game in development. We would get planetary landings... I started investigating when that would happen. Found out that you actually have to buy the Horizons expantion in order to get it, it will not be added to the original game. Now horizons is finally here. Is that worth buying? Well, looking at some more videos, it seems that this part of the game is about.... Landing, and driving aimlessly across the serface of the same, impressively large, but still impressively boring planets. There is simply just nothing interesting enough to see. And the price is five times what I paid for the base game. Well, at least I get a discount for already having bought the first one. I guess I'll pass and wait for star citizen or no mans sky.

Bottom line is:
The game is really empty and pointless. Giving you a feeling of insignificance really is no excuse. Not when you get the feeling from the game simply being empty and pointless. Everything is the same. Exploring space, stations, missions and combat. If you can get the game at 75% off, as I did, then maybe it's worth trying out as it will give you a few hours or days of fun before you realize how dull it is. At full price? Definitely not. I miss freelancer, wing commander, and all the other good old space games. I'll rather wait for star citizen and no mans sky and see if they have something more to offer.

reviewText:
Not at all related to this review, but if you do not like flight simulations, you will want steer clear of this game.  Do you have a joystick?  If the answer is no, you will want to avoid buying this game.  It's a combat flight simulation (IN SPACE!!) at its core, and frankly it's just not that enjoyable without a joystick in my opinion.... who knows, maybe I'm a purest.

At any rate, that has nothing to do with this review, more of an FYI as I haven't seen too many reviews point that out.  I do have a joystick and I happen to love a good combat flight sim, but for whatever reason, I just cannot fall in love with Elite: Dangerous.  I've put about 20+ hours into the game and while that's not sufficient to cover to entire depth of the game, it is more than enough time to acclimate myself with the game play and all the different career tracks" you can take throughout it.

What I like.

I have to say

Want to explore? You'll spend hours charting new systems

reviewText: I want to love this game so badly. It looks stunning and the scale is spot on. This game make you feel smaller than an ant and flying around systems at 25 times the speed of light can be amazingly terrifying. You don't know fear until you unexpectedly come out of super cruise at a neutron star in full throttle while checking a text on your phone, then franticly trying to escape it's pull knowing if you don't you'll be paying hundreads of thousands of dollars on insurance as well as lose all your exploration data. That being said, I've put hundreads of hours into this game, yet still feel like I've done and acomplished absolutly nothing at all. You'll be jumping from job to job because their all boring, (I've tried bounty hunting, mining, trading, and exploring and they all feel one inch deep and 1000 miles wide, and in this case that 1000 miles is literal distance you have to travel) then you'll eventually give up and quit the game like most players before you. This game is the most mind numbing grind I've played in a long long time. The multiplayer is boring in the base game, yet very hard to play right in Horizons, and planetary landing with a friend a near impossible to cordinate. On top of that, expansions are going to total at least $250 on top of the $60 for the game, making this a $310 game just to have a complete version, and you're sure as hell going to buy them because the base game feels so empty. Overall, I would recommend waiting for at least a few seasons of expansions to come out befor even considering buying this game. If it's in this state when No Mans Sky and Star Citizen release, it has no hope of competing.

reviewText:
I seriously loved this game at first. I still love it. It is just not everything it can be. I still play it from time to time to get my space sim fix but overall this is a lackluster game. It has a lot of promising content but the devs want you to shell out $60 USD every year for $10 worth of content.

+First Person Flying Through Space (Aww yisss!)
+Great Space Trucking Simulator
+Active Developer Community Moderators (It is nice to see people from Frontier on Reddit)
+You can join a wing with your friend and fly through space together. (More on this in the negative section)

-Difficult learning curve for new players using a keyboard and mouse. It took me quite a long time to get my keybinds to where it was comfortable to fly with a keyboard.
-Many game breaking bugs are put off until the next major patch forcing you to just deal with them for months. (I am looking at you Lost Connection to Transaction Server" mining bug.)
-Exploring the black is boring. Since all the systems are procedurally generated they start to look and feel the exact same. There are no cool space anomalies to witness like stars colliding or a black hole and a star colliding. Everything starts to look the same.
-The Power Play content seemed cool at first but it was quickly apparent that the different factions barely change game play at all. It is too easy to overlook to be considered a major feature of the game.
-While you can join a wing to play with a friend you can really only dog fight together or run trade routes together. There aren't any missions to do with friends. For being an MMO this game has almost no focus on the social aspect of the game
date:
it really feels like an after thought.
-Game feels more like a single player game than a multiplayer game.

I really want to recommend this game
recommended: but right now I just can't. I want to try Horizons also
hoursPlayed: but I just can't bring myself to pay another $60 and be disappointed again. I have played for 60+ hours so far
voteText: so I did get good value but at this point the game is so repetitive that I find myself not wanting to play at all."

reviewText: This game is really quite good, and there is a lot to it. The game's flight mechanics are simple enough that they can be easily grasped and intuitively controlled faster than with most flight games. Entering this game, you should expect a learning curve, and for part of the fun being exploring all the things you can do as you learn. If you're expecting the game to tell you how to play beyond basic tutorials or what to do to experience the game, you're going to blunder around for an hour, rage quit, and then feel the game lacks content and you were ripped off. This game is a sandbox. Be prepared to find your own way. Lets get to the game itself:\n\nThe general point of the game is to reach Elite" rank. You can do this via combat

reviewText: Over the years i have played a lot of sim games even the original elite from there i was hooked it was for me the best game out there well now they have revamped it in evey way. i highly recommend this game to anyone who loves flight sims and to the rest that dont play this type of game i still say get it. the game has 1 million planets to go to endless space stations. it is a bit hard to get used to at first, but give it time and you soon will be an expert pilot in no time. You start off with a small craft that cant do a lot but after a few jobs you then can start to build yourself a half decent craft. over time you will get bigger ships and better cash to spend upgrading them there are many ways to get credits  you can do cargo runs or be evil and get a bounty on your head as a pirate going around killing all in your way. The best way to play this is on a flight stick the game has so much depth in it youll be amazed at what the game holds as you play more into it. and now there is a add on coming so that you can land on planets get in your buggy and drive around or come in to orbit and see what goods you can take, i love this game and have put a lot of time in to this there is so much more i could tell you about this game but then i would spoil it for you. I hope this helps you in deciding if you should invest in this game i simply say yes get it you wont be disapointed in it at all.

reviewText:
I really wanted to like Vague: Dangerous.

From first impressions, you would think people giving the game negative comments are crazy. The game looks and sounds great and the initial flying around to explore a little is exciting. But then you actually want to start playing and request a mission...

Why do I call it vague? All I have done in my time in this game is hop from system to sytem looking for a mission to do, only to get something ridiculous about Find target X in the Y system". It's this lack of information that lead me to fail mission after mission simply because I don't know what they are asking me to do.

Is target X hanging around the star? Is he at a station? A planet? Deep space? I checked everywhere. X didn't show his ugly face.

reviewText:
Elite: Dangerous makes Star Wars look like amateur hour...Without the lightsabers and magical religion with fanatical samurai followers...
Let me just put it that way right now.

The game is pretty much a first person version of EVE Online. It puts you in with a very brief, to-the-point tutorial system, and after that, you're on your own! Dropped in the middle of some starbase in an obscure, unfamiliar, GIGANTIC! INCOMPREHENSIBLY HUGE galaxy(I've heard there are over 400 billion separate, identifiable objects in the map...Not confirmed info by the way!)

The game is pretty much....Well...The storyline of the game is that for you, there is no storyline...You're about to create it! You are given a free ship, and the lowest of the low armaments and utilities, and you're set against the entire galaxy with nothing but your cunning...Aaaand hopefully more than a little bit of pre-gaming research!
Once you even figure out how the darned controls work, your next order of business is deciding what you're going to be...A trader? A smuggler? A pirate? A mercenary? There are many more things you can do than that, but I'm just not aware of them yet(Allegedly).
Next up it's pretty much exactly like EVE Online; you jump from star system to star system with your Hyper Drive, go do what you arrived at the spot to do, and then hop skotch from system to system back to where ever you're going, etc. etc.
Sounds pretty simple right? Trust me, it's not. From intercepting pirates, to the crushing, almost inescapable gravitational pull of stars and black holes(If you get too close!), there are all manners of things to look out for...Even the damnably easy sounding task of docking at a flipping space station! GAWD! Could they have made it any more difficult!?!?!?

Be that as it may...If you like space ship games, and more importantly, if you like a challenge, then I couldn't recommend this game more. It's great fun, and you really get that sense of achievement, even from something seemingly simplistic like doing a mission! Everything in this game is automatically set to Very Hard difficulty, and if you can't handle the complexity, then I suggest going with something easy, like Star Trek Online or something.

And the graphics? Well considering I have a GeForce GTX 980 Ti, then I'm probably not the go-to person for those with lesser hardware in comparrison, so honestly, I have absolutely no idea how well this game works at lowest settings.
But for the high tier hardware users, you're in for a treat. This game is absolutely stunningly beautiful, and every detail is taken into consideration. If your thing is eyecandy, then you're gonna LOVE this, even just sitting in the cockpit(A ♥♥♥♥ PIT!? WHERE! TOSS ME IN PLZ!!!) is a thrill ride for those enjoying big fancy graphics!

Seriously, if you enjoy video games about space travel/combat/exploration, and if you enjoy your games being natively difficult, and making every accomplishment you make, a considerably important one, then I highly, highly suggest you get this title!
But if you prefer your games to be simplistic, easy, and generally casual, then I don't think you should give this one a go.

reviewText:
(Please not that my playtime is not accurate; I've put around 70 hours into the game off of Steam)

Elite: Dangerous is a decent space sim. It certainly has its moments; dogfighting through asteroid fields, getting rich after finally finishing a trade route. However, once you've played a couple hours of the game you've essentially seen everything it has to offer. Sure, there's bigger ships, there's better weapons; you could spend a few hours travelling to see a black hole; but most of the game will be spent mindlessly drifting from system to system, occasionally stopping in at a station for refueling, hoping that your next trade or bounty will finally give you enough to afford that next ship. The game is huge in scope (you have an entire galaxy open to you) but most of that galaxy is empty. The game's world is vast, but once you scrape the surface, you'll realize that it's equally shallow. As you travel around, you'll begin to realize that you're really just seeing the same things again; the same stars, the same planets, the same stations, the same NPCs... if you're inclined to spend hours travelling between systems, there's a few unique sights, but it really doesn't justify the tedium of getting there. Frontier has created a gigantic, intimidating universe, but it's completely empty.

Speaking of Frontier, ♥♥♥♥ those guys. I know every other reviewer has already mentioned this horse ♥♥♥♥, but I can't help but rant a bit.

I paid seventy dollars for this game in early access. People who paid sixty or  seventy dollars (as opposed to the game's current price of thirty) had to pay significantly more than new players, not to mention full price for the game's mediocre DLC. And speaking of the DLC, what in the unholy ♥♥♥♥??? Context: Players who buy the DLC before buying the game, will get both the DLC and the original game for $60. Players who already own the game and buy the DLC, pay $120, or more. This is ridiculous. This is the kind of cash-grabbing ♥♥♥♥ that even EA wouldn't dare to pull. Yeah, I said it. Frontier is worse than EA.

I can't deny that I've enjoyed my time spent playing the game itself, but that's not nearly enough to justify this idiocy. Please don't validate Frontier's ♥♥♥♥-headed payment model by giving them your hard-earned money.

reviewText:
I seriously loved this game at first. I still love it. It is just not everything it can be. I still play it from time to time to get my space sim fix but overall this is a lackluster game. It has a lot of promising content but the devs want you to shell out $60 USD every year for $10 worth of content.

+First Person Flying Through Space (Aww yisss!)
+Great Space Trucking Simulator
+Active Developer Community Moderators (It is nice to see people from Frontier on Reddit)
+You can join a wing with your friend and fly through space together. (More on this in the negative section)

-Difficult learning curve for new players using a keyboard and mouse. It took me quite a long time to get my keybinds to where it was comfortable to fly with a keyboard.
-Many game breaking bugs are put off until the next major patch forcing you to just deal with them for months. (I am looking at you Lost Connection to Transaction Server" mining bug.)
-Exploring the black is boring. Since all the systems are procedurally generated they start to look and feel the exact same. There are no cool space anomalies to witness like stars colliding or a black hole and a star colliding. Everything starts to look the same.
-The Power Play content seemed cool at first but it was quickly apparent that the different factions barely change game play at all. It is too easy to overlook to be considered a major feature of the game.
-While you can join a wing to play with a friend you can really only dog fight together or run trade routes together. There aren't any missions to do with friends. For being an MMO this game has almost no focus on the social aspect of the game
date:
it really feels like an after thought.
-Game feels more like a single player game than a multiplayer game.

I really want to recommend this game
recommended: but right now I just can't. I want to try Horizons also
hoursPlayed: but I just can't bring myself to pay another $60 and be disappointed again. I have played for 60+ hours so far
voteText: so I did get good value but at this point the game is so repetitive that I find myself not wanting to play at all."

reviewText:
One of the my favorite games in many many years.  Simply put, if at any point you were a fan of games like Freelancer, Descent, EVE, or of course the old Elite titles... this is the game for you.

Pro's :

- open world with not-quite MMO level multiplayer interaction.  The effects of players in single-player, private-group and open-world all have the same impact on the universe.  The same will be true of the upcoming XBOXONE version of the game.
- a wide variety of things to interest players, from trading to bounty hunting, missions and pve 'ratting' to mining and even exploring a galaxy that consists of OVER 400 BILLION STARS!
- Comprehensive controls that can be used by the most novice player, and refined to the desired complexity that a long-term flight sim / space sim player would want.  It's viable to play the game with a KB/Mouse just as it is with a controller or a joystick or HOTAS.

Cons ;

- Learning curve is a little steep if you go it alone.  Finding a community of other players to help you learn will make the transition smoother and faster.
- Along with that, there's no real in-game 'community' or guild mechanism, meaning all player groups really only exist at the metagame level and are harder for players to find and join.
- Frontier is notoriously opaque in regards to the math, mechanisms, algorithms, and reasoning behind how many aspects of the game work.  While this allows them some lattitude in deciding to make changes without causing public uproar, it also differs from the way that most developers and players operate in this day and age, where transparency and trust go hand in hand between the userbase and developers.
- This is not really a con, but can be for some right now.  The game is not really complete, nor will it really ever be.  This means that a lot of things you would expect to see in a highly polished game (guild system for instance) do not exist, but as the developer is committed to growing, building, and expanding the game long term -- I'd say that's fine.

All in all I *highly* recommend this game to anyone who will listen.  I have already dropped more than 2-300 hours into it (as of the time of this post ~100hrs on Steam, plus a couple hundred hours prior to the game keys for steam being provided).  A lot of that time has been spent on my own flying around the galaxy exploring and getting my name attached to the 'first found by Lukano!' stamp on celestial systems and points of interest.  I have also seen super massive black holes at the center of the galaxy, and lived to talk about it.

reviewText: Frontier has developed a solid core game which they can now expand upon. They've given attention to detail in the different looks of each ship, which even have their own individual sound effects. Space looks amazing, and is deadly all the same (black holes are fun!). Three core paths to reach elite status in, factions to gain rank with, and now Powerplay on top of that. Plenty of ships to fly with more being added. Best of all, pay once and play forever, so you can take a break and do something else while waiting for the next update to come if you grow bored. All in all a very enjoyable first person space game.

reviewText: The trailer is misleading as hell. But it's an incredibly fun game if you're not only looking for action. That's to say there isn't action, there is. You can fit your ship to become a battle ship, but you can also fit it to be an exploration or trading ship. All paths are interchangable whenever you want to change. I've been playing as an explorer and I'm still not bored with it, nor have I even had enough money to purchase the next ship. I really enjoy how either laid back or fast paced this game is. It's your choice to choose how you play.

reviewText: So far I have some time in and I have to say, this is a pretty fun game.  I've enjoyed it so much I ordered a joystick and throttle just to add more dimension to it.  Graphics are pleasing, sound effects are what you would expect.  You get the female computer voice that makes you want to have a conversation with while jumping through multiple systems.  A cool effect is when your cockpit blows out everyhting gets muffled and silent.  Controls are a little rough when using mouse and keyboard but still playable.  There isn't a ton of content if you compare this sandbox to say GTA but really what game does.    It's a game that YOU the player needs to make the story.  You can take on bounties or be the hunted.  You can spend time just travelling and exploring, scanning objects to collect credits.  Future expansions will provide more exploration involving landing on planets.  The learning curve is set pretty high, however, if you go in knowing you will take the time to learn the controls and different aspects then you will be an Ace in no time.  If you come into the game thinking you will master it in a hour you will be mad and more than likely post complaints on the forums.  If you are a casual gamer wanting to jump in and play for an hour chances are you won't like the game and complain on the forums.  DO NOT BUY THE GAME IF YOU EXPECT BATTLEFIELD STYLE GAMEPLAY.

reviewText: Elite: Dangerous combines the open universe fun of Eve Online with the freedom to shoot, trade, and explore found in the X series. With no choke points to be camped at, three modes of play including solo, online, and private where each uses the same character in a persistent universe that is affected by your actions. Shoot pirates, steel cargo, smuggle, trade, mine, and explore in a galaxy containing over 400 BILLION stars. On top of this help shape the future of galactic politics in the new Powerplay expansion; a completely free and completely optional sublayer of the game that offers bonuses and rivalries to keep you occupied for many hours.

reviewText:
Space, the final frontier. These are the voyages of the Starship Enterprise. It's five-year mission: to explore . . . *Warning: Interdiction Detected! Pirates proceed to gangbang the ship into oblivion.

Welcome to Elite: Dangerous. The do whatever you want simulator. The game throws you into the cold, vast void known as space, where its up to you to choose your destiny. Do you want to be a space cop, and dole out justice to all those evil pirates, or innocent pilots that accidently sat afk to long somewhere, orrrr do you want to be a heartless murderer who hunts truckers and other like for money, well you can do either! You can also be a said space trucker and listen to music while you fly through space, researching trade routes and profitable merchandise on your long journies. Great for those who want to take it slow and enjoy the beautiful surroundings. You can also be a miner, which, I can't honestly say much about, because who has time to shoot space rocks with lasers when I can shoot OTHER PEOPLE with lasers.

Theres lots to do and see in this game, and you can move at your own pace. Money can be made fairly freely through either trading or killing, and it doesn't take too long to upgrade ot a larger ship. The games great fun, and the sense of scale is there, especially when you duel it out in a massive space battle a few days distance away from a planet.

The sound is also incredible, from the ratling of your autocannons peppering enemy ships, to the missiles and lasers that tear and cut through hulls respectfully. The music is also fairly calming as well, and even a bit funny at times, such as when you're presented with The Blue Danube Waltz  as you autodock into a station.

The visuals are likewise, just as good, when you're tearing through space near the speed of light. You'll be thrown into what appears to be wormwholes, seeing a dull, entrancing tornado of light enshroud your journey to another system. You'll pass by colossal, eye catching explosions of light as your emerge near stars. And the first time you dock into a massive space station, and get tucked away into your own very little hangar, you'll get a sense of protection and a profound calmness thats hard to explain. They all tie together to make the game feel like you're actually in space, and not just coasting through the air with a black sphere around you that has some stars painted on.

Combat is fairly detailed as it is simple. You can outfit yourself with a variety of weapons ranging from lasers, autocannons, missles, torpedoes, and the like. You can aim center mass and try to blast your targets away, or, you can surgically strike at key internals of their ship, such as their powerplant, thrusters, cockpit, etc. I can tell you I never get tired of seeing my autocannons create ripples of light that dance around the enemies hull as I waltz around them. It's truely a sight to behold, as is the specteral beams of light wisking around the enemies shields as I fire my lasers.

There are a few issues in the game, primarily with the AI misbehaving. Enemy ships are way too easy to kill, even for a beginner, and they often make very poor decisions elsewhere, such as when docking at a station(They slam into walls and get caught in various places). In general, they just have poor pathing, You can also accidently tap" an ally in combat with friendly fire
date: and cause all allied ships in the instance to want you dead. It may seem like an annoyance to accidently hit a teamate
recommended: but considering that high conflict instances can have A LOT of ships flying round
hoursPlayed: its a lot easier than you'd think.\n\nWhile not wide spread
voteText: the issues with this game are fairly degrading to the experience(considering the vast amount of AI ships you will encounter compared to player) and hold it back from being a much better title. However
helpfulPercent: the game is being updated over time

votesTotal: Elite: Dangerous is still a thing to behold. I would suggest watching videos of gameplay to be sure you actually enjoy the pace.\n\nBut in general

reviewText:
Overview:
Pros:
-Beautiful Visuals
-Flight and Combat that requires skill to be efficient
-No subscription fee. Pay for it you own it.
-Slower paced, long term gameplay

Cons:
-Missions can be repetitive (but there is an update coming!)
-DLC Prices (personally I think it is worth it, but I know some people are ♥♥♥♥♥♥. I bought the lifetime pass since there are 10 years worth of expansions planned, and I see great potential in the expansions)
-The ship you start in sucks (Explained later. Yes I know that is how it is supposed to be).
-Flight is supposedly unrealistic (I'm not a physics expert, but I like it).

The visuals in this game are absolutely stunning! There are so many things to go see including black holes and stars orbiting stars and all sorts of planets (which we can't land on yet but eventually!). Speaking of landing on planets, some people are mad that Horizons is only letting players land on planets and moons with no atmosphere, but eventually we will be able to land on ALL planets (well I guess you can't land on Gas Giants, but you can fly in them I guess). Frontier is just spacing out the releases of landable planets into the expansions which makes sense to me because it probably takes a ton of work to make all the planet surfaces for different kinds, but I digress.

There are some issues with the game. A lot of people complain that the missions are boring and repetitive. I completely agree. The missions do get repetitive; however, there is an update coming to the game that is going to completely change the mission system, so don't let that discourage you. From what I've heard, you won't need to buy Horizons for the mission update.

This brings me to the next topic, the expansions. A lot of people have been complaining about the price of the DLC, and I can see where there are coming from. My response to that is you don't have to pay a subscription fee for the game. Other games such as EVE Online require you to pay monthly, but with Elite: Dangerous it is just a one time fee. I feel that the money someone would put into a subscription game vs. the pay and play forever is pretty much equal. If that still doesn't satisfy those people, then they could have gotten the lifetime pass since there are 10 years of expansions planned for the game. If each expansion is $60 it would've payed for itself after 3 expansions.

Another thing that people complain about is the combat taking forever; however many of those people only have an hour or maybe two hours posted which more than likely means one thing. They are still in the starter sidewinder. Of course combat is going to take forever in the sidewinder!!!!! It is the starter piece of ♥♥♥♥ ship that is meant to be garbage! It cant really do ♥♥♥♥! There is also a chance that maybe those people actually got to the Eagle or Viper but probably didn't upgrade it which is another reason combat would've taken forever because they weapon they give as stock weapons is also ♥♥♥♥♥♥, but that is the point. You have to work and upgrade your ship. Personally, I fly a maxed out Vulture for combat, and I can fry ships in a minute or two. Much faster than these outrageous claims of 20 minutes to kill one ship.

People also complain about the turn speeds, and while I don't know much about physics I must say that I can't really complain about the turn speed. All I really feel you have to do is set Flight Assist to a hot key and toggle it off while you turn and then back on. If you are in a smaller ship you'll turn pretty damn fast that way. Of course the bigger ships like the Anaconda and Python might  take a little longer to turn but the Anaconda is 152.4 meters long (almost 1.5 football fields) and the Python is 87.9 meters which is smaller but still huge! Ships that big probably will take a long ♥♥♥ time to turn. I will admit that the YAW is pretty horrendous though.

The last thing I want to talk about is the boring" factor. A lot of people are saying that this game is boring
date: but it is just slow paced. This isn't your fly around a shoot em' up get to the top quick game. It is definitely long term style of gameplay that requires patience and dedication. If that doesn't sound like your kind of game then just don't even bother. There are people that enjoy a slower pace and there are people who need action constantly. If you think that latter is you
recommended: go play CoD or something. If you're the former

reviewText:
Literally the best experience I've ever had in a game just happened to me in E:D.

I'm in a 1-on-1 dogfight with the target of an assassination mission. He's in a larger and heavier ship than mine, so I'm strafing him to whittle down his hull and mostly stay out of his range. Things are going fine, he got my shields down but all I have to do is retreat until they come back online and then move back in to continue poking holes in his hull.

But then my engines got destroyed -- and my canopy blew out at the same time.

My ship was tumbling completely out of control, my computer was screaming warnings at me with muffled sound (no oxygen in the cockpit), and a timer started counting down; 7.5 minutes until I ran out of oxygen and suffocated.

For about a minute, I just accepted my fate as I tumbled, watching the timer count down and the rings of the nearby planet spin in and out of view.

Then I remembered this menu option I had seen earlier: Reboot/repair". I activated it and watched as my cockpit went dark
recommended: then came back online one at a time. It worked. My thrusters were repaired. I restored power to them
hoursPlayed: targeted the nearest station
voteText:
and warped out.

I made it inside the dock with 1:19 worth of oxygen remaining.

Words cannot do that experience justice. It was 100% unscripted
helpfulPercent: but felt exactly like something out of a movie. I literally sat there after I docked for about 5 minutes
votesHelpful: reflecting on what had just happened.\n\nGod damn I love this game."

reviewText:
Elite is a classic. That said in the most broad, literal of meanings, of course - released in the '80s it brought space to games for the first time. It's impossible to deny that it still does that, but... space brings with it an inherent flaw.
Nothing.
So much nothing.
I'm not a great pilot, that much is obvious to anyone who's ever flown with or against me, but I have to say the combat in the game is nowhere close to how it's represented. Maybe that's me, but ships turn at quite a slow rate, even the more 'maneouvrable' ships like the Eagle, and while combat is interesting in its own way, it's not as fast-paced as many would have you believe.
It's also interesting in a similar way to Euro Truck simulator (although I do hate to equate these games) in that a lot of money can - and most likely will - be made from hauling, illicitly or otherwise; that choice is yours. And perhaps that's why I love this game, the choice. You can go anywhere in the galaxy, and don't let sci-fis like Mass Effect fool you, the galaxy is bigger than you could possibly imagine. There's so much travelling to be done, it's unparalelled. But, even with FTL travel (which is done really well, but I'll get to that)... space is a whole lot of nothing. The first thing I noticed when I brought this game was that it's small for such a big title, only 5-6GB. It took me a while to realise that this is because most of it is empty. Space doesn't really need assets to fill it, even if there is the occasional conflict zone or Signal Source you can drop in on.
Luckily though whilst the speed/distace capabilities of the game and your ship are realistic, the ability to travel faster than light is present and believe me, that's a good thing. The realism of the vastness of even just one solar system hits home when you realise that without powering up FTL, it would take you well over a year to make a dent in the progress of even the least significant of journeys. So you're given two levels of FTL, two 'tiers' as it were; Supercruise and Frameshift. Supercruise handles speeds between 0.1C (C being the speed of light for those who don't know) up to maybe 100C on long journeys. Frameshifting then is the next step up, and where Supercruise is intended for travel between two stations in a single system, Frameshifting is for travel between two systems. There's no set number on the speed, but your dial flicks about and usually hangs around the 10,000C mark. You don't have control of your ship when you're Frameshifting, but it gets you where you want to be.
That's travel down. The next thing to talk about is probably combat. I touched on it earlier, but I never gave it the credit it does deserve. Like I said, it is interesting in its own way, although it's a little slower than people might expect going in. My recommendation within this recommendation? Get gimballed weapons asap. Anyway, tracking targets, scanning and fighting are fun and there's a lot of skill involved, since the most skilled of fighters can take out the heavier ships since even if it's noticeably scaled down, it's still relative.
Progress can also be slow, but for a game which is part-MMO that's to be expected. Building influence with a system party can take a long while (especially if you're a smuggler) takes time and trust, but pays off in the long run. But not being able to put in 50 hours or so and be at the endgame is what makes putting the time in worth it.
Speaking of building influence and puttign time in, there's plenty to do to pay the bills. Combat is the most obvious (although seldom the most lucrative right off the bat), with Hauling a close second. But there's also mining, exploration (since you can come back from hundred of light years away and sell the exploration data for hefty sums) and Powerplay.
Powerplay is the ongoing war between the Alliance, the Empire, and the Federation. I won't say there's protagonists and antagonists, since... well, there isn't - each faction stands for itself and is neither 'good' nor 'bad' (but join the Alliance anyway) and the player can make any choice they want to support whoever they want. Powerplay is almost like the next tier up from standard play, carrying important documents to systems in need of expansion or fortification, or even just plain shooting down the enemy.
That's pretty much all I have to say about Elite: Dangerous. I do recommend it, but make sure you know what you're buying first.
Oh, and make sure you know a good radio station or a good wingman. Those cockpits can get so lonely.

reviewText:
Euro truck simulator 2, with space battles.

*Edited after a decent ammount of hours playtime*

This game isn't for everyone. The game isn't very friendly for new players, it's difficult to get into, you will find buggs, the tutorials aren't very good and the game doesn't tell you what to do once you're realeased into the world. It's a slower paced game, somewhat grindy and traveling in space is a big part of it.

With that said, this game is amazing. I can't even wrap my head around the size of this world, it's litterally mind blowing. If you have any sort of interest in space, if you own a HOTAS, or simply just a joystick you owe yourself to buy this game, sit down and invest the time it takes to learn and understand it. It works great with mouse and keyboard, but for the sake of immersion, a joystick is WAY better. The game isn't for everyone, but if you invest some time on youtube to find out what there is to do in this world, I'm almost certain that you will get your moneys worth of fun with this game. Sure, the task might get somewhat repetative over time, but it's a damn good game nonetheless

Hostile as it might be to new players I still can't do anything other than recommend it, amazing game.

reviewText:
Short version: If you can get it on sale and are willing to look past the problems, it can be a lot of fun. Only get it on sale.

Long version:

I recommend this game, but with caution, and only when the game is on sale. Why is that, you may ask? Well, it's because in it's current state it is a bit of a mess, and the dev's seem more intent on adding new content than fixing what's already there.

I'll give some examples, which also act as 'cons' for the game.

The missions are broken, no doubt about it; You're tasked with hunting a pirate in another system, so you head over there, only to find they are nowhere to be seen, or you have to smuggle goods into another station, but the exact millisecond you drop out of supercruise you get scanned, or if you make it past that the station security will ram & scan you.

That brings us to the next topic of broken A.I.: You want to go and bounty hunt, only to find that the enemies will sometimes stop in place and just spin, allowing you to shoot them without a fight. Or the aforementioned problem of ram & scan, where a station NPC will just throttle into you while scanning you, and then YOU get charged for reckless flying.

The devs don't seem to be doing much about it, and are working on essentially pointless features for the expansion. So you go onto a rock to shoot some rocks or maybe a floaty thing, and you've seen all the expansion has to offer. And then, instead of making it so there's a point to going down, they decide, Hey
date: let's add faces to the game and some shiny things to craft!"\n\nAnd those issues just scratch the surface; There's no real point to Horizons
recommended: the instancing is broken... the list goes on.\n\nSo why am I still giving this a thumbs up? Because between all the problems with the game
hoursPlayed: you'll still have more than your moneys worth for $20. Just do what you want to do; Shoot some things as a freelance bounty hunter
voteText: or haul some goods to a station in need
helpfulPercent: or maybe mining is your thing? Just don't do missions for now and you'll have a blast. Sure
votesHelpful: you may argue that you shouldn't have to avoid missions
votesTotal: and you're right. FDev really needs to do something about it. But you can still have fun without them
votesFunny: which is what I've been doing and I've been having loads of fun.\n\nNow the important question: Do I think that Frontier is going to fix the game? I think the answer is yes. They may not be the best at communicating with the community

column17: that's fine; just come check back in a few months. Maybe you're right maybe I am. But if I am right

column19: then Frontier will deliver on making this game what it has the potential to be: Amazing."

I was really looking forward to Elite, most the negative reviews didn't sway me since I don't mind games with a bit of a grind.

reviewText:
I haven't played too much of Elite: Dangerous, but from what I have played, I have loved it. It is a very immersive experience (especially if you can get your hands on a VR headset) and even when not in combat (haven't experienced too much of it, 2 or 4 battles) it's pretty relaxing.

There is a bit of a learning curve, but doing the tutorial really helps out in this situation. The controls are top-notch, and the ambient music is very nice, but turning on some chill tunes and just flying from destinations is great.

It also reminds me of real life, at certain stations, there are not many docking stations, so you must wait for one to open. I usually take this time to talk to the other players (or captains, as players are called in-game) and it is strangely entertaining, although when you have 10 min to complete a mission and the docks are filled, it can kind of suck.

All in all, is it worth the $60 price tag? I would say yes, but not everyone can get a hang of it, so I reccomend watching some streams of it or Youtube videos.

reviewText:
Elite: Dangerous is the only space game that I like so much since nexus jupiter incident.

Here are the things that I like about it:
+ the scale of the star systems is huge
+ the jump ability is easy to use
+ ships are beautifully designed
+ 1st person angle made me feel like I am the pilot
+ the interior design of ship is nice
+ bounty hunting is fun and enjoyable
+ it gave me a strong feeling that I'm in space when I'm playing it, especially when I travel near a sun or a planet
+ it is nice to fly with other players through space
+ nice game mechanics

It's a worth playing space game.

reviewText:
This game is very good for what it says it is... a space simulator where you can roam the universe and do whatever comes to your mind. You can mine... you can bounty hunt... you can do police work.

However, getting started can be a pain in the ♥♥♥... and between these awesome moments of getting 100k credits off of one mining trip or blasting the heck out of a bunch of wanted fighters is a lot of boring... boring... boring travel and errands.

Some people (me) embrace this and simply make it part of the experience, but i can understand where some would get frustrated and impatient with the games slow progression and pacing.

Overall this game is very good and definitely delivers on the aspects advertised... even though there can be some very dull points.
