reviewText:
I'm editing my review to make a much shorter, more easily digested review. I will leave the original below the dotted line.

The pros:
It's really fun
I managed to squeeze wel over 1000 hours of gameplay out of it to this day and I am still playing
The gameplay is superbly designed and the grinding does not feel like typical grinding
The sound effects are amazing. Just superb 10/10 each ship sounds different
Each ship and starport look very nice. The graphics are indeed beyond pretty good.

The cons:
The game completely lacked immersion until Horizons came out, and I am not buying Horizons, so it still lacks it for me and could lack immersion even with Horizons. This is due to the lack of impact I have within the world and how everything I do just translates to me being given credits. No matter what I do, I'm always paid in credits and never get some kind of other reward, or an option to do something else with my ores/stolen goods/bought goods.

In open play you may find a lot of hostile players who blow you up for no reason. I have however not experienced this, but I have seen dozens complain about it.

There is a lack of player on player interaction unless you go out of your way. In other words we lack guilds, corporations, etc. All we got are forums to communicate, wings to form and private groups to manage. It helps, but it's not enough for easy, large scale moments.

Nothing encourages you to play in open play, which makes it too easy to pick solo, which can feel lonely and at the same time put you off from going online later. It depends on the induvidual.


-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


I have no idea how to really review this game. It is both geat, but at the same time manages to disappoint me in some aspects.

When I first started playing I had all this awe and a feeling of wonder. I saw a guy in trouble, being killed by a pirate. From his dialogue I felt deeply in need of rescuing him. From his words of gratitude I expected him to either join my crew, or even let me take over his ship, but no. The game had none of that. The awe disappeared and settled for a more realistic view within 2 weeks.

There are a lot of features that were promised before the game came out, that didn't make it into the game, and still have not entered the game to this date. A few are:

Being able to hijack a ship, to take it for yourself.
Have multi passenger ship, aka have you and 2 friends control a ship together.
Having the ability to walk around stations as well as your ship.

Those are 3 features I was really excited about. Hopefully they are gonna come soon, because the game has been out for a year, and I still don't see them anywhere in sight, while Frontier has made DLC.


Overall the game breaks down to 5 aspects, and you can play either as you like:

Exploring. Buy a ship, fit it for exploration and have it be self-sustained for long travels. Explore 100,000 light years at once if you want to, and return to a station to claim your reward for your exploration data.

This is however pretty samy all the way through, and not that interesting. It's kind of like fishing. Some people love it, some like it, and others despise it.


Pirating. I've chosen not to do pirating, but this requires you to fit a ship for combat, and blow ships up to steal their cargo. Or you can disable their systems, and force them to drop their cargo, and then steal that. You also buy/sell stuff from the black market in some cases.


Trading. Ah, this I enjoy. It's similar to exploring in the aspect of flying around and seeing a lot of pretty systems, but I find it to be the 3rd most fun thing in Elite. It's very enjoyable and gives a steady profit, while being fairly low risk.


Mission running. Now this I like. Missions are varied, and go from being combat oriented, to being emergency missions that require you to get medical supplies or food for a station. My 2nd favorite activity.


Bounty Hunting. Now this is the juiciest part of this game for me. I love combat, and the combat system in this game feels good. The mechanics and everything is well polished and feels great. I keep coming back to this game 2-4 weeks at a time 3-6 times a year to immerse myself just because of the combat system. Bounty hunting works by going into mining belts, or following signal sources, and then blowing up anyone who is a wanted criminal. It's simple, elegant and fun.


So overall, Elite is a repetitive game, but it manages to stay fun due to how well the game is made overall.


Now to some cons of the game:

There are not nearly enough ships. I felt like going from a sidewinder to a cobra was a big deal, and going to an ASP also felt really big. Then from an ASP to a Python it didn't feel as great, but it still felt really good. However, that's not a lot of ships. I could get an Anaconda, but I never wanted one, and I really don't feel like it would swoo me after my old Python, and current Imperial Clipper.

I want more choice and options. For combat, I pretty much have one single path of ships to choose from, unless I rank up in the federation or empire.


Then we have the weapons. Now overall I think the weapons are pretty great and each type feels unique, but I have to go over the issues that weapons have.

The really good ones, suffer from a lack of ammo in some cases. Especially my favorite weapon against hull, namely missiles. I freaking love missiles, but they are limited to class 2? why? god why??? and also the ammo capacity is barely enough for 1 anaconda. What's up with that? Multicannons of the same class are way weaker, but have enough amoo for 3, maybe 4 anacondas. I just don't see why missiles have to be so gimped in damage as well as ammo, but mostly in ammo.


I also feel like cannons have a bit too low ammo, but nowhere near as bad as missiles.


The biggest gripe to me is however not related to ammo, or damage or heat. It's related to weapon variety/classes.

I want class 3 multicannons and class 3 missiles, but they don't exist. Also the best multicannon is rank F? Are you kidding me? Where is the upgraded version? I'm really glad I use large hardpoints for thermal weapons, but when facing a large ship, class 2 weapons are nerfed against their hull, making the battle take long unless I really get in there.


Some other weapons that are great against hull have class 3. For example a plasma accelerator, or a fragment cannon. I'd just like a bit more weapon variety, as well as better versions.

I mean, I've used the exact same setup on my cobra, ASP, Python AND Clipper. I would have expected to use at least something else by now, but I have not. After 500 more hours of gameplay, I'm still using the same god damn thing as I did 500 hours ago. I'm either forced to change to use something that I don't like, or I have to gimp myself by using the only weapons that I do like. Either choice is not optimal, but I have no choice but to stick with my original setup of the best near stable lasers + gimbailed multicannons.

I absolutely recomend this game if you are interested. You may be doing the same thing over and over a lot, but it does not feel grindy.


I don't really know how to rate this game on a 1-10 scale like I do with other games, but if time spent enjoying a game counts towards it being good, then Elite definitely has an 8/10 or better. I do somehow feel that due to a bit of laziness on the developer's side that a 6/10 might be fair too.

So as far as my rating goes, I'll give Elite: Dangerous a 7.5/10. It has promise, but it has got to show it to deserve an 8/10 or 9/10, which I feel is the highest I will ever be able to rate this game.

reviewText:
I can't really recommend this game unless you are a really big fan of simulation style games in space.

First and foremost this game is not new player friendly at all. Not the community they've been pretty good but the lack of real tutorials or explanation of concepts is just awful. I bet about 80% of the people who play this just bail on it after they cant figure out how to even move their ♥♥♥♥ left and right correctly. They depserately need one single training scenario where they use the default keys for mouse and keyboard and explain what they do.

The framework of the game is simple:

- Smuggle
- Trade
- Pirate
- Explore
- Mine
- Warrior
- A little of them all

These are your 'classes' and they are detrmined by your ship (once you can afford it). For example if you want to be a big money trader you need to have a large cargo hold so you better work on getting a ship for that - but most of the ships with large cargo holds are very expensive or can't fight back so you basically end up just getting a hauler in the start and lugging goods all over jumping from star system to star system boring yourself to tears. Every once in a while you'll get interdicted which mean someone rips you out of superdrive (which is your cruising speed in a system map) and tries to fight you to steal your cargo. These little battles are usually pretty annoying. I've had a few times where I had fun but its usually when the ship pilot is so stupid he runs in to me and blows himself up.

Mining is absolutely pointless. You make so little money its a wonder anyone would ever do it.

Pirating is kind of fun for a bit but then gets very repetitive and you realize that you're a griefer.

Smuggling is kind of exciting the first few times you do it then it gets boring and repetitive - the quests are basically identical. It reminds of WoW quests... the location changes but the quest remain the same.

The Galactic Powers are pretty cool and the trade good selection is cool. The ships are appealing and the space ports look amazing. However the rest of the game is so.... bleh.

After the initial wonder period of about 10 hours you'll get bored pretty fast. We found the multiplayer aspects of the game (cooperative) really crappy. I mean you can't even share updates on a quest you all have to talk to a person to continue, etc. Why? One example are those really terrible quests where you need to wait for x number of minutes for someone to show up and go 'hey bud, deliver the weed to grassland ok?'

I want to like this game so badly because the concept is so cool but damn is it boring and redious. I like trading but sometimes even with a good FSD (the thing that makes you travel really far and fast) jumps can be in the 20-30 range... I mean its like 30-45 minutes of staring at black space and white dots flying by.... its soooo boring.

Trading is the ONLY really good way to make consistent money. Everything else is a huge waste of time. Especially mining. At least fighting in conflict zones is kind of fun and makes some decent money assuming you dont get blown up by a master level anaconda or something.

Speaking of combat, also not too bad but sometimes the AI is too good - like when they constantly boost when you've got them in sight. Ends up being 15 minutes of rapid turning. (yes Im not super great at combat yet but Im okay)

I'd give this game a C+. It really needs to get more exciting... more varied weapons, more variation in quests, useful professions, better reputation and galactic powers system, etc. So much potential that just sits there wasted. As of now its a barebones grind fest for money and standing.

And the developers did a nice job they really did so don't think Im calling the game terrible because I'm not - it's just so mediocre in the fun department because there just sin't enough meat on the bones yet. My friends and I have a hard time enjoying it together and that's when you know a game is not doing something right.

reviewText:
It's a beautiful, but very empty shell of what could have been a great game.
Pros:
1. It's a gorgeous game. The planets and suns look fantastic, the effects are also very well done, and to top it off it runs quite well on my system. (GTX 750 Ti - Intel i5 46770k)
2. HUGE map. Lots to see and explore.

Cons:
1. Ship progression is very linear. There's no point in flying in any other ship than the best one for your class, you really don't have a lot of choice.
2. Empty. With the lack of a hub world (Like Jita in EVE) it's very hard to plant your roots anywhere, and meet other players. There isn't a guild/corportation system either so even if you find a group it's hard to stay together. The wing system is horribly implimented and pointless, a friend and I tried to travel together but it was so damn confusing we decided I'll just meet you there". Would it have been so hard to just impliment a 'follow autopilot' kinda thing? Also with the fact that most people are grinding out ships in single player there's just absolutely no player interaction besides getting shot at. This was a long section...
3. The physics are all off. I feel like I'm playing War Thunder in space
date: but in less maneuverable planes. Most of the ships I've played feel sluggish and turn slowly
recommended: there's a pointless hard limit on speed. You're in space
hoursPlayed:
there isn't an atmosphere to slow you down! Please...
4. The mission system is just plain boring. Very repedetive.

TL;DR It's a blonde bimbo of a game

reviewText: The game looks cool as you start to play it, sound design is really nice, and everything looks cool. I really like how docking in space stations works.  However, once you get past how cool stuff looks and sounds, the game is really stale. Cargo hauling becomes really boring after a while. Dock at a station, buy stuff, go to next station, repeat. Also, it may have a bazillion star systems but it doesn't matter because they're all the same. One might have a different color star, a few more or less planets, and a space station with a different name, but thats about all the variation. I hear they added planetary landings in the new Elite Dangerous Horizons"
recommended: which doesn't seem nearly worth it to me to drive a buggy around an empty planet."

reviewText: I lost a lot of smuggling missions due a bug that NPCs scan you without you receiving a 'scan warning'. This bug is there since along time and they don't fix it. Needless to say that I lost a lot of my time and potential game credits due to this bug. Frustrating! but it should be fun right? I contacted the support for 5 times but got no single reply or statement on this. There are a lot of these little bugs or annoyances that the company refuses to care for. Examples ? You do not have a rear view (even cars today have it but a core fusion propelled spaceship capable of travelling faster the light does not have this), they sell custom ship paint jobs for money but do not provide a working 3rd person view, there are millions of star systems but no way of bookmarking any of them, etc, etc. Instead of giving the game some love and fixing bugs and straightening edges they sell you full prized expansions. Meh. It hurts to not recommed since ED is essentially a very good game but the company is after milking customers than improving on the core mechanics.

reviewText:
As much enjoyment as I have gotten and continue to get, I cannot recommend this game to new players.  the 2.1 patch was not well thought out, not well implemented, and just made a mess of the game.  Its made NPC's difficult for seasoned pilots.  Random encounters would spell trouble for new pilots.  NPC's interdict and attack for no reason.  Some are interdicting and attempting to steal cargo from a ship that doesn't even have cargo holds?  Did 2.1 go through any sort of testing process before it was carelessly tossed out the door?  The engineers update seems tacked on and unnessessary.  It almost makes the game pay-to-win as people without the expansion will miss out on upgraded components.

There are a number of different activities you can do, such as bounty hunting (make sure you have plenty of lube), trading, smuggling (though that was nerfed into the ground as well), mining and exploration.

Exploration seems thew most active segment community.

EVERYTHING is a major grind, which sucks a lot of the fun from the game.

reviewText:
The company behind this game has the right idea. Unfortunately the good news ends there.

Pros
------
Flight control is great
Compatability with  numerous HOTAS and flight sticks
Oculous rift
Immersion
Sound design
Art
Ship Designs
etc.
Just overall the base game is great and i thoroughly enjoyed getting into dogfights.


The bad news however is that the DEV team has no clue what they're doing.

Cons
-------
P2P NETWORKING: This means there are 0 server checks for their code. Simple hacking like memory editing your shield to be unbreakable is easily achievable. Anything you can think of is pretty much a hack in this game. Infinite ammo, infinite power for modules, etc etc. Combat logging is a huge issue with this networking structure as well. If anyone is flying around a multimillion credit ship and is a risk of losing it they can just ALT+F4 the process and they are immediately removed from space. Visually their ship will hang there for a few moments but you wont be able to damage them any further and then it will shortly disappear. They can then log into solo mode and fly to the nearest station and repair with no issues. The sad part is that the DEVs condone this behavior and say that it isnt a cheat.


SOLO/OPEN MODE: Open mode is where you can pilot through the Elite universe and are able to interact with other Commanders (players). This is of course the most fun mode due to random instances other people can create. For traders it would be the risk of running into other players roleplaying as Pirates and for Pirates it would be other players hunting them roleplaying as Bounty Hunters. Unfortunately not only does instancing as i stated above ruin the possibilities of having player interaction the balance between SOLO play and OPEN play do too.
There is 0 incentive for any trader to trade in open because there is no buff to gains made while trading in open. So typically the best way to make money is to trade in SOLO mode while binging on netflix and then when you want to pvp you bring a fully decked out 200 million+ credit  combat ship to open and have your way till insurance makes you poor again and then do it all over.  The DEVs also have stated that this will not be changed and they have no plans to everr change it. Go ahead, google it. This ultimately means trading is the one true profession in this game because thanks to SOLO it can't be stopped. Which means PIRACY goes out the window as a lucrative position due to the rarity of targets.
And due to that bounty hunting is only viable in resource sites where there is npc pirates. BTW thats broken too. as in you have to reset it multiple times to get the instance you want. SORRY!

I also feel i should mention that everything anyone does in SOLO affects powerplay in OPEN. So the PVE only playergroup MOBIUS who has thousands of members could potentially outpush every other group because they only play solo. They cant be stopped. Brilliant faction gameplay 1/10.


CONTENT: There is a serious lack of content. out of all the hours ive played i never gave a damn about the progressing background story. I never felt interested in the POWERPLAY update. The weapons that were for tier 3 or so of your powerplay rank were never tested in the beta for powerplay and thanks to that they were released as trash. the way some factions weapons operate also make 0 sense for that faction. Why do pirates get a weapon for shield stripping thats only effective if you're literally kissing the enemy ship? But the police faction get a weapon perfect for piracy. a hit to a module will shut that module down for a few seconds at range.
powerplay was paraded around as a huge content update but it turned the incredibly grindy nature of Elite into even more of a grind. You either mine for credits, trade for credits or res farm for credits. i could actually go far enough to call this space farming simulator. Only difference is that this has pewpew.

oh and by the way they did everything they could to discourage you from taking part in powerplay. once you join a faction get ready to evade interdictions as often as 5 times in one minute. The spike in NPC hostility is INSANE once you join a faction. Its almost not even worth it. Even in your factions home system you will be interdicted religously by enemy faction NPCs that just roam around and chill there. IT MAKES NO SENSE.
Your faction HQ will also not even be aligned with the type of heirarchy that your faction parades around as.
One of the FEDERATION factions home system is claimed as INDEPENDENT..... what!?

CQC: This isnt even out yet but there was a QA for the DEVs that they released on their forums that was incredibly discouraging.
There was a lot of speculation that CQC (because its a dedicated pvp arena) would be released without p2p networking and there would be dedicated servers.

BIG FAT NOPE! They're gonna hold fast to their p2p structure and release a broken pvp arena mode. Hackers welcome.



TRAILERS: Holy ♥♥♥♥. They are the most misleading videos. The game is literally nothing like any of their trailers. fighting around stations wont happen. There's a zone enveloping every station that penalizes you if you shoot near it and if you manage to hit the station you're just dead, Station guns will just annhiliate you.
the WINGS video. Things never go down like that. You got valuable cargo and 3 guys staring down that hauler? Well see when more people show up, as soon as the first shot is fired the most effective way to stop them is to, well, gib that cargo hauler. In an actual hold up once those wingmates fired that hauler would just get lit up, No fancy manuevers in that fat ship.

So for my final statement ill just say the games fun, but not $60 worth of fun. Get it on sale. Perferably 50% off or more.

reviewText:
Anytime before 06/05/15, I would've recommended this game. It had promise and I found it quite enjoyable... until powerplay. Powerplay ruined Elite: Dangerous and plagued it with bugs galore, even after fixing most of the bugs it felt stale with a cliché government system now added. As of 05/08/15 all my hope for this game has offically ran out, creating an expansion with a £39.99[www.frontierstore.net] ($85.77AUD) paywall, I bought for the game for $60AUD and I'm not paying another $85AUD to unlock features that were promised to be in this game.

I give this game 3/10 for the direction that its going in.

Don't buy this game, you're better of waiting for Elite: Dangerous Horizons if you don't want to waste your money.

reviewText:
Great Space Sim. Once you get a HOTAS or at least a Flight Stick, it will make things much easier. Playing this game without a flight stick is like playing a FPS without a mouse.
The best thing about this game is that it's a sandbox... the size of our galaxy. Seriously.
Some of the celestial bodies are beautiful to behold.

Overall score 9/10 - I paid full price and got my money’s worth.

What could have made this game perfect:
Other professions besides combat, like exploration, trade, and mining can get tedious and boring. Don’t get me wrong, these professions are here for the people who don’t want to combat and put their ship at risk. It’s the slow and steady way to earn your way in the game… but sometimes it’s too slow.

What makes this game awesome:
The ship selection and almost endless ship customization and upgrades really add to the game. Where this game really shines is Flying and Combat/bounty hunting. Combat is top notch and can get extremely complex. You can take down enemies with sheer force, and you can even take down enemies stronger than you with your skill. There is so much to do during combat, it doesn’t get boring.
Graphics and sound are also top notch. There’s even a third-party add-on that allows you voice control of you ship--awesome.

reviewText:
Best flight game in years.

It's a MMO/MMORPG/Sandbox/etc world so don't expect anything to hold your hand. If your into the linear games with a strong cinematic story avoid this one. It does have a rich lore if your whiling to read the books.

Other than doing one of 4 major professions (Combat, Trading, Mining, Exploration) your gonna have to RP for fun. You can do just about anything so you get a nice Sandbox feeling if you stray away from the major professions. The fun will be what you make of it. Kind of like the Arma series.

I have an absurd amount of hours into this game already. I bought it pre-steam sales.

reviewText:
First: I played the game about 30-40 hours before I added it to Steam.

After the first few hours in the game everything seems to be repeating. There is no motivation to go on and do the same things over and over again.

Also, the prices for the add ons are plain ridiculous. I am not paying 200+ Euros for a single game and its future content. My understanding at release was, that for example planetary flight and landing would be introduced later in the game, I thought okay, maybe 5€ DLC no big deal, but this is not acceptable.

I don´t see a reason to continue to play a game were I can´t even modify the looks of the ship in the slightest way nor change the colour without buying it. Sure, nothing serious either, can´t get an advantage out of a red fighter can I? What bothers me though, is that you get the feeling, that you have to buy everything... And not for a small amount of money, it adds up to huge amounts if you look to future releases. I am going to play Everspace and No Mans Sky when they come out and I will return to Elite: Dangerous in a few years and buy everything for a tenner.

A lot of wasted potential in my eyes... Especially since the concept is really nice. But the greed of the people behind it ruined it for me.

Maybe EA is involved in the game afterall...
